This had gone on for a month or two when there came a Saturday in September, on which a fair and a market coincided; and the pilgrims from Trantridge sought double delights at the inns on that account. Tess’s occupations made her late in setting out, so that her comrades reached the town long before her. It was a fine September evening, just before sunset, when yellow lights struggle with blue shades in hairlike lines, and the atmosphere itself forms a prospect without aid from more solid objects, except the innumerable winged insects that dance in it. Through this low-lit mistiness Tess walked leisurely along.
这种情况持续了一两个月，到了九月的一个星期六，恰逢集市和集市。因此，来自特兰特里奇的朝圣者在旅馆中寻求双重乐趣。苔丝的工作使她出发较晚，因此她的战友们比她先到达了小镇。那是九月的一个晴朗的夜晚，就在日落之前，黄色的灯光与发丝般的蓝色阴影搏斗，大气本身形成了一个前景，没有更坚固的物体的帮助，除了无数有翅膀的昆虫在其中跳舞。苔丝在这昏暗的薄雾中悠闲地走着。

She did not discover the coincidence of the market with the fair till she had reached the place, by which time it was close upon dusk. Her limited marketing was soon completed; and then as usual she began to look about for some of the Trantridge cottagers.
直到到达那里，她才发现市场与集市的重合，此时已近黄昏。她有限的营销很快就完成了；然后像往常一样，她开始四处寻找一些特兰特里奇的村民。

At first she could not find them, and she was informed that most of them had gone to what they called a private little jig at the house of a hay-trusser and peat-dealer who had transactions with their farm. He lived in an out-of-the-way nook of the townlet, and in trying to find her course thither her eyes fell upon Mr d’Urberville standing at a street corner.
起初她找不到他们，后来她得知，他们中的大多数人都去了一个与他们的农场有交易的干草捆工和泥炭商人家里的所谓私人小吉格。他住在小镇的一个偏僻角落，在试图找到去那里的路线时，她的目光落在了站在街角的德伯维尔先生身上。

‘What—my Beauty? You here so late?’ he said.
‘什么——我的美人？你这么晚了？”他说。

She told him that she was simply waiting for company homeward.
她告诉他，她只是在等人回家。

‘I’ll see you again,’ said he over her shoulder as she went on down the back lane.
“我会再见到你的。”当她沿着后巷走时，他越过她的肩膀说道。

Approaching the hay-trussers, she could hear the fiddled notes of a reel proceeding from some building in the rear; but no sound of dancing was audible—an exceptional state of things for these parts, where as a rule the stamping drowned the music. The front door being open she could see straight through the house into the garden at the back as far as the shades of night would allow; and nobody appearing to her knock, she traversed the dwelling and went up the path to the outhouse whence the sound had attracted her.
走近干草桁架时，她能听到后面某栋建筑传来卷轴的拨动声。但听不到跳舞的声音——对于这些部分来说这是一种特殊的状态，通常跺脚声淹没了音乐。前门开着，在夜色允许的范围内，她可以直接透过房子看到后面的花园。敲门时没有人出现，她穿过住宅，沿着小路走到外屋，声音就是从那里吸引了她。

It was a windowless erection used for storage, and from the open door there floated into the obscurity a mist of yellow radiance, which at first Tess thought to be illuminated smoke. But on drawing nearer she perceived that it was a cloud of dust, lit by candles within the outhouse, whose beams upon the haze carried forward the outline of the doorway into the wide night of the garden.
那是一座没有窗户的储藏室，从敞开的门里飘来一团黄色光芒的薄雾，苔丝起初以为是被照亮的烟雾。但走近后，她发现那是一团灰尘，被外屋里的蜡烛点燃，薄雾上的光线将门口的轮廓带入花园的广阔夜色中。

When she came close and looked in she beheld indistinct forms racing up and down to the figure of the dance, the silence of their footfalls arising from their being overshoe in ‘scroff’—that is to say, the powdery residuum from the storage of peat and other products, the stirring of which by their turbulent feet created the nebulosity that involved the scene. Through this floating, fusty debris of peat and hay, mixed with the perspirations and warmth of the dancers, and forming together a sort of vegeto-human pollen, the muted fiddles feebly pushed their notes, in marked contrast to the spirit with which the measure was trodden out. They coughed as they danced, and laughed as they coughed. Of the rushing couples there could barely be discerned more than the high lights—the indistinctness shaping them to satyrs clasping nymphs—a multiplicity of Pans whirling a multiplicity of Syrinxes; Lotis attempting to elude Priapus, and always failing.
当她走近一看，她看到一些模糊的人影在舞者的身影上跑来跑去，他们的脚步声之所以寂静，是因为他们穿着“草帽”套鞋——也就是说，是泥炭储存中留下的粉状残留物。和其他产品，它们湍急的脚的搅动创造了涉及场景的云雾。透过这些漂浮的、发霉的泥炭和干草碎片，与舞者的汗水和温暖混合在一起，形成一种植物人花粉，静音的小提琴无力地推动着他们的音符，与小节的精神形成鲜明对比。被践踏了。他们一边跳舞一边咳嗽，一边咳嗽一边笑。在匆匆而来的情侣中，除了高光之外，几乎无法辨认——模糊的形状将他们塑造成紧紧拥抱着仙女的萨特——许多潘斯旋转着许多注射器；洛蒂斯试图躲避普里阿普斯，但总是失败。

At intervals a couple would approach the doorway for air, and the haze no longer veiling their features, the demigods resolved themselves into the homely personalities of her own next-door neighbours. Could Trantridge in two or three short hours have metamorphosed itself thus madly!
每隔一段时间，一对情侣就会走到门口呼吸新鲜空气，雾气不再遮住他们的面容，半神们将自己变成了她隔壁邻居的朴素性格。难道特兰特里奇在短短的两三个小时内就已经疯狂地变形了！

Some Sileni of the throng sat on benches and hay-trusses by the wall; and one of them recognized her.
人群中的一些西莱尼人坐在墙边的长凳和干草桁架上。其中一个认出了她。

‘The maids don’t think it respectable to dance at The Flower-de-Luce,’ he explained. ‘They don’t like to let everybody see which be their fancy-men. Besides, the house sometimes shuts up just when their jints begin to get greased. So we come here and send out for liquor.’
“女仆们认为在露斯之花跳舞是不值得尊敬的，”他解释道。 “他们不喜欢让每个人都看到谁是他们的心上人。此外，当他们开始润滑时，房子有时会关闭。所以我们来这里并派人去买酒。

‘But when be any of you going home?’ asked Tess with some anxiety.
“但是你们什么时候回家呢？”苔丝有些焦急地问道。

‘Now—a’most directly. This is all but the last jig.’
‘现在——’最直接。这只是最后一个夹具。

She waited. The reel drew to a close, and some of the party were in the mind of starting. But others would not, and another dance was formed. This surely would end it, thought Tess. But it merged in yet another. She became restless and uneasy; yet, having waited so long, it was necessary to wait longer; on account of the fair the roads were dotted with roving characters of possibly ill intent; and, though not fearful of measurable dangers, she feared the unknown. Had she been near Marlott she would have had less dread.
她等待着。影片即将结束，一些人正准备开始。但其他人不肯，于是另一种舞蹈就形成了。这肯定会结束它，苔丝想。但它又融入了另一个。她变得焦躁不安。然而，等了这么久，还得等更长的时间。由于集市的缘故，道路上布满了可能怀有恶意的流浪者。尽管她不害怕可衡量的危险，但她害怕未知的事物。如果她靠近马洛特，她的恐惧就会少一些。

‘Don’t ye be nervous, my dear good soul,’ expostulated, between his coughs, a young man with a wet face and his straw hat so far back upon his head that the brim encircled it like the nimbus of a saint. ‘What’s yer hurry? To-morrow is Sunday, thank God, and we can sleep it off in church-time. Now, have a turn with me?’
“别紧张，我亲爱的好心人，”一个脸上湿漉漉的年轻人在咳嗽声中劝告道，他的草帽一直高高地戴在头上，帽檐像圣人的光环一样环绕着它。 ‘你急什么？感谢上帝，明天是周日，我们可以在教堂时间里睡个好觉。现在，跟我一起来吧？

She did not abhor dancing, but she was not going to dance here. The movement grew more passionate: the fiddlers behind the luminous pillar of cloud now and then varied the air by playing on the wrong side of the bridge or with the back of the bow. But it did not matter; the panting shapes spun onwards.
她并不讨厌跳舞，但她不打算在这里跳舞。乐章变得更加热情：发光云柱后面的小提琴手时不时地在琴桥的反面或弓背上演奏来改变空气。但这并不重要；气喘吁吁的身影向前旋转。

They did not vary their partners if their inclination were to stick to previous ones. Changing partners simply meant that a satisfactory choice had not as yet been arrived at by one or other of the pair, and by this time every couple had been suitably matched. It was then that the ecstasy and the dream began, in which emotion was the matter of the universe, and matter but an adventitious intrusion likely to hinder you from spinning where you wanted to spin.
如果他们愿意坚持以前的伴侣，他们就不会改变他们的伴侣。更换伴侣只是意味着其中一方还没有做出令人满意的选择，而此时每对情侣都已经合适了。就在那时，狂喜和梦想开始了，其中情感是宇宙的物质，而物质只是一种偶然的入侵，可能会阻碍你在你想旋转的地方旋转。

Suddenly there was a dull thump on the ground: a couple had fallen, and lay in a mixed heap. The next couple, unable to check its progress, came toppling over the obstacle. An inner cloud of dust rose around the prostrate figures amid the general one of the room, in which a twitching entanglement of arms and legs was discernible.
突然，地上发出沉闷的重击声：一对情侣倒在了地上，混杂在一起。接下来的一对夫妇无法检查其进度，因此翻倒了障碍物。房间里的倒地人物周围升起一团灰尘，可以看出房间里的手臂和腿在抽搐。

‘You shall catch it for this, my gentleman, when you get home!’ burst in female accents from the human heap—those of the unhappy partner of the man whose clumsiness had caused the mishap; she happened also to be his recently married wife, in which assortment there was nothing unusual at Trantridge as long as any affection remained between wedded couples; and, indeed, it was not uncustomary in their later lives, to avoid making odd lots of the single people between whom there might be a warm understanding.
“我的先生，当你回到家时，你会为此受到惩罚的！”人群中突然响起女性口音——这些口音是那个因笨手笨脚造成这场灾难的男人的不幸伴侣的口音。她碰巧也是他新婚的妻子，只要夫妻之间还有感情，这种类型的人在特兰特里奇并没有什么不寻常的。事实上，在他们后来的生活中，避免结交一些可能有温暖了解的单身人士并不是什么不寻常的事情。

A loud laugh from behind Tess’s back, in the shade of the garden, united with the titter within the room. She looked round, and saw the red coal of a cigar: Alec d’Urberville was standing there alone. He beckoned to her, and she reluctantly retreated towards him.
在花园的树荫下，苔丝背后传来一声响亮的笑声，与房间里的窃笑声融为一体。她环顾四周，看到了一支雪茄的红炭：亚历克·德伯维尔独自站在那里。他向她招了招手，她才不情愿地退到他身边。

‘Well, my Beauty, what are you doing here?’
“那么，我的美人，你来这里做什么？”

She was so tired after her long day and her walk that she confided her trouble to him—that she had been waiting ever since he saw her to have their company home, because the road at night was strange to her. ‘But it seems they will never leave off, and I really think I will wait no longer.’
经过漫长的一天和步行之后，她太累了，所以她向他吐露了自己的烦恼——自从他看到她以来，她就一直在等待他们的陪伴回家，因为晚上的路对她来说很陌生。 “但他们似乎永远不会离开，我真的认为我不会再等了。”

‘Certainly do not. I have only a saddle-horse here to-day; but come to The Flower-de-Luce, and I’ll hire a trap, and drive you home with me.’
‘当然不。今天我这里只有一匹鞍马；但到了露斯花店来，我会雇一个陷阱，然后开车送你回家。”

Tess, though flattered, had never quite got over her original mistrust of him, and, despite their tardiness, she preferred to walk home with the work-folk. So she answered that she was much obliged to him, but would not trouble him. ‘I have said that I will wait for ‘em, and they will expect me to now.’
苔丝虽然受宠若惊，但始终没有完全克服她最初对他的不信任，尽管他们迟到了，她还是更愿意和工人一起步行回家。于是她回答说她很感激他，但不会麻烦他。 “我说过我会等他们，他们现在也会等我。”

‘Very well, Miss Independence. Please yourself... Then I shall not hurry... My good Lord, what a kick-up they are having there!’
“很好，独立小姐。请你自己……那我就不着急了……天哪，他们在那里玩得多么开心啊！

He had not put himself forward into the light, but some of them had perceived him, and his presence led to a slight pause and a consideration of how the time was flying. As soon as he had re-lit a cigar and walked away the Trantridge people began to collect themselves from amid those who had come in from other farms, and prepared to leave in a body. Their bundles and baskets were gathered up, and half an hour later, when the clock-chime sounded a quarter past eleven, they were straggling along the lane which led up the hill towards their homes.
他没有把自己暴露在光亮中，但他们中的一些人已经察觉到了他，他的出现让他们稍微停顿了一下，思考时间过得如何。他一重新点燃雪茄，走开，特兰特里奇人就开始从其他农场进来的人中聚集起来，准备集体离开。他们的包裹和篮子都被收拾起来，半小时后，当钟声敲响十一点一刻时，他们正沿着通向山上家的小路散漫。

It was a three-mile walk, along a dry white road, made whiter to-night by the light of the moon.
这是一条三英里的步行路程，沿着一条干燥的白色道路，今晚的月光使道路显得更加洁白。

Tess soon perceived as she walked in the flock, sometimes with this one, sometimes with that, that the fresh night air was producing staggerings and serpentine courses among the men who had partaken too freely; some of the more careless women also were wandering in their gait—to wit, a dark virago, Car Darch, dubbed Queen of Spades, till lately a favourite of d’Urberville’s; Nancy, her sister, nicknamed the Queen of Diamonds; and the young married woman who had already tumbled down. Yet however terrestrial and lumpy their appearance just now to the mean unglamoured eye, to themselves the case was different. They followed the road with a sensation that they were soaring along in a supporting medium, possessed of original and profound thoughts, themselves and surrounding nature forming an organism of which all the parts harmoniously and joyously interpenetrated each other. They were as sublime as the moon and stars above them, and the moon and stars were as ardent as they.
苔丝很快就发现，当她在羊群中行走时，有时与这个，有时与那个，新鲜的夜晚空气在那些过于自由地参与的人们中产生了令人震惊和蜿蜒的路线；一些比较粗心的女人也在步态上徘徊——也就是说，一个深色的泼妇卡·达奇（Car Darch），被称为黑桃皇后，直到最近才成为德伯维尔的最爱。她的妹妹南希（Nancy），绰号“钻石女王”；还有那个已经摔倒的少妇。然而，无论他们现在的外表在平淡无奇的人看来多么平凡和凹凸不平，但对他们自己来说，情况却有所不同。他们沿着这条路走，感觉自己在一个支撑媒介中翱翔，拥有原创而深刻的思想，他们自己和周围的自然形成一个有机体，其中所有部分和谐而愉快地相互渗透。他们如同头顶上的月亮和星星一样崇高，而月亮和星星也和他们一样炽热。

Tess, however, had undergone such painful experiences of this kind in her father’s house that the discovery of their condition spoilt the pleasure she was beginning to feel in the moonlight journey. Yet she stuck to the party, for reasons above given.
然而，苔丝在她父亲的家里经历了如此痛苦的经历，以至于他们的状况的发现破坏了她在月光之旅中开始感受到的快乐。但由于上述原因，她仍然坚持参加该党。

In the open highway they had progressed in scattered order; but now their route was through a field-gate, and the foremost finding a difficulty in opening it, they closed up together.
在开阔的公路上，他们散乱地行进。但现在他们的路线是穿过一个田门，最重要的是发现很难打开它，所以他们一起关闭了。

This leading pedestrian was Car the Queen of Spades, who carried a wicker-basket containing her mother’s groceries, her own draperies, and other purchases for the week. The basket being large and heavy, Car had placed it for convenience of porterage on the top of her head, where it rode on in jeopardized balance as she walked with arms akimbo.
领头的行人是黑桃皇后卡，她提着一个柳条篮，里面装着她母亲的杂货、她自己的窗帘以及本周需要购买的其他物品。篮子又大又重，为了方便搬运，卡把它放在了她的头顶上，当她叉腰走路时，篮子在危险的平衡中行驶。

‘Well—whatever is that a-creeping down thy back, Car Darch?’ said one of the group suddenly.
“好吧——到底是什么东西从你的背上爬下来，卡·达奇？”其中一个人突然说道。

All looked at Car. Her gown was a light cotton print, and from the back of her head a kind of rope could be seen descending to some distance below her waist, like a Chinaman’s queue.
所有人都看着车。她的长袍是浅色棉质印花的，从她的后脑勺可以看到一条绳子垂到腰部以下一段距离，就像中国人的辫子一样。

‘‘Tis her hair falling down,’ said another.
“她的头发掉下来了，”另一个人说。

No; it was not her hair: it was a black stream of something oozing from her basket, and it glistened like a slimy snake in the cold still rays of the moon.
不;那不是她的头发：那是一股黑色的东西从她的篮子里渗出来，在冰冷的月光下闪闪发光，像一条粘糊糊的蛇。

‘‘Tis treacle,’ said an observant matron.
“这是糖浆，”一位细心的护士长说道。

Treacle it was. Car’s poor old grandmother had a weakness for the sweet stuff. Honey she had in plenty out of her own hives, but treacle was what her soul desired, and Car had been about to give her a treat of surprise. Hastily lowering the basket the dark girl found that the vessel containing the syrup had been smashed within.
原来是糖浆。汽车可怜的老祖母很喜欢吃甜食。她从自己的蜂巢里得到了很多蜂蜜，但糖浆才是她灵魂所渴望的，而卡正准备给她一份惊喜。黑衣少女急忙放下篮子，发现里面装有糖浆的容器已经被砸碎了。

By this time there had arisen a shout of laughter at the extraordinary appearance of Car’s back, which irritated the dark queen into getting rid of the disfigurement by the first sudden means available, and independently of the help of the scoffers. She rushed excitedly into the field they were about to cross, and flinging herself flat on her back upon the grass, began to wipe her gown as well as she could by spinning horizontally on the herbage and dragging herself over it upon her elbows.
这时，汽车背部异常的样子引起了一阵大笑，这激怒了黑暗女王，她用第一个可用的突然手段摆脱了毁容，而无需嘲笑者的帮助。她兴奋地冲进他们即将穿过的田野，仰面朝草地上一扑，开始在草丛上水平旋转并用肘部拖着自己的身体，尽可能地擦拭她的长袍。

The laughter rang louder; they clung to the gate, to the posts, rested on their staves, in the weakness engendered by their convulsions at the spectacle of Car. Our heroine, who had hitherto held her peace, at this wild moment could not help joining in with the rest.
笑声更大声了；他们在看到卡尔的景象后全身抽搐，浑身无力，紧抓着大门、柱子，靠在木棍上。我们的女主人公，一直保持沉默，在这个疯狂的时刻，忍不住加入了其他人的行列。

It was a misfortune—in more ways than one. No sooner did the dark queen hear the soberer richer note of Tess among those of the other work-people than a long-smouldering sense of rivalry inflamed her to madness. She sprang to her feet and closely faced the object of her dislike.
这在很多方面都是一种不幸。黑暗女王一听到苔丝在其他工人中发出的更冷静、更丰富的声音，一种长期压抑的竞争感就让她发疯了。她跳了起来，紧紧地面对着她不喜欢的对象。

‘How darest th’ laugh at me, hussy!’ she cried.
“你怎么敢嘲笑我，你这个女人！”她叫道。

‘I couldn’t really help it when t’others did,’ apologized Tess, still tittering.
“当其他人这么做的时候，我实在是没办法。”苔丝抱歉地说道，仍然在窃笑。

‘Ah, th’st think th’ beest everybody, dostn’t, because th’ beest first favourite with He just now! But stop a bit, my lady, stop a bit! I’m as good as two of such! Look here—here’s at ‘ee!’
“啊，大家都认为这是最好的，不是吗，因为刚才他是第一热门！”但是停下来一点，我的女士，停下来一点！我和两个这样的人一样好！看这里——这里是“ee！”

To Tess’s horror the dark queen began stripping off the bodice of her gown—which for the added reason of its ridiculed condition she was only too glad to be free of—till she had bared her plump neck, shoulders, and arms to the moonshine, under which they looked as luminous and beautiful as some Praxitelean creation, in their possession of the faultless rotundities of a lusty country-girl. She closed her fists and squared up at Tess.
令苔丝惊恐的是，黑暗女王开始脱掉她礼服的紧身胸衣——再加上礼服的状况令人嘲笑，她很高兴能摆脱它——直到她把丰满的脖子、肩膀和手臂暴露在月光下，在此之下，她们看起来就像普拉克西特勒斯的某些创造物一样明亮而美丽，拥有一个精力充沛的乡村女孩的完美圆润。她握紧拳头，对着苔丝摆好姿势。

‘Indeed, then, I shall not fight!’ said the latter majestically; ‘and if I had know you was of that sort, I wouldn’t have so let myself down as to come with such a whorage as this is!’
“那么，我确实不会战斗！”后者威严地说。 “如果我知道你是这样的人，我就不会这么让自己失望，带着这样的胡言乱语而来！”

The rather too inclusive speech brought down a torrent of vituperation from other quarters upon fair Tess’s unlucky head, particularly from the Queen of Diamonds, who having stood in the relations to d’Urberville that Car had also been suspected of, united with the latter against the common enemy. Several other women also chimed in, with an animus which none of them would have been so fatuous as to show but for the rollicking evening they had passed. Thereupon, finding Tess unfairly browbeaten, the husbands and lovers tried to make peace by defending her; but the result of that attempt was directly to increase the war.
这段相当包罗万象的讲话，招致了来自其他方面的猛烈的谩骂，尤其是来自钻石女王的谩骂，她与卡也曾被怀疑的德伯维尔关系密切，与后者联合起来反对德伯维尔。共同的敌人。其他几个女人也附和道，她们都怀着敌意，要不是度过了那个热闹的夜晚，她们都不会愚蠢地表现出这种敌意。于是，丈夫和情人发现苔丝受到不公正的威吓，试图通过保护她来求和。但这种企图的结果是直接加剧了战争。

Tess was indignant and ashamed. She no longer minded the loneliness of the way and the lateness of the hour; her one object was to get away from the whole crew as soon as possible. She knew well enough that the better among them would repent of their passion next day. They were all now inside the field, and she was edging back to rush off alone when a horseman emerged almost silently from the corner of the hedge that screened the road, and Alec d’Urberville looked round upon them.
苔丝既愤怒又羞愧。她不再介意路上的孤独和时间的迟早；她的唯一目标就是尽快离开全体船员。她很清楚，他们中的佼佼者第二天就会后悔自己的激情。他们现在都在田野里了，她正慢慢地向后退去，准备独自冲出去，这时一个骑兵几乎无声无息地从挡住道路的树篱一角出现，亚历克·德伯维尔环顾四周看着他们。

‘What the devil is all this row about, work-folk?’ he asked.
“工人们，这一切到底是为了什么？”他问道。

The explanation was not readily forthcoming; and, in truth, he did not require any. Having heard their voices while yet some way off he had ridden creepingly forward, and learnt enough to satisfy himself.
解释并没有立即得到。事实上，他不需要任何东西。距离他们还有一段距离时，他听到了他们的声音，便缓慢地前行，学到了足够多的知识，足以让自己满意。

Tess was standing apart from the rest, near the gate. He bent over towards her. ‘Jump up behind me,’ he whispered, ‘and we’ll get shot of the screaming cats in a jiffy!’
苔丝站在大门附近，远离其他人。他向她弯下腰。 “跳到我身后，”他低声说道，“我们很快就能击中尖叫的猫！”

She felt almost ready to faint, so vivid was her sense of the crisis. At almost any other moment of her life she would have refused such proffered aid and company, as she had refused them several times before; and now the loneliness would not of itself have forced her to do otherwise. But coming as the invitation did at the particular juncture when fear and indignation at these adversaries could be transformed by a spring of the foot into a triumph over them, she abandoned herself to her impulse, climbed the gate, put her toe upon his instep, and scrambled into the saddle behind him. The pair were speeding away into the distant gray by the time that the contentious revellers became aware of what had happened.
她感觉自己快要晕倒了，危机感是如此强烈。几乎在她生命中的任何其他时刻，她都会拒绝这种提供的帮助和陪伴，就像她以前多次拒绝过的那样；现在，孤独本身并不会迫使她做出其他的事。但正如邀请函所发出的邀请，正值对这些对手的恐惧和愤慨可以通过脚的一跳转化为对他们的胜利的特殊时刻，她屈服于自己的冲动，爬上大门，把脚趾放在他的脚背上，然后爬上他身后的马鞍。当有争议的狂欢者意识到发生了什么事时，两人正加速驶入遥远的灰色地带。

The Queen of Spades forgot the stain on her bodice, and stood beside the Queen of Diamonds and the new-married, staggering young woman—all with a gaze of fixity in the direction in which the horse’s tramp was diminishing into silence on the road.
黑桃皇后忘记了她紧身胸衣上的污点，站在方块皇后和新婚的、摇摇晃晃的年轻女子旁边——所有人都目不转睛地看着马蹄声在路上逐渐减弱的方向。

‘What be ye looking at?’ asked a man who had not observed the incident.
“你在看什么？”一个没有目睹这一事件的人问道。

‘Ho-ho-ho!’ laughed dark Car.
“嗬——嗬——嗬！”黑车笑道。

‘Hee-hee-hee!’ laughed the tippling bride, as she steadied herself on the arm of her fond husband.
“嘻嘻嘻！”喝得醉醺醺的新娘在她深爱的丈夫的手臂上站稳了身子，笑着说道。

‘Heu-heu-heu!’ laughed dark Car’s mother, stroking her moustache as she explained laconically: ‘Out of the frying-pan into the fire!’
“嘿嘿嘿！”黑卡的母亲一边笑着一边抚摸着自己的小胡子，简洁地解释道：“从煎锅到火里！”

Then these children of the open air, whom even excess of alcohol could scarce injure permanently, betook themselves to the field-path; and as they went there moved onward with them, around the shadow of each one’s head, a circle of opalized light, formed by the moon’s rays upon the glistening sheet of dew. Each pedestrian could see no halo but his or her own, which never deserted the head-shadow, whatever its vulgar unsteadiness might be; but adhered to it, and persistently beautified it; till the erratic motions seemed an inherent part of the irradiation, and the fumes of their breathing a component of the night’s mist; and the spirit of the scene, and of the moonlight, and of Nature, seemed harmoniously to mingle with the spirit of wine.
然后，这些露天的孩子们，即使过量的酒精也很难对他们造成永久伤害，他们走上田野小路。当他们走到那里时，他们一起向前移动，在每个人头顶的阴影周围，有一圈乳白色的光，是月光照射在闪闪发光的露珠上形成的。每个行人都看不到除了他或她自己的光环之外的任何光环，它永远不会抛弃头影，无论它的粗俗不稳定如何；却坚守它，坚持不懈地美化它；直到不稳定的运动似乎成为辐射的固有部分，而他们呼吸的烟雾成为夜雾的一部分；场景的精神、月光的精神和自然的精神似乎与酒的精神和谐地融为一体。

XI

The twain cantered along for some time without speech, Tess as she clung to him still panting in her triumph, yet in other respects dubious. She had perceived that the horse was not the spirited one he sometimes rose, and felt no alarm on that score, though her seat was precarious enough despite her tight hold of him. She begged him to slow the animal to a walk, which Alec accordingly did.
两人慢吞吞地走了一段时间，一言不发，苔丝紧紧抱住他，仍然因胜利而气喘吁吁，但在其他方面却有些可疑。她察觉到这匹马并不是他有时所起的那匹活泼的马，因此并没有感到惊慌，尽管尽管她紧紧地抱住了他，但她的座位还是很不稳定。她恳求他放慢动物的速度，亚历克照做了。

‘Neatly done, was it not, dear Tess?’ he said by and by.
“干得漂亮，不是吗，亲爱的苔丝？”他渐渐说道。

‘Yes!’ said she. ‘I am sure I ought to be much obliged to you.’
“是的！”她说。 “我确信我应该非常感谢你。”

‘And are you?’
“你是吗？”

She did not reply.
她没有回答。

‘Tess, why do you always dislike my kissing you?’
“苔丝，你为什么总是不喜欢我吻你？”

‘I suppose—because I don’t love you.’
“我想——因为我不爱你。”

‘You are quite sure?’
“你确定吗？”

‘I am angry with you sometimes!’
“有时我很生你的气！”

‘Ah, I half feared as much.’ Nevertheless, Alec did not object to that confession. He knew that anything was better then frigidity. ‘Why haven’t you told me when I have made you angry?’
“啊，我也有一半担心。”不过，亚历克并不反对这种坦白。他知道什么都比性冷淡更好。 “我惹你生气了，你为什么不告诉我？”

‘You know very well why. Because I cannot help myself here.’
‘你很清楚为什么。因为我在这里无法自拔。

‘I haven’t offended you often by love-making?’
“我没有经常做爱得罪你吗？”

‘You have sometimes.’
“有时候你会这样。”

‘How many times?’
'多少次？'

‘You know as well as I—too many times.’
“你和我一样清楚——太多次了。”

‘Every time I have tried?’
“每次我都尝试过？”

She was silent, and the horse ambled along for a considerable distance, till a faint luminous fog, which had hung in the hollows all the evening, became general and enveloped them. It seemed to hold the moonlight in suspension, rendering it more pervasive than in clear air. Whether on this account, or from absent-mindedness, or from sleepiness, she did not perceive that they had long ago passed the point at which the lane to Trantridge branched from the highway, and that her conductor had not taken the Trantridge track.
她一声不吭，马儿缓步走了很长一段距离，直到一整晚都笼罩在山谷中的微弱发光雾变得普遍起来，笼罩了他们。它似乎让月光悬浮起来，使它比晴朗的空气中更普遍。不知是因为这个原因，还是因为心不在焉，或者是因为困倦，她没有意识到他们早已过了通往特兰特里奇的车道从高速公路的分支点，而她的售票员也没有走上特兰特里奇的轨道。

She was inexpressibly weary. She had risen at five o’clock every morning of that week, had been on foot the whole of each day, and on this evening had in addition walked the three miles to Chaseborough, waited three hours for her neighbours without eating or drinking, her impatience to start them preventing either; she had then walked a mile of the way home, and had undergone the excitement of the quarrel, till, with the slow progress of their steed, it was now nearly one o’clock. Only once, however, was she overcome by actual drowsiness. In that moment of oblivion her head sank gently against him.
她有说不出的疲倦。那一周，她每天早上五点钟就起床，每天都步行，而且当天晚上还步行了三英里去蔡斯伯勒，不吃不喝地等了三个小时，等了邻居。不耐烦地开始阻止其中任何一个；然后她走了一英里回家，经历了争吵的兴奋，直到随着他们的马慢慢前行，现在已经快一点了。然而，只有一次她真正感到困倦。在那一瞬间的遗忘中，她的头轻轻地靠在了他身上。

D’Urberville stopped the horse, withdrew his feet from the stirrups, turned sideways on the saddle, and enclosed her waist with his arm to support her.
德伯维尔停下马，将脚从马镫上退开，在马鞍上侧身，用手臂环住她的腰，支撑着她。

This immediately put her on the defensive, and with one of those sudden impulses of reprisal to which she was liable she gave him a little push from her. In his ticklish position he nearly lost his balance and only just avoided rolling over into the road, the horse, though a powerful one, being fortunately the quietest he rode.
这立刻让她处于防御状态，她突然有一种报复的冲动，她把他推开了。在这个令人发痒的姿势中，他几乎失去了平衡，只是避免了滚到路上，这匹马虽然是一匹强大的马，但幸运的是他骑的最安静。

‘That is devilish unkind!’ he said. ‘I mean no harm—only to keep you from falling.’
“这太不友善了！”他说。 “我无意伤害——只是为了防止你跌倒。”

She pondered suspiciously, till, thinking that this might after all be true, she relented, and said quite humbly, ‘I beg your pardon, sir.’
她疑惑地想了想，直到想到这可能是真的，她才松了口气，谦虚地说：“请原谅，先生。”

‘I won’t pardon you unless you show some confidence in me. Good God!’ he burst out, ‘what am I, to be repulsed so by a mere chit like you? For near three mortal months have you trifled with my feelings, eluded me, and snubbed me; and I won’t stand it!’
“除非你对我表现出一些信心，否则我不会原谅你。天啊！”他大声说道，“我算什么，竟然会被你这样的小东西如此排斥？近三个月来，你一直在玩弄我的感情，躲避我，冷落我；我受不了！

‘I’ll leave you to-morrow, sir.’
“我明天就离开你，先生。”

‘No, you will not leave me to-morrow! Will you, I ask once more, show your belief in me by letting me clasp you with my arm? Come, between us two and nobody else, now. We know each other well; and you know that I love you, and think you the prettiest girl in the world, which you are. Mayn’t I treat you as a lover?’
“不，明天你不会离开我！”我再次问你，你愿意让我用手臂拥抱你，以表明你对我的信任吗？来吧，现在就我们两个人之间，没有其他人。我们彼此很了解；你知道我爱你，并认为你是世界上最漂亮的女孩，事实也确实如此。难道我不能把你当情人吗？

She drew a quick pettish breath of objection, writhing uneasily on her seat, looked far ahead, and murmured, ‘I don’t know—I wish—how can I say yes or no when—‘
她轻快地吸了一口气，表示反对，在座位上不安地扭动着，看着前方，低声说道：“我不知道——我希望——我怎么能说是或不，当——”

He settled the matter by clasping his arm round her as he desired, and Tess expressed no further negative. Thus they sidled slowly onward till it struck her they had been advancing for an unconscionable time—far longer than was usually occupied by the short journey from Chaseborough, even at this walking pace, and that they were no longer on hard road, but in a mere trackway.
他按照自己的意愿用手臂搂住了她，解决了这件事，苔丝也没有再表示消极。就这样，他们慢慢地侧着身子向前走，直到她突然意识到，他们已经前进了一段不合情理的时间——比通常从蔡斯伯勒出发的短途路程所花费的时间要长得多，即使是以这种步行速度，而且他们不再走在艰难的道路上，而是在一个艰难的道路上。只是轨道。

‘Why, where be we?’ she exclaimed.
“为什么，我们在哪儿？”她惊呼道。

‘Passing by a wood.’
“经过一片树林。”

‘A wood—what wood? Surely we are quite out of the road?’
‘一块木头——什么木头？我们肯定已经远离道路了吧？

‘A bit of The Chase—the oldest wood in England. It is a lovely night, and why should we not prolong our ride a little?’
“Chase 的一点点——英格兰最古老的树林。”这是一个美好的夜晚，为什么我们不应该延长我们的旅程呢？

‘How could you be so treacherous!’ said Tess, between archness and real dismay, and getting rid of his arm by pulling open his fingers one by one, though at the risk of slipping off herself. ‘Just when I’ve been putting such trust in you, and obliging you to please you, because I thought I had wronged you by that push! Please set me down, and let me walk home.’
“你怎么能这么奸诈！”苔丝在顽皮和真正的沮丧之间说道，她一根一根地拉开他的手指，摆脱了他的手臂，尽管冒着滑倒的危险。 ‘就在我如此信任你，并强迫你取悦你的时候，因为我认为我的推动冤枉了你！请把我放下，让我走回家。”

‘You cannot walk home, darling, even if the air were clear. We are miles away from Trantridge, if I must tell you, and in this growing fog you might wander for hours among these trees.’
“亲爱的，即使空气晴朗，你也无法步行回家。如果我必须告诉你的话，我们距离特兰特里奇有几英里远，在这越来越大的雾气中，你可能会在这些树林中徘徊几个小时。

‘Never mind that,’ she coaxed. ‘Put me down, I beg you. I don’t mind where it is; only let me get down, sir, please!’
“别介意，”她哄道。 ‘放我下来，我求你了。我不介意它在哪里；请让我下来，先生！”

‘Very well, then, I will—on one condition. Having brought you here to this out-of-the-way place, I feel myself responsible for your safe-conduct home, whatever you may yourself feel about it. As to your getting to Trantridge without assistance, it is quite impossible; for, to tell the truth, dear, owing to this fog, which so disguises everything, I don’t quite know where we are myself. Now, if you will promise to wait beside the horse while I walk through the bushes till I come to some road or house, and ascertain exactly our whereabouts, I’ll deposit you here willingly. When I come back I’ll give you full directions, and if you insist upon walking you may; or you may ride—at your pleasure.’
“那好吧，我愿意——但有一个条件。”把你带到这个偏僻的地方后，我觉得自己对你的家的安全负责，无论你自己对此有何感受。至于你在没有帮助的情况下到达特兰特里奇，那是完全不可能的。因为，说实话，亲爱的，由于这片大雾，它掩盖了一切，我自己也不太知道我们在哪里。现在，如果你答应在我穿过灌木丛时在马旁边等着，直到我到达某条路或某所房子，并确定我们的确切位置，我很乐意将你安置在这里。当我回来时，我会给你完整的指示，如果你坚持步行，你可以；或者你也可以骑——随你的意。

She accepted these terms, and slid off on the near side, though not till he had stolen a cursory kiss. He sprang down on the other side.
她接受了这些条件，然后滑到了近侧，尽管直到他偷偷地吻了一下。他从另一边跳了下来。

‘I suppose I must hold the horse?’ said she.
“我想我必须牵着马？”她说。

‘Oh no; it’s not necessary,’ replied Alec, patting the panting creature. ‘He’s had enough of it for to-night.’
'不好了; “没必要。”亚历克回答道，拍拍这个气喘吁吁的生物。 “今晚他已经受够了。”

He turned the horse’s head into the bushes, hitched him on to a bough, and made a sort of couch or nest for her in the deep mass of dead leaves.
他把马头埋进灌木丛，把它拴在一根树枝上，然后在深深的枯叶中为她搭了一个沙发或巢。

‘Now, you sit there,’ he said. ‘The leaves have not got damp as yet. Just give an eye to the horse—it will be quite sufficient.’
“现在，你坐在那里，”他说。 ‘叶子还没有湿。只要照看一下马就足够了。”

He took a few steps away from her, but, returning, said, ‘By the bye, Tess, your father has a new cob to-day. Somebody gave it to him.’
他离开她几步，但又回来了，说道：“再见，苔丝，你父亲今天有了一只新的玉米棒子。”有人给了他。

‘Somebody? You!’
‘有人吗？你！'

D’Urberville nodded.
德伯维尔点点头。

‘O how very good of you that is!’ she exclaimed, with a painful sense of the awkwardness of having to thank him just then.
“哦，你真是太好了！”她大声说道，因为此时不得不感谢他，她感到一种痛苦的尴尬。

‘And the children have some toys.’
“孩子们有一些玩具。”

‘I didn’t know—you ever sent them anything!’ she murmured, much moved. ‘I almost wish you had not—yes, I almost wish it!’
“我不知道——你给他们寄过任何东西！”她低声说道，非常感动。 “我几乎希望你没有——是的，我几乎希望它！”

‘Why, dear?’
“为什么，亲爱的？”

‘It—hampers me so.’
“它——太妨碍我了。”

‘Tessy—don’t you love me ever so little now?’
“泰西——你现在不爱我了吗？”

‘I’m grateful,’ she reluctantly admitted. ‘But I fear I do not—‘ The sudden vision of his passion for herself as a factor in this result so distressed her that, beginning with one slow tear, and then following with another, she wept outright.
“我很感激，”她不情愿地承认。 “但我担心我不——”突然想到他对自己的热情是造成这一结果的一个因素，这让她非常痛苦，她先是缓缓流下一滴眼泪，然后又流下另一滴眼泪，哭得彻底。

‘Don’t cry, dear, dear one! Now sit down here, and wait till I come.’ She passively sat down amid the leaves he had heaped, and shivered slightly. ‘Are you cold?’ he asked.
‘别哭，亲爱的，亲爱的！你先坐在这里，等我来。”她被动地坐在他堆起的树叶中间，微微颤抖着。 “你冷吗？”他问。

‘Not very—a little.’
“不太——有一点。”

He touched her with his fingers, which sank into her as into down. ‘You have only that puffy muslin dress on—how’s that?’
他用手指触碰她，手指深深地陷进她的身体里。 “你只穿着那件蓬松的平纹细布连衣裙——怎么样？”

‘It’s my best summer one. ‘Twas very warm when I started, and I didn’t know I was going to ride, and that it would be night.’
“这是我最好的夏天。 “我开始骑行时天气非常暖和，我不知道我要骑行，而且那会是晚上。”

‘Nights grow chilly in September. Let me see.’ He pulled off a light overcoat that he had worn, and put it round her tenderly. ‘That’s it—now you’ll feel warmer,’ he continued. ‘Now, my pretty, rest there; I shall soon be back again.’
“九月的夜晚变得寒冷。让我看看。”他脱下身上的一件薄外套，温柔地给她披上。 “就是这样——现在你会感觉更温暖了，”他继续说道。 “现在，我的美人，就在那儿休息吧；我很快就会回来。

Having buttoned the overcoat round her shoulders he plunged into the webs of vapour which by this time formed veils between the trees. She could hear the rustling of the branches as he ascended the adjoining slope, till his movements were no louder than the hopping of a bird, and finally died away. With the setting of the moon the pale light lessened, and Tess became invisible as she fell into reverie upon the leaves where he had left her.
他把大衣的扣子扣在她的肩上，一头扎进了蒸汽网中，此时蒸汽网在树林之间形成了面纱。当他爬上毗邻的斜坡时，她能听到树枝的沙沙声，直到他的动作不比鸟儿的跳跃声大，最后才消失。随着月色的落下，苍白的光芒减弱了，苔丝变得看不见了，她在他离开的树叶上陷入沉思。

In the meantime Alec d’Urberville had pushed on up the slope to clear his genuine doubt as to the quarter of The Chase they were in. He had, in fact, ridden quite at random for over an hour, taking any turning that came to hand in order to prolong companionship with her, and giving far more attention to Tess’s moonlit person than to any wayside object. A little rest for the jaded animal being desirable, he did not hasten his search for landmarks. A clamber over the hill into the adjoining vale brought him to the fence of a highway whose contours he recognized, which settled the question of their whereabouts. D’Urberville thereupon turned back; but by this time the moon had quite gone down, and partly on account of the fog The Chase was wrapped in thick darkness, although morning was not far off. He was obliged to advance with outstretched hands to avoid contact with the boughs, and discovered that to hit the exact spot from which he had started was at first entirely beyond him. Roaming up and down, round and round, he at length heard a slight movement of the horse close at hand; and the sleeve of his overcoat unexpectedly caught his foot.
与此同时，亚历克·德伯维尔已经推上了斜坡，以消除他对他们所在的追逐区的真正怀疑。事实上，他已经相当随意地骑了一个多小时，采取任何转弯。为了延长与苔丝的陪伴，她对月光下的人给予了更多的关注，而不是任何路边的物体。对于这头疲惫不堪的动物来说，稍微休息一下是可取的，他没有加快寻找地标的速度。翻过山丘进入毗邻的山谷，他来到了一条高速公路的围栏处，他认出了高速公路的轮廓，这解决了他们的下落问题。德伯维尔随即回头。但此时月亮已经完全落下去了，部分原因是大雾，虽然离黎明已经不远了，但蔡斯周围笼罩在浓浓的黑暗之中。他不得不伸出双手前进，以避免与树枝接触，并发现一开始他完全无法到达他出发的确切位置。他上上下下地走来走去，一圈又一圈，终于听到近旁的马匹轻微的动静。没想到大衣的袖子绊住了他的脚。

‘Tess!’ said d’Urberville.
“苔丝！”德伯维尔说。

There was no answer. The obscurity was now so great that he could see absolutely nothing but a pale nebulousness at his feet, which represented the white muslin figure he had left upon the dead leaves. Everything else was blackness alike. D’Urberville stooped; and heard a gentle regular breathing. He knelt and bent lower, till her breath warmed his face, and in a moment his cheek was in contact with hers. She was sleeping soundly, and upon her eyelashes there lingered tears.
没有人回答。现在天色变得如此昏暗，他除了脚下一片苍白的云雾之外什么也看不见，这代表了他留在枯叶上的白色平纹细布身影。其他一切都一样漆黑一片。德伯维尔弯下腰；并听到轻柔规律的呼吸声。他跪下来，弯下腰，直到她的呼吸温暖了他的脸，刹那间，他的脸颊就贴到了她的脸颊上。她睡得很熟，睫毛上还挂着泪水。

Darkness and silence ruled everywhere around. Above them rose the primeval yews and oaks of The Chase, in which there poised gentle roosting birds in their last nap; and about them stole the hopping rabbits and hares. But, might some say, where was Tess’s guardian angel? where was the providence of her simple faith? Perhaps, like that other god of whom the ironical Tishbite spoke, he was talking, or he was pursuing, or he was in a journey, or he was sleeping and not to be awaked.
黑暗和寂静笼罩着周围的一切。在它们上方，矗立着蔡斯的原始紫杉和橡树，里面栖息着温柔的鸟儿，正在进行最后的小憩。他们周围偷走了跳跃的兔子和野兔。但是，也许有人会说，苔丝的守护天使在哪里？她单纯的信仰的天意在哪里？也许，就像讽刺的提斯比特人所说的另一个神一样，他正在说话，或者他正在追求，或者他正在旅途，或者他正在睡觉而不是被唤醒。

Why it was that upon this beautiful feminine tissue, sensitive as gossamer, and practically blank as snow as yet, there should have been traced such a coarse pattern as it was doomed to receive; why so often the coarse appropriates the finer thus, the wrong man the woman, the wrong woman the man, many thousand years of analytical philosophy have failed to explain to our sense of order. One may, indeed, admit the possibility of a retribution lurking in the present catastrophe. Doubtless some of Tess d’Urberville’s mailed ancestors rollicking home from a fray had dealt the same measure even more ruthlessly towards peasant girls of their time. But though to visit the sins of the fathers upon the children may be a morality good enough for divinities, it is scorned by average human nature; and it therefore does not mend the matter.
为什么在这片美丽的女性组织上，敏感如游丝，几乎空白如雪，应该被描绘出如此粗糙的图案，因为它注定要接受；为什么呢？为什么如此频繁地以粗取精，男人错了女人，女人错了男人，数千年的分析哲学未能向我们的秩序感解释。事实上，人们可能承认当前的灾难中潜藏着报复的可能性。毫无疑问，苔丝·德伯维尔的一些被邮寄的祖先在打架后欢快地回家时，对他们那个时代的农家女孩也采取了同样的措施，甚至更加残酷。尽管将父亲的罪过归咎于孩子对于神来说可能是一种足够好的道德，但它却被普通人的本性所蔑视。因此它并不能解决问题。

As Tess’s own people down in those retreats are never tired of saying among each other in their fatalistic way: ‘It was to be.’ There lay the pity of it. An immeasurable social chasm was to divide our heroine’s personality thereafter from that previous self of hers who stepped from her mother’s door to try her fortune at Trantridge poultry-farm.
正如苔丝自己的人在那些隐居处一样，从不厌倦地用宿命论的方式彼此说：“本来就是这样。”这就是遗憾。此后，我们女主人公的性格与她走出母亲家门，到特兰特里奇家禽养殖场碰碰运气的那个自己之间存在着不可估量的社会鸿沟。

END OF PHASE THE FIRST
第一阶段结束

Phase the Second: Maiden No More
第二阶段：少女不再

XII
十二

The basket was heavy and the bundle was large, but she lugged them along like a person who did not find her especial burden in material things. Occasionally she stopped to rest in a mechanical way by some gate or post; and then, giving the baggage another hitch upon her full round arm, went steadily on again.
篮子很重，包裹也很大，但她拖着它们走，就像一个不觉得物质上有什么特别负担的人一样。偶尔她会机械地在某个门或柱子旁停下来休息。然后，她又把行李套在她那圆圆的手臂上，继续稳步前行。

It was a Sunday morning in late October, about four months after Tess Durbeyfield’s arrival at Trantridge, and some few weeks subsequent to the night ride in The Chase. The time was not long past daybreak, and the yellow luminosity upon the horizon behind her back lighted the ridge towards which her face was set—the barrier of the vale wherein she had of late been a stranger—which she would have to climb over to reach her birthplace. The ascent was gradual on this side, and the soil and scenery differed much from those within Blakemore Vale. Even the character and accent of the two peoples had shades of difference, despite the amalgamating effects of a roundabout railway; so that, though less than twenty miles from the place of her sojourn at Trantridge, her native village had seemed a far-away spot. The field-folk shut in there traded northward and westward, travelled, courted, and married northward and westward, thought northward and westward; those on this side mainly directed their energies and attention to the east and south.
那是十月下旬的一个周日早晨，距离苔丝·德北菲尔德抵达特兰特里奇大约四个月，也是在蔡斯夜骑之后的几个星期。时间刚过黎明不久，她身后地平线上的黄色光亮照亮了她脸所朝向的山脊——她最近对那里陌生的山谷的屏障——她必须爬过去才能到达。到达她的出生地。这边的上升是平缓的，土壤和风景与布莱克莫尔谷内的有很大不同。尽管有环岛铁路的融合作用，但两国人民的性格和口音也存在细微差别。因此，尽管距离她在特兰特里奇的逗留地不到二十英里，她的家乡却显得很遥远。关在那里的田野居民向北方和西方进行贸易、旅行、求爱、结婚，向北方和西方思考；这边的人主要把精力和注意力集中在东部和南部。

The incline was the same down which d’Urberville had driven her so wildly on that day in June. Tess went up the remainder of its length without stopping, and on reaching the edge of the escarpment gazed over the familiar green world beyond, now half-veiled in mist. It was always beautiful from here; it was terribly beautiful to Tess to-day, for since her eyes last fell upon it she had learnt that the serpent hisses where the sweet birds sing, and her views of life had been totally changed for her by the lesson. Verily another girl than the simple one she had been at home was she who, bowed by thought, stood still here, and turned to look behind her. She could not bear to look forward into the Vale.
六月的那一天，德伯维尔疯狂地驱赶她下坡，坡度与她所走的坡度是一样的。苔丝没有停下来，继续走完剩下的路程，到达悬崖边缘时，她凝视着远处熟悉的绿色世界，现在，世界已半笼罩在薄雾中。从这里看去总是很美丽；今天对苔丝来说真是太美了，因为自从她最后一次看到它之后，她就知道蛇在甜美的鸟儿歌唱时发出嘶嘶声，她对生活的看法也因这堂课而完全改变了。与在家中那个单纯的女孩相比，她确实是另一个女孩，她因思想而低头，一动不动地站在这里，转身向后看。她无法忍受展望山谷。

Ascending by the long white road that Tess herself had just laboured up, she saw a two-wheeled vehicle, beside which walked a man, who held up his hand to attract her attention.
沿着苔丝自己刚刚辛苦走完的那条白色的长路往上走，她看到一辆两轮车，旁边走着一个男人，他举起手来吸引她的注意。

She obeyed the signal to wait for him with unspeculative repose, and in a few minutes man and horse stopped beside her.
她听从了信号，平静地等待他，几分钟后，人和马就停在了她身边。

‘Why did you slip away by stealth like this?’ said d’Urberville, with upbraiding breathlessness; ‘on a Sunday morning, too, when people were all in bed! I only discovered it by accident, and I have been driving like the deuce to overtake you. Just look at the mare. Why go off like this? You know that nobody wished to hinder your going. And how unnecessary it has been for you to toil along on foot, and encumber yourself with this heavy load! I have followed like a madman, simply to drive you the rest of the distance, if you won’t come back.’
“你为什么要这样偷偷地溜走？”德伯维尔气喘吁吁地说。 “也是在周日早上，当时人们都已经上床睡觉了！”我只是偶然发现的，而且我一直开得很好，想要超越你。只要看看母马就知道了。为什么就这样走了？你知道没有人愿意阻碍你的前进。你步行劳作，背负如此重的担子，是多么没有必要啊！我像个疯子一样跟着，只是为了开车送你走完剩下的路程，如果你不回来的话。

‘I shan’t come back,’ said she.
“我不会回来了，”她说。

‘I thought you wouldn’t—I said so! Well, then, put up your basket, and let me help you on.’
“我以为你不会——我就是这么说的！好吧，那么，把你的篮子收起来，让我帮你。”

She listlessly placed her basket and bundle within the dog-cart, and stepped up, and they sat side by side. She had no fear of him now, and in the cause of her confidence her sorrow lay.
她无精打采地将篮子和包袱放进狗车里，然后走上前去，他们并排坐着。她现在不再害怕他了，她的悲伤源于她的信任。

D’Urberville mechanically lit a cigar, and the journey was continued with broken unemotional conversation on the commonplace objects by the wayside. He had quite forgotten his struggle to kiss her when, in the early summer, they had driven in the opposite direction along the same road. But she had not, and she sat now, like a puppet, replying to his remarks in monosyllables. After some miles they came in view of the clump of trees beyond which the village of Marlott stood. It was only then that her still face showed the least emotion, a tear or two beginning to trickle down.
德伯维尔机械地点燃了一支雪茄，旅程继续，在路边常见的物品上断断续续、毫无感情地交谈着。他完全忘记了初夏时节，当他们沿着同一条路向相反的方向行驶时，他费力去吻她。但她没有，现在她像个木偶一样坐着，用单音节回答他的话。几英里后，他们看到了树林，远处就是马洛特村。直到这时，她那静止的脸上才露出了一丝情绪，一两滴泪水开始淌下来。

‘What are you crying for?’ he coldly asked.
“你哭什么？”他冷冷地问道。

‘I was only thinking that I was born over there,’ murmured Tess.
“我只是以为我出生在那里，”苔丝低声说道。

‘Well—we must all be born somewhere.’
“嗯——我们都必须出生在某个地方。”

‘I wish I had never been born—there or anywhere else!’
“我希望我从未出生过——在那里或其他任何地方！”

‘Pooh! Well, if you didn’t wish to come to Trantridge why did you come?’
'呸！好吧，如果你不想来特兰特里奇，那你为什么来呢？

She did not reply.
她没有回答。

‘You didn’t come for love of me, that I’ll swear.’
“我发誓，你不是为了爱我才来的。”

‘‘Tis quite true. If I had gone for love o’ you, if I had ever sincerely loved you, if I loved you still, I should not so loathe and hate myself for my weakness as I do now! ... My eyes were dazed by you for a little, and that was all.’
” “这是千真万确的。如果我是为了爱你而去的，如果我曾经真诚地爱过你，如果我还爱你，我就不会像现在这样厌恶和憎恨自己的软弱！ ……我的眼睛被你迷惑了一会儿，仅此而已。

He shrugged his shoulders. She resumed—
他耸耸肩。她继续——

‘I didn’t understand your meaning till it was too late.’
“我没明白你的意思，直到为时已晚。”

‘That’s what every woman says.’
“每个女人都这么说。”

‘How can you dare to use such words!’ she cried, turning impetuously upon him, her eyes flashing as the latent spirit (of which he was to see more some day) awoke in her. ‘My God! I could knock you out of the gig! Did it never strike your mind that what every woman says some women may feel?’
“你怎么敢用这样的词！”她大声喊道，急躁地转向他，当潜在的灵魂（有一天他会看到更多）在她体内苏醒时，她的眼睛闪烁着光芒。 '我的上帝！我可以把你赶出演出！你有没有想过，每个女人所说的话，有些女人可能会有同样的感受？

‘Very well,’ he said, laughing; ‘I am sorry to wound you. I did wrong—I admit it.’ He dropped into some little bitterness as he continued: ‘Only you needn’t be so everlastingly flinging it in my face. I am ready to pay to the uttermost farthing. You know you need not work in the fields or the dairies again. You know you may clothe yourself with the best, instead of in the bald plain way you have lately affected, as if you couldn’t get a ribbon more than you earn.’
“很好，”他笑着说道。 ‘我很抱歉伤害了你。我做错了——我承认。”他继续说道：“只是你不必总是把它扔到我脸上。我已经准备好付出最大的代价了。您知道您不再需要在田地里或奶牛场工作。你知道你可以给自己穿上最好的衣服，而不是像最近那样光秃秃的，就好像你不能得到比你挣的更多的丝带一样。

Her lip lifted slightly, though there was little scorn, as a rule, in her large and impulsive nature.
她的嘴唇微微上扬，尽管她性格大而冲动，但通常不带一丝蔑视。

‘I have said I will not take anything more from you, and I will not—I cannot! I SHOULD be your creature to go on doing that, and I won’t!’
“我说过我不会再从你那里拿走任何东西，我不会——我不能！我应该成为你的创造物，继续这样做，但我不会！

‘One would think you were a princess from your manner, in addition to a true and original d’Urberville—ha! ha! Well, Tess, dear, I can say no more. I suppose I am a bad fellow—a damn bad fellow. I was born bad, and I have lived bad, and I shall die bad in all probability. But, upon my lost soul, I won’t be bad towards you again, Tess. And if certain circumstances should arise—you understand—in which you are in the least need, the least difficulty, send me one line, and you shall have by return whatever you require. I may not be at Trantridge—I am going to London for a time—I can’t stand the old woman. But all letters will be forwarded.’
“从你的举止来看，人们会认为你是一位公主，而且是一个真正的、原创的德伯维尔——哈！哈！好吧，苔丝，亲爱的，我不能再说了。我想我是个坏人——一个该死的坏人。我生来就是坏的，我活得也是坏的，而且很可能我也会死得很坏。但是，以我迷失的灵魂起誓，我不会再对你不好了，苔丝。如果出现某些情况——你明白——在你最不需要、最困难的情况下，给我写一封信，你就会得到你需要的任何东西。我可能不在特兰特里奇——我要去伦敦一段时间——我受不了那个老太婆。但所有信件都会被转发。”

She said that she did not wish him to drive her further, and they stopped just under the clump of trees. D’Urberville alighted, and lifted her down bodily in his arms, afterwards placing her articles on the ground beside her. She bowed to him slightly, her eye just lingering in his; and then she turned to take the parcels for departure.
她说她不想让他开车送她走得更远，他们就在树丛下停了下来。德伯维尔下了车，将她整个人抱在怀里，然后把她的物品放在她旁边的地上。她向他微微鞠了一躬，目光只是停留在他的身上。然后她转身拿着包裹准备离开。

Alec d’Urberville removed his cigar, bent towards her, and said—
亚历克·德伯维尔取下雪茄，弯腰对她说道——

‘You are not going to turn away like that, dear! Come!’
‘亲爱的，你不能就这样转身走开！来！'

‘If you wish,’ she answered indifferently. ‘See how you’ve mastered me!’
“如果你愿意的话。”她漠然地回答。 “看你怎么征服我的！”

She thereupon turned round and lifted her face to his, and remained like a marble term while he imprinted a kiss upon her cheek—half perfunctorily, half as if zest had not yet quite died out. Her eyes vaguely rested upon the remotest trees in the lane while the kiss was given, as though she were nearly unconscious of what he did.
于是她转过身来，抬起头来面对他，当他在她的脸颊上印下一个吻时，她的脸仍然像大理石一样——半是敷衍，半是好像热情还没有完全消失。亲吻时，她的目光模糊地落在巷子里最远的树上，仿佛她几乎没有意识到他做了什么。

‘Now the other side, for old acquaintance’ sake.’
“现在到另一边了，看在老熟人的份上。”

She turned her head in the same passive way, as one might turn at the request of a sketcher or hairdresser, and he kissed the other side, his lips touching cheeks that were damp and smoothly chill as the skin of the mushrooms in the fields around.
她以同样被动的方式转过头，就像一个人可能会应素描师或美发师的要求转过头一样，而他亲吻了另一侧，他的嘴唇触碰着湿润而光滑的脸颊，就像周围田野里蘑菇的皮肤一样。 。

‘You don’t give me your mouth and kiss me back. You never willingly do that—you’ll never love me, I fear.’
‘你不把你的嘴给我并回吻我。你永远不会愿意这样做——我担心你永远不会爱我。

‘I have said so, often. It is true. I have never really and truly loved you, and I think I never can.’ She added mournfully, ‘Perhaps, of all things, a lie on this thing would do the most good to me now; but I have honour enough left, little as ‘tis, not to tell that lie. If I did love you, I may have the best o’ causes for letting you know it. But I don’t.’
“我经常这么说。是真的。我从来没有真正真正地爱过你，我想我永远也不能。”她悲伤地补充道，“也许，在这件事上撒谎对我现在来说是最好的；但我还有足够的荣誉，尽管如此，我不能撒谎。如果我真的爱你，我可能有最好的理由让你知道。但我不这么认为。

He emitted a laboured breath, as if the scene were getting rather oppressive to his heart, or to his conscience, or to his gentility.
他费力地喘了口气，仿佛这一幕对他的心、他的良心、或者他的绅士风度来说变得相当压抑。

‘Well, you are absurdly melancholy, Tess. I have no reason for flattering you now, and I can say plainly that you need not be so sad. You can hold your own for beauty against any woman of these parts, gentle or simple; I say it to you as a practical man and well-wisher. If you are wise you will show it to the world more than you do before it fades... And yet, Tess, will you come back to me! Upon my soul, I don’t like to let you go like this!’
“嗯，苔丝，你真是忧郁得可笑。我现在没有什么理由恭维你，我可以坦白地说，你不用这么伤心。你可以坚持自己的美丽，与任何具有这些特质的女人相比，无论是温柔的还是简单的；我以一个务实的人和好心人的身份对你说这句话。如果你明智的话，你会在它消失之前更多地向世界展示它……然而，苔丝，你会回到我身边吗！我发誓，我不想让你就这样离开！

‘Never, never! I made up my mind as soon as I saw—what I ought to have seen sooner; and I won’t come.’
‘从来没有，从来没有！我一看到就下定决心——我应该早点看到的；我不会来。

‘Then good morning, my four months’ cousin—good-bye!’
“那么早上好，我四个月大的表弟——再见！”

He leapt up lightly, arranged the reins, and was gone between the tall red-berried hedges.
他轻轻地跳了起来，整理好缰绳，然后消失在高大的红浆果树篱之间。

Tess did not look after him, but slowly wound along the crooked lane. It was still early, and though the sun’s lower limb was just free of the hill, his rays, ungenial and peering, addressed the eye rather than the touch as yet. There was not a human soul near. Sad October and her sadder self seemed the only two existences haunting that lane.
苔丝没有看他，而是沿着弯曲的小巷慢慢蜿蜒前行。时间还早，虽然太阳的下半身刚刚离开了山丘，但他的光线，不友善，凝视着，吸引着眼睛，而不是触摸。附近没有一个人类的灵魂。悲伤的十月和她更悲伤的自己似乎是那条小巷中唯一的两个存在。

As she walked, however, some footsteps approached behind her, the footsteps of a man; and owing to the briskness of his advance he was close at her heels and had said ‘Good morning’ before she had been long aware of his propinquity. He appeared to be an artisan of some sort, and carried a tin pot of red paint in his hand. He asked in a business-like manner if he should take her basket, which she permitted him to do, walking beside him.
然而，正当她走着的时候，身后有脚步声靠近，是一个男人的脚步声。由于他的动作很快，他就紧跟在她的后面，在她早就意识到他的接近之前，他就说了声“早上好”。他看起来像是一位工匠，手里拿着一罐红色油漆。他以一种公事公办的方式询问他是否应该拿走她的篮子，她允许他这样做，并走在他身边。

‘It is early to be astir this Sabbath morn!’ he said cheerfully.
“这个安息日早上起床还早！”他高兴地说。

‘Yes,’ said Tess.
“是的，”苔丝说。

‘When most people are at rest from their week’s work.’
“当大多数人从一周的工作中得到休息时。”

She also assented to this.
对此，她也表示同意。

‘Though I do more real work to-day than all the week besides.’
“尽管我今天做的实际工作比整周都多。”

‘Do you?’
'你？'

‘All the week I work for the glory of man, and on Sunday for the glory of God. That’s more real than the other—hey? I have a little to do here at this stile.’ The man turned, as he spoke, to an opening at the roadside leading into a pasture. ‘If you’ll wait a moment,’ he added, ‘I shall not be long.’
“我整个星期都为了人类的荣耀而工作，周日则为了上帝的荣耀而工作。这比另一个更真实——嘿？我在这个栅栏有一点事要做。”说话的时候，那人转身走向路边通向牧场的一个空地。 “如果你能等一下，”他补充道，“我不会等太久的。”

As he had her basket she could not well do otherwise; and she waited, observing him. He set down her basket and the tin pot, and stirring the paint with the brush that was in it began painting large square letters on the middle board of the three composing the stile, placing a comma after each word, as if to give pause while that word was driven well home to the reader’s heart—
既然他手里有她的篮子，她就别无选择。她等待着，观察着他。他放下她的篮子和锡罐，用里面的画笔搅动油漆，开始在组成栅栏的三个中间板上画大的方形字母，在每个单词后面放一个逗号，仿佛要停顿一下。这句话深深地印在了读者的心里——

THY, DAMNATION, SLUMBERETH, NOT.
你的，该死的，不睡觉。

2 Pet. ii. 3.
2 宠物。二. 3.

Against the peaceful landscape, the pale, decaying tints of the copses, the blue air of the horizon, and the lichened stile-boards, these staring vermilion words shone forth. They seemed to shout themselves out and make the atmosphere ring. Some people might have cried ‘Alas, poor Theology!’ at the hideous defacement—the last grotesque phase of a creed which had served mankind well in its time. But the words entered Tess with accusatory horror. It was as if this man had known her recent history; yet he was a total stranger.
在宁静的风景、苍白、腐烂的树林、地平线的蓝色空气和长满青苔的门框的映衬下，这些凝视的朱红色文字闪闪发光。他们似乎在大声喊叫，让气氛响起。有些人可能会对这种可怕的污损大喊“唉，可怜的神学！”——这是当时对人类大有裨益的信条最后的怪诞阶段。但苔丝听到这句话时，心里充满了指责的恐惧。就好像这个男人知道她最近的经历一样；但他完全是个陌生人。

Having finished his text he picked up her basket, and she mechanically resumed her walk beside him.
发完短信后，他拿起她的篮子，她机械地继续在他身边行走。

‘Do you believe what you paint?’ she asked in low tones.
“你相信你画的东西吗？”她低声问道。

‘Believe that tex? Do I believe in my own existence!’
‘相信那个特克斯吗？我相信自己的存在吗？

‘But,’ said she tremulously, ‘suppose your sin was not of your own seeking?’
“但是，”她颤抖着说道，“如果你的罪不是你自己造成的呢？”

He shook his head.
他摇摇头。

‘I cannot split hairs on that burning query,’ he said. ‘I have walked hundreds of miles this past summer, painting these texes on every wall, gate, and stile the length and breadth of this district. I leave their application to the hearts of the people who read ‘em.’
他说：“对于这个紧迫的问题，我无法挑剔。” “去年夏天我走了数百英里，在这个地区的每一面墙壁、大门和栅栏上都画了这些文字。我把它们的应用留给那些读过它们的人。

‘I think they are horrible,’ said Tess. ‘Crushing! Killing!’
“我认为他们太可怕了，”苔丝说。 ‘粉碎！杀人！’

‘That’s what they are meant to be!’ he replied in a trade voice. ‘But you should read my hottest ones—them I kips for slums and seaports. They’d make ye wriggle! Not but what this is a very good tex for rural districts. ... Ah—there’s a nice bit of blank wall up by that barn standing to waste. I must put one there—one that it will be good for dangerous young females like yerself to heed. Will ye wait, missy?’
“这就是它们的本来面目！”他用专业的声音回答道。 “但你应该读一下我最热门的那些——我把它们放在贫民窟和海港上。他们会让你蠕动！不是，而是这对于农村地区来说是一个非常好的文本。 ……啊——那个谷仓旁边有一大块空白的墙闲置着。我必须在那里放一个——一个对于像你这样危险的年轻女性来说会有好处的。你会等吗，小姐？

‘No,’ said she; and taking her basket Tess trudged on. A little way forward she turned her head. The old gray wall began to advertise a similar fiery lettering to the first, with a strange and unwonted mien, as if distressed at duties it had never before been called upon to perform. It was with a sudden flush that she read and realized what was to be the inscription he was now halfway through—
“不，”她说。苔丝提着篮子艰难地前行。向前走了一小段，她转过头。古老的灰色墙壁上开始出现与第一面类似的火热字体，带着一种奇怪而不寻常的神态，仿佛对它以前从未被要求执行的职责感到苦恼。当她读到一半时，她突然脸红了，意识到他现在读到一半的铭文是什么——

THOU, SHALT, NOT, COMMIT—
你不应该承诺——

Her cheerful friend saw her looking, stopped his brush, and shouted—
她兴高采烈的朋友看到​​她在看，停下了画笔，喊道——

‘If you want to ask for edification on these things of moment, there’s a very earnest good man going to preach a charity-sermon to-day in the parish you are going to—Mr Clare of Emminster. I’m not of his persuasion now, but he’s a good man, and he’ll expound as well as any parson I know. ‘Twas he began the work in me.’
“如果你想寻求对这些当下事情的启发，今天有一位非常热心的好人将在你要去的教区进行慈善布道——埃明斯特的克莱尔先生。我现在不同意他的观点，但他是个好人，他会像我认识的任何牧师一样阐述得很好。 “正是他在我身上开始了工作。”

But Tess did not answer; she throbbingly resumed her walk, her eyes fixed on the ground. ‘Pooh—I don’t believe God said such things!’ she murmured contemptuously when her flush had died away.
但苔丝没有回答。她颤抖着继续行走，眼睛盯着地面。 “呸——我不相信上帝会说这样的话！”当她的脸红消失后，她轻蔑地低声说道。

A plume of smoke soared up suddenly from her father’s chimney, the sight of which made her heart ache. The aspect of the interior, when she reached it, made her heart ache more. Her mother, who had just come down stairs, turned to greet her from the fireplace, where she was kindling barked-oak twigs under the breakfast kettle. The young children were still above, as was also her father, it being Sunday morning, when he felt justified in lying an additional half-hour.
父亲的烟囱里突然冒出一缕青烟，看着她心都痛了。当她到达里面时，里面的景象让她的心更加疼痛。她的母亲刚刚下楼，转身在壁炉旁迎接她，她正在早餐水壶下点燃树皮橡树枝。年幼的孩子们还在上面，她的父亲也在上面，那是周日早上，他觉得多躺半个小时是合理的。

‘Well!—my dear Tess!’ exclaimed her surprised mother, jumping up and kissing the girl. ‘How be ye? I didn’t see you till you was in upon me! Have you come home to be married?’
“好吧！——我亲爱的苔丝！”她惊讶的母亲惊呼道，跳起来亲吻了女孩。 ‘你怎么样？直到你出现在我面前我才看到你！你回家结婚了吗？

‘No, I have not come for that, mother.’
“不，我不是为了这个而来的，妈妈。”

‘Then for a holiday?’
“那么去度假吗？”

‘Yes—for a holiday; for a long holiday,’ said Tess.
“是的——去度假； “放个长假吧。”苔丝说。

‘What, isn’t your cousin going to do the handsome thing?’
“怎么，你表弟不打算做一件帅气的事吗？”

‘He’s not my cousin, and he’s not going to marry me.’
“他不是我的表弟，他不会嫁给我。”

Her mother eyed her narrowly.
她母亲眯起眼睛看着她。

‘Come, you have not told me all,’ she said.
“得了吧，你还没有告诉我一切，”她说。

Then Tess went up to her mother, put her face upon Joan’s neck, and told.
然后苔丝走到她母亲面前，把脸靠在琼的脖子上，告诉了她。

‘And yet th’st not got him to marry ‘ee!’ reiterated her mother. ‘Any woman would have done it but you, after that!’
“但这并没有让他结婚！”她母亲重申道。 “从那以后，除了你之外，任何女人都会这么做！”

‘Perhaps any woman would except me.’
“也许除了我之外，任何女人都会这么做。”

‘It would have been something like a story to come back with, if you had!’ continued Mrs Durbeyfield, ready to burst into tears of vexation. ‘After all the talk about you and him which has reached us here, who would have expected it to end like this! Why didn’t ye think of doing some good for your family instead o’ thinking only of yourself? See how I’ve got to teave and slave, and your poor weak father with his heart clogged like a dripping-pan. I did hope for something to come out o’ this! To see what a pretty pair you and he made that day when you drove away together four months ago! See what he has given us—all, as we thought, because we were his kin. But if he’s not, it must have been done because of his love for ‘ee. And yet you’ve not got him to marry!’
“如果你有的话，这会是一个可以带回来的故事！”德北菲尔德夫人继续说道，她快要气得哭起来了。 ‘你和他的事都传到我们这儿来了，谁能想到会是这样的结局！为什么你不考虑为家人做点好事，而只考虑自己呢？看看我是如何耕种和奴役的，而你可怜的、虚弱的父亲，他的心像滴水的锅一样堵塞了。我确实希望能有一些成果！看看四个月前你们一起开车离开的那一天，你和他是多么漂亮的一对啊！看看他给了我们什么——一切，正如我们所想的，因为我们是他的亲属。但如果他不是，那一定是因为他对“ee”的爱。但你还没有让他结婚！

Get Alec d’Urberville in the mind to marry her! He marry HER! On matrimony he had never once said a word. And what if he had? How a convulsive snatching at social salvation might have impelled her to answer him she could not say. But her poor foolish mother little knew her present feeling towards this man. Perhaps it was unusual in the circumstances, unlucky, unaccountable; but there it was; and this, as she had said, was what made her detest herself. She had never wholly cared for him; she did not at all care for him now. She had dreaded him, winced before him, succumbed to adroit advantages he took of her helplessness; then, temporarily blinded by his ardent manners, had been stirred to confused surrender awhile: had suddenly despised and disliked him, and had run away. That was all. Hate him she did not quite; but he was dust and ashes to her, and even for her name’s sake she scarcely wished to marry him.
让亚历克·德伯维尔考虑娶她！他娶了她！关于婚姻，他从来没有说过一句话。如果他有呢？她说不上来，她对社会拯救的强烈渴望是如何促使她回答他的。但她可怜又愚蠢的母亲却不知道她现在对这个男人的感情。也许这在当时的情况下是不寻常的、不幸的、不负责任的。但它就在那里；正如她所说，这就是她厌恶自己的原因。她从来没有完全关心过他。她现在一点也不关心他了。她害怕他，在他面前退缩，屈服于他巧妙地利用她的无助。然后，他的热情态度暂时蒙蔽了他的双眼，让他迷惑不解地投降了：突然鄙视他、不喜欢他，然后逃跑了。就这些。她并不十分恨他；但他对她来说只是尘土和灰烬，甚至为了她的名字，她也不愿意嫁给他。

‘You ought to have been more careful if you didn’t mean to get him to make you his wife!’
“如果你不是故意让他娶你为妻的话，你应该更加小心！”

‘O mother, my mother!’ cried the agonized girl, turning passionately upon her parent as if her poor heart would break. ‘How could I be expected to know? I was a child when I left this house four months ago. Why didn’t you tell me there was danger in men-folk? Why didn’t you warn me? Ladies know what to fend hands against, because they read novels that tell them of these tricks; but I never had the chance o’ learning in that way, and you did not help me!’
“哦，妈妈，我的妈妈！”痛苦的女孩大声喊道，她热情地转向她的父母，仿佛她可怜的心要碎了。 ‘我怎么能知道呢？四个月前我离开这个家时，我还是个孩子。你为什么不告诉我男人有危险？你为什么不警告我？女士们知道该抵挡什么，因为她们读的小说告诉她们这些技巧。但我从来没有机会以这种方式学习，而且你也没有帮助我！”

Her mother was subdued.
她的母亲被制服了。

‘I thought if I spoke of his fond feelings and what they might lead to, you would be hontish wi’ him and lose your chance,’ she murmured, wiping her eyes with her apron. ‘Well, we must make the best of it, I suppose. ‘Tis nater, after all, and what do please God!’
“我想，如果我说出他的好感以及它们可能会导致什么，你就会对他忠诚并失去机会，”她低声说道，用围裙擦着眼睛。 “好吧，我想我们必须充分利用它。 “这毕竟是自然之事，上帝会喜悦什么！”

XIII
十三

The event of Tess Durbeyfield’s return from the manor of her bogus kinsfolk was rumoured abroad, if rumour be not too large a word for a space of a square mile. In the afternoon several young girls of Marlott, former schoolfellows and acquaintances of Tess, called to see her, arriving dressed in their best starched and ironed, as became visitors to a person who had made a transcendent conquest (as they supposed), and sat round the room looking at her with great curiosity. For the fact that it was this said thirty-first cousin, Mr d’Urberville, who had fallen in love with her, a gentleman not altogether local, whose reputation as a reckless gallant and heartbreaker was beginning to spread beyond the immediate boundaries of Trantridge, lent Tess’s supposed position, by its fearsomeness, a far higher fascination that it would have exercised if unhazardous.
苔丝·德北菲尔德从她的假亲戚的庄园回来的事件在国外广为流传，如果谣言对于方圆一英里的空间来说不是太大的话。下午，马洛特的几个年轻女孩，苔丝以前的同学和熟人，打电话来看望她，她们穿着她们最好的衣服，浆洗过，熨烫过，就像拜访了一个取得了超然征服的人（正如她们所认为的那样），然后坐下来。房间里的人都好奇地看着她。事实上，正是这位三十表弟德伯维尔先生爱上了她，一位不完全是本地人的绅士，他作为一个鲁莽的英勇和令人心碎的名声开始传播到特兰特里奇的直接边界之外苔丝的假定地位，由于其可怕性，赋予了它在没有危险的情况下所表现出的更高的魅力。

Their interest was so deep that the younger ones whispered when her back was turned—
他们的兴趣如此之深，以至于当她转过身去时，年轻的孩子们低声说道——

‘How pretty she is; and how that best frock do set her off! I believe it cost an immense deal, and that it was a gift from him.’
‘她多么漂亮啊！那件最好的连衣裙让她多么着迷啊！我相信这花费了巨大的代价，而且这是他的礼物。”

Tess, who was reaching up to get the tea-things from the corner-cupboard, did not hear these commentaries. If she had heard them, she might soon have set her friends right on the matter. But her mother heard, and Joan’s simple vanity, having been denied the hope of a dashing marriage, fed itself as well as it could upon the sensation of a dashing flirtation. Upon the whole she felt gratified, even though such a limited and evanescent triumph should involve her daughter’s reputation; it might end in marriage yet, and in the warmth of her responsiveness to their admiration she invited her visitors to stay to tea.
苔丝正伸手去拿角落柜子里的茶具，没有听到这些评论。如果她听到了他们的话，她可能很快就会纠正她的朋友们的说法。但她的母亲听到了，琼单纯的虚荣心被剥夺了美好婚姻的希望，在一次潇洒的调情中得到了最大的满足。总的来说，她感到很欣慰，尽管这种有限且转瞬即逝的胜利会涉及到她女儿的声誉；也许最终会以婚姻告终，而她对他们的钦佩做出了热情的回应，她邀请客人留下来喝茶。

Their chatter, their laughter, their good-humoured innuendoes, above all, their flashes and flickerings of envy, revived Tess’s spirits also; and, as the evening wore on, she caught the infection of their excitement, and grew almost gay. The marble hardness left her face, she moved with something of her old bounding step, and flushed in all her young beauty.
他们的闲聊、笑声、幽默的暗示，尤其是他们闪烁的嫉妒之情，也让苔丝精神焕发。随着夜幕降临，她也感染了他们的兴奋，变得几乎快活起来。她的脸上不再有大理石般的坚硬，她迈着古老的跳跃步伐，年轻的美丽让她脸红了。

At moments, in spite of thought, she would reply to their inquiries with a manner of superiority, as if recognizing that her experiences in the field of courtship had, indeed, been slightly enviable. But so far was she from being, in the words of Robert South, ‘in love with her own ruin,’ that the illusion was transient as lightning; cold reason came back to mock her spasmodic weakness; the ghastliness of her momentary pride would convict her, and recall her to reserved listlessness again.
有时，她会不顾思考地回答他们的询问，表现出一种优越感，仿佛认识到自己在求爱方面的经历确实有点令人羡慕。但用罗伯特·索思的话说，她远非“爱上自己的毁灭”，这种幻觉像闪电一样转瞬即逝。冰冷的理智回来嘲笑她痉挛性的虚弱。她一时的骄傲所带来的可怕的感觉会让她感到内疚，并让她再次陷入保留的无精打采之中。

And the despondency of the next morning’s dawn, when it was no longer Sunday, but Monday; and no best clothes; and the laughing visitors were gone, and she awoke alone in her old bed, the innocent younger children breathing softly around her. In place of the excitement of her return, and the interest it had inspired, she saw before her a long and stony highway which she had to tread, without aid, and with little sympathy. Her depression was then terrible, and she could have hidden herself in a tomb.
还有第二天黎明时的沮丧，那时不再是周日，而是周一；也没有最好的衣服；那些欢笑的访客都消失了，她独自一人在旧床上醒来，天真的小孩子们在她身边轻轻地呼吸着。她不再为归来而兴奋，也不再激发兴趣，而是看到了面前的一条漫长而石质的公路，她必须在没有援助、也没有多少同情的情况下走在这条公路上。当时她的抑郁症非常严重，她简直可以把自己藏进坟墓里。

In the course of a few weeks Tess revived sufficiently to show herself so far as was necessary to get to church one Sunday morning. She liked to hear the chanting—such as it was—and the old Psalms, and to join in the Morning Hymn. That innate love of melody, which she had inherited from her ballad-singing mother, gave the simplest music a power over her which could well-nigh drag her heart out of her bosom at times.
几周后，苔丝恢复了足够的精神，足以在周日早上去教堂。她喜欢听吟诵——就像它本来的样子——和古老的诗篇，并加入晨祷。她从歌谣母亲那里继承了对旋律与生俱来的热爱，赋予了她最简单的音乐力量，有时几乎可以把她的心从怀里拉出来。

To be as much out of observation as possible for reasons of her own, and to escape the gallantries of the young men, she set out before the chiming began, and took a back seat under the gallery, close to the lumber, where only old men and women came, and where the bier stood on end among the churchyard tools.
为了尽可能不被人注意，也为了躲避年轻人的殷勤，她在钟声开始前就出发了，在画廊下面靠近木材的地方坐了一个后座，那里只有老旧的木材。男人和女人都来了，棺材竖立在教堂墓地的工具中间。

Parishioners dropped in by twos and threes, deposited themselves in rows before her, rested three-quarters of a minute on their foreheads as if they were praying, though they were not; then sat up, and looked around. When the chants came on, one of her favourites happened to be chosen among the rest—the old double chant ‘Langdon’—but she did not know what it was called, though she would much have liked to know. She thought, without exactly wording the thought, how strange and god-like was a composer’s power, who from the grave could lead through sequences of emotion, which he alone had felt at first, a girl like her who had never heard of his name, and never would have a clue to his personality.
教区居民三三两两地来到她面前，在她面前排成一排，在额头上休息了四分之三分钟，仿佛在祈祷，尽管他们并没有这样做。然后坐起来，环顾四周。当圣歌响起时，她最喜欢的一首歌曲恰好从其余歌曲中被选中——古老的双圣歌“兰登”——但她不知道它叫什么，尽管她很想知道。她想，虽然没有确切地表达这个想法，作曲家的力量是多么奇怪和神圣，他从坟墓里就能引导出一系列的情感，只有他一个人第一次感受到这种感觉，像她这样一个从未听说过他名字的女孩，永远不会知道他的个性。

The people who had turned their heads turned them again as the service proceeded; and at last observing her, they whispered to each other. She knew what their whispers were about, grew sick at heart, and felt that she could come to church no more.
随着仪式的进行，原本转过头的人们又转过头来。最后他们观察到了她，互相窃窃私语。她知道他们的窃窃私语是怎么回事，心里感到恶心，觉得自己不能再去教堂了。

The bedroom which she shared with some of the children formed her retreat more continually than ever. Here, under her few square yards of thatch, she watched winds, and snows, and rains, gorgeous sunsets, and successive moons at their full. So close kept she that at length almost everybody thought she had gone away.
她与一些孩子共用的卧室比以往任何时候都更加频繁地成为她的隐居处。在这里，在她那几平方码的茅草下，她看着风、雪、雨、绚丽的日落和连续的满月。她离她如此之近，以至于最后几乎每个人都认为她已经离开了。

The only exercise that Tess took at this time was after dark; and it was then, when out in the woods, that she seemed least solitary. She knew how to hit to a hair’s-breadth that moment of evening when the light and the darkness are so evenly balanced that the constraint of day and the suspense of night neutralize each other, leaving absolute mental liberty. It is then that the plight of being alive becomes attenuated to its least possible dimensions. She had no fear of the shadows; her sole idea seemed to be to shun mankind—or rather that cold accretion called the world, which, so terrible in the mass, is so unformidable, even pitiable, in its units.
苔丝此时唯一进行的锻炼是在天黑之后。正是在那个时候，当她在树林里时，她显得最不孤独。她知道如何在夜晚的那一刻达到毫厘之差，此时光明与黑暗是如此平衡，白天的束缚和夜晚的悬念相互抵消，留下绝对的精神自由。就在那时，活着的困境被削弱到了最小的可能程度。她不惧怕阴影；她唯一的想法似乎就是回避人类——或者更确切地说，回避那个被称为世界的冰冷的堆积物，这个世界在整体上如此可怕，在其单位中却如此不可畏惧，甚至可怜。

On these lonely hills and dales her quiescent glide was of a piece with the element she moved in. Her flexuous and stealthy figure became an integral part of the scene. At times her whimsical fancy would intensify natural processes around her till they seemed a part of her own story. Rather they became a part of it; for the world is only a psychological phenomenon, and what they seemed they were. The midnight airs and gusts, moaning amongst the tightly-wrapped buds and bark of the winter twigs, were formulae of bitter reproach. A wet day was the expression of irremediable grief at her weakness in the mind of some vague ethical being whom she could not class definitely as the God of her childhood, and could not comprehend as any other.
在这些孤独的山丘和山谷中，她静止的滑翔与她所身处的环境融为一体。她弯曲而隐秘的身材成为场景中不可或缺的一部分。有时，她异想天开的幻想会强化她周围的自然过程，直到它们似乎成为她自己故事的一部分。相反，他们成为了其中的一部分；因为世界只是一种心理现象，以及它们看起来的样子。午夜的风和阵风，在冬天树枝紧紧包裹的花蕾和树皮中呻吟，是苦涩的谴责的公式。潮湿的一天表达了她对某种模糊道德存在的软弱的无可挽回的悲伤，她无法将这个存在明确地归类为她童年的上帝，也无法像其他上帝一样理解它。

But this encompassment of her own characterization, based on shreds of convention, peopled by phantoms and voices antipathetic to her, was a sorry and mistaken creation of Tess’s fancy—a cloud of moral hobgoblins by which she was terrified without reason. It was they that were out of harmony with the actual world, not she. Walking among the sleeping birds in the hedges, watching the skipping rabbits on a moonlit warren, or standing under a pheasant-laden bough, she looked upon herself as a figure of Guilt intruding into the haunts of Innocence. But all the while she was making a distinction where there was no difference. Feeling herself in antagonism, she was quite in accord. She had been made to break an accepted social law, but no law known to the environment in which she fancied herself such an anomaly.
但这种对她自己的人物塑造的包容，基于陈规的碎片，充满了对她反感的幻影和声音，是苔丝的幻想的一个令人遗憾和错误的创造——一群道德妖怪，她无缘无故地害怕。与现实世界不和谐的是他们，而不是她。漫步在树篱中熟睡的鸟儿中间，看着月光下的窝里跳跃的兔子，或者站在挂满野鸡的树枝下，她把自己视为一个侵入纯真出没的罪恶的人物。但她一直在区分那些没有区别的地方。她感觉自己处于敌对状态，但又很和谐。她被迫违反了公认的社会法则，但在她认为自己如此异常的环境中，并没有任何法则。

XIV
十四

It was a hazy sunrise in August. The denser nocturnal vapours, attacked by the warm beams, were dividing and shrinking into isolated fleeces within hollows and coverts, where they waited till they should be dried away to nothing.
那是八月的一个朦胧的日出。夜间更浓的水蒸气在温暖的光束的攻击下，在空洞和隐蔽处分裂并收缩成孤立的羊毛，在那里等待着它们被干燥得一无所有。

The sun, on account of the mist, had a curious sentient, personal look, demanding the masculine pronoun for its adequate expression. His present aspect, coupled with the lack of all human forms in the scene, explained the old-time heliolatries in a moment. One could feel that a saner religion had never prevailed under the sky. The luminary was a golden-haired, beaming, mild-eyed, God-like creature, gazing down in the vigour and intentness of youth upon an earth that was brimming with interest for him.
由于雾气，太阳有一种奇怪的、有感情的、个性化的外观，需要男性代词才能充分表达。他现在的样子，再加上场景中缺乏所有的人类形态，立刻就解释了古代的日光崇拜。人们可以感觉到，天底下从来没有一种更理智的宗教盛行过。那个发光体是一个金发碧眼、目光温和、神一般的生物，他以青春的活力和专注凝视着这片对他充满兴趣的大地。

His light, a little later, broke though chinks of cottage shutters, throwing stripes like red-hot pokers upon cupboards, chests of drawers, and other furniture within; and awakening harvesters who were not already astir.
过了一会儿，他的光射破了小屋百叶窗的缝隙，在橱柜、抽屉柜和里面的其他家具上留下了像烧红的拨火棍一样的条纹；以及唤醒尚未苏醒的收割者。

But of all ruddy things that morning the brightest were two broad arms of painted wood, which rose from the margin of yellow cornfield hard by Marlott village. They, with two others below, formed the revolving Maltese cross of the reaping-machine, which had been brought to the field on the previous evening to be ready for operations this day. The paint with which they were smeared, intensified in hue by the sunlight, imparted to them a look of having been dipped in liquid fire.
但那天早晨，在所有红润的东西中，最亮的是两条宽阔的彩绘木臂，它们从马洛特村附近的黄色玉米地边缘升起。他们和下面的另外两个人组成了收割机的旋转马耳他十字形，该收割机已于前一天晚上运到田间，准备今天的作业。它们所涂的油漆在阳光的照射下颜色变得更加强烈，使它们看起来就像是浸在液体火中一样。

The field had already been ‘opened”; that is to say, a lane a few feet wide had been hand-cut through the wheat along the whole circumference of the field for the first passage of the horses and machine.
这个领域已经“开放”了；也就是说，沿着田地的整个圆周，在小麦中手工开辟了一条几英尺宽的小巷，以便马匹和机器首先通过。

Two groups, one of men and lads, the other of women, had come down the lane just at the hour when the shadows of the eastern hedge-top struck the west hedge midway, so that the heads of the groups were enjoying sunrise while their feet were still in the dawn. They disappeared from the lane between the two stone posts which flanked the nearest field-gate.
两群人，一男一童，一男一女，正好在东树篱顶的影子投到西树篱中途的时候，沿着小巷走来，这样，两群人的头都在享受日出，而他们的脚还在黎明。他们从最近的大门两侧的两根石柱之间的小巷消失了。

Presently there arose from within a ticking like the love-making of the grasshopper. The machine had begun, and a moving concatenation of three horses and the aforesaid long rickety machine was visible over the gate, a driver sitting upon one of the hauling horses, and an attendant on the seat of the implement. Along one side of the field the whole wain went, the arms of the mechanical reaper revolving slowly, till it passed down the hill quite out of sight. In a minute it came up on the other side of the field at the same equable pace; the glistening brass star in the forehead of the fore horse first catching the eye as it rose into view over the stubble, then the bright arms, and then the whole machine.
不一会儿，里面就响起了蚱蜢做爱般的滴答声。机器已经启动了，在大门上方可以看到三匹马和前面提到的摇摇晃晃的长机器的一连串移动，一名司机坐在一匹牵引马上，一名服务员坐在机具的座位上。整辆马车沿着田野的一侧行驶，机械收割机的手臂缓慢旋转，直到它驶下山坡，消失在视线之外。过了一会儿，它就以同样均匀的速度出现在场地的另一边。当前马的前额上闪闪发光的黄铜星星首先映入眼帘，然后是明亮的手臂，然后是整个机器。

The narrow lane of stubble encompassing the field grew wider with each circuit, and the standing corn was reduced to a smaller area as the morning wore on. Rabbits, hares, snakes, rats, mice, retreated inwards as into a fastness, unaware of the ephemeral nature of their refuge, and of the doom that awaited them later in the day when, their covert shrinking to a more and more horrible narrowness, they were huddled together, friends and foes, till the last few yards of upright wheat fell also under the teeth of the unerring reaper, and they were every one put to death by the sticks and stones of the harvesters.
每绕一圈，田野周围的窄茬就变得越来越宽，随着早晨的流逝，未收割的玉米面积也缩小了。兔子、野兔、蛇、大鼠、小鼠，都向内撤退，仿佛进入了一个堡垒，没有意识到他们的避难所是短暂的，也没有意识到当天晚些时候等待着他们的厄运，他们的隐蔽处缩小到越来越可怕的狭窄，他们是朋友也是敌人，挤在一起，直到最后几码直立的麦子也落在了无误的收割者的牙齿之下，他们一个个都被收割机的棍棒和石头杀死了。

The reaping-machine left the fallen corn behind it in little heaps, each heap being of the quantity for a sheaf; and upon these the active binders in the rear laid their hands—mainly women, but some of them men in print shirts, and trousers supported round their waists by leather straps, rendering useless the two buttons behind, which twinkled and bristled with sunbeams at every movement of each wearer, as if they were a pair of eyes in the small of his back.
收割机把掉落的玉米分成小堆，每堆的数量相当于一捆。后面的活页夹将手放在这些东西上——主要是女人，但也有一些穿着印花衬衫和裤子的男人，用皮带系在腰上，使后面的两颗纽扣变得毫无用处，每一颗纽扣都在阳光下闪烁和竖起。每个佩戴者的一举一动，都仿佛是他后背上的一双眼睛。

But those of the other sex were the most interesting of this company of binders, by reason of the charm which is acquired by woman when she becomes part and parcel of outdoor nature, and is not merely an object set down therein as at ordinary times. A field-man is a personality afield; a field-woman is a portion of the field; she had somehow lost her own margin, imbibed the essence of her surrounding, and assimilated herself with it.
但异性的那些活页夹是这群活页夹中最有趣的，因为当女人成为户外自然的重要组成部分时，她就获得了魅力，而不仅仅是像平时那样放置在其中的物体。外勤人员是指在外地工作的人。田野妇女是田野的一部分；她不知何故失去了自己的边缘，吸收了周围环境的精华，并将自己同化了。

The women—or rather girls, for they were mostly young—wore drawn cotton bonnets with great flapping curtains to keep off the sun, and gloves to prevent their hands being wounded by the stubble. There was one wearing a pale pink jacket, another in a cream-coloured tight-sleeved gown, another in a petticoat as red as the arms of the reaping-machine; and others, older, in the brown-rough ‘wropper’ or over-all—the old-established and most appropriate dress of the field-woman, which the young ones were abandoning. This morning the eye returns involuntarily to the girl in the pink cotton jacket, she being the most flexuous and finely-drawn figure of them all. But her bonnet is pulled so far over her brow that none of her face is disclosed while she binds, though her complexion may be guessed from a stray twine or two of dark brown hair which extends below the curtain of her bonnet. Perhaps one reason why she seduces casual attention is that she never courts it, though the other women often gaze around them.
妇女们——或者更确切地说是女孩，因为她们大多很年轻——戴着拉长的棉质帽子，上面有飘动的大窗帘来遮挡阳光，还戴着手套，以防双手被胡茬弄伤。其中一个穿着淡粉色夹克，另一个穿着米色紧身袖长袍，还有一个穿着像收割机手臂一样红的衬裙；还有一些年龄较大的人，穿着棕色粗糙的“外套”或工作服——这是一种老式的、最适合田野妇女的服装，但年轻人正在放弃这种服装。今天早上，人们的目光不由自主地回到了那个穿着粉红色棉袄的女孩身上，她是所有人物中最柔美、最精致的一个。但她的帽子被拉得很远，盖住了她的额头，所以在她绑的时候，她的脸都没有露出来，尽管她的肤色可以从延伸到帽子帘子下面的一两根深棕色头发猜出来。也许她之所以能引起不经意的关注，原因之一就是她从不求爱，尽管其他女人经常注视着她们。

Her binding proceeds with clock-like monotony. From the sheaf last finished she draws a handful of ears, patting their tips with her left palm to bring them even. Then, stooping low, she moves forward, gathering the corn with both hands against her knees, and pushing her left gloved hand under the bundle to meet the right on the other side, holding the corn in an embrace like that of a lover. She brings the ends of the bond together, and kneels on the sheaf while she ties it, beating back her skirts now and then when lifted by the breeze. A bit of her naked arm is visible between the buff leather of the gauntlet and the sleeve of her gown; and as the day wears on its feminine smoothness becomes scarified by the stubble and bleeds.
她的装订过程像时钟一样单调。她从最后完成的捆中取出一把耳朵，用左手掌拍打耳朵的尖端，使它们均匀。然后，她弯下腰，向前走，双手将玉米收拢在膝盖上，然后将戴着手套的左手推到包裹下面，与另一侧的右手相会，像情人一样将玉米抱在怀里。她把绳子的两端连在一起，在系绳子时跪在捆上，时不时地在微风吹起时拍打裙子。在手套的浅黄色皮革和长袍的袖子之间可以看到她裸露的手臂的一小部分；随着时间的流逝，它女性般的光滑感也因胡茬和流血而变得伤痕累累。

At intervals she stands up to rest, and to retie her disarranged apron, or to pull her bonnet straight. Then one can see the oval face of a handsome young woman with deep dark eyes and long heavy clinging tresses, which seem to clasp in a beseeching way anything they fall against. The cheeks are paler, the teeth more regular, the red lips thinner than is usual in a country-bred girl.
她时不时地站起来休息，重新系好凌乱的围裙，或者拉直帽子。然后，人们可以看到一位英俊的年轻女子的鹅蛋脸，她有着深邃的黑眼睛和长长的浓密的头发，似乎以恳求的方式紧紧抓住任何碰到的东西。与乡村女孩相比，她的脸颊更苍白，牙齿更整齐，红唇更薄。

It is Tess Durbeyfield, otherwise d’Urberville, somewhat changed—the same, but not the same; at the present stage of her existence living as a stranger and an alien here, though it was no strange land that she was in. After a long seclusion she had come to a resolve to undertake outdoor work in her native village, the busiest season of the year in the agricultural world having arrived, and nothing that she could do within the house being so remunerative for the time as harvesting in the fields.
这是苔丝·德北菲尔德，或者是德伯维尔，有所改变——相同，但又不一样；尽管她身处的地方并不陌生，但现阶段她还是以陌生人和外星人的身份生活在这里。经过长期的隐居之后，她决定在家乡进行户外工作，这是一年中最繁忙的季节。农业的一年已经到来，对于她来说，在家里做的事情没有什么比在田里收割更有价值的了。

The movements of the other women were more or less similar to Tess’s, the whole bevy of them drawing together like dancers in a quadrille at the completion of a sheaf by each, every one placing her sheaf on end against those of the rest, till a shock, or ‘stitch’ as it was here called, of ten or a dozen was formed.
其他女人的动作或多或少与苔丝的相似，她们一大群人聚集在一起，就像四行舞中的舞者，每个人完成一捆，每个人都将她的捆与其他人的捆放在一起，直到十个或十几个震动，或者这里所说的“缝合”形成了。

They went to breakfast, and came again, and the work proceeded as before. As the hour of eleven drew near a person watching her might have noticed that every now and then Tess’s glance flitted wistfully to the brow of the hill, though she did not pause in her sheafing. On the verge of the hour the heads of a group of children, of ages ranging from six to fourteen, rose over the stubbly convexity of the hill.
他们去吃早餐，然后又回来了，工作照常进行。随着十一点钟的临近，一个注视着她的人可能会注意到，苔丝的目光时不时地若有所思地扫向山顶，尽管她并没有停下割草的动作。时间快到了，一群年龄从六岁到十四岁不等的孩子们的头从山上的胡茬凸出的地方升起。

The face of Tess flushed slightly, but still she did not pause.
苔丝的脸微微泛红，但她仍然没有停下来。

The eldest of the comers, a girl who wore a triangular shawl, its corner draggling on the stubble, carried in her arms what at first sight seemed to be a doll, but proved to be an infant in long clothes. Another brought some lunch. The harvesters ceased working, took their provisions, and sat down against one of the shocks. Here they fell to, the men plying a stone jar freely, and passing round a cup.
其中年纪最大的是一个女孩，披着一条三角形的披肩，披肩的一角拖在胡茬上，怀里抱着一个乍一看像是洋娃娃的东西，但事实证明是一个穿着长衣服的婴儿。另一个人带来了一些午餐。收割者停止了工作，拿起他们的食物，坐下来抵御其中的冲击。他们倒在了这里，人们自由地摆弄着一个石罐，传递着一个杯子。

Tess Durbeyfield had been one of the last to suspend her labours. She sat down at the end of the shock, her face turned somewhat away from her companions. When she had deposited herself a man in a rabbit-skin cap, and with a red handkerchief tucked into his belt, held the cup of ale over the top of the shock for her to drink. But she did not accept his offer. As soon as her lunch was spread she called up the big girl, her sister, and took the baby of her, who, glad to be relieved of the burden, went away to the next shock and joined the other children playing there. Tess, with a curiously stealthy yet courageous movement, and with a still rising colour, unfastened her frock and began suckling the child.
