苔丝·德北菲尔德是最后暂停工作的人之一。震惊结束后，她坐了下来，脸有些偏离同伴。当她给自己安排一个戴兔皮帽的男人，并把一条红色手帕塞进他的腰带时，把一杯啤酒放在电击器的顶部让她喝。但她没有接受他的提议。午餐一准备好，她就叫来了大女孩，她的妹妹，并抱起了她的孩子，她很高兴摆脱了负担，去参加下一个震动，加入了在那里玩耍的其他孩子。苔丝以一种奇怪的隐秘而勇敢的动作，脸色仍在上升，解开她的连衣裙，开始给孩子喂奶。

The men who sat nearest considerately turned their faces towards the other end of the field, some of them beginning to smoke; one, with absent-minded fondness, regretfully stroking the jar that would no longer yield a stream. All the women but Tess fell into animated talk, and adjusted the disarranged knots of their hair.
坐在最近的人体贴地把脸转向田野的另一端，其中一些人开始抽烟。一个人心不在焉地喜爱着，遗憾地抚摸着不再流水的罐子。除了苔丝之外，所有的女人都七嘴八舌地聊着，整理着乱糟糟的发髻。

When the infant had taken its fill, the young mother sat it upright in her lap, and looking into the far distance, dandled it with a gloomy indifference that was almost dislike; then all of a sudden she fell to violently kissing it some dozens of times, as if she could never leave off, the child crying at the vehemence of an onset which strangely combined passionateness with contempt.
当婴儿吃饱后，年轻的母亲把它笔直地放在腿上，望着远方，用一种阴郁、冷漠、近乎厌恶的态度抚摸着它。突然间，她猛烈地亲吻了它几十次，仿佛永远无法停止，孩子突然哭了起来，这种奇怪的热情与轻蔑结合在一起。

‘She’s fond of that there child, though she mid pretend to hate en, and say she wishes the baby and her too were in the churchyard,’ observed the woman in the red petticoat.
“她很喜欢那个孩子，尽管她假装讨厌那个孩子，并说她希望孩子和她也都在教堂墓地里，”穿红色衬裙的女人说道。

‘She’ll soon leave off saying that,’ replied the one in buff. ‘Lord, ‘tis wonderful what a body can get used to o’ that sort in time!’
“她很快就会不再这么说了，”浅黄色的人回答道。 “主啊，身体能够及时适应这种情况真是太好了！”

‘A little more than persuading had to do wi’ the coming o’t, I reckon. There were they that heard a sobbing one night last year in The Chase; and it mid ha’ gone hard wi’ a certain party if folks had come along.’
我认为，“对于即将到来的事情，说服不仅仅是说服”。去年的一个晚上，他们在追逐区听到了一阵抽泣声；如果人们一起来的话，某个政党就会变得很艰难。

‘Well, a little more, or a little less, ‘twas a thousand pities that it should have happened to she, of all others. But ‘tis always the comeliest! The plain ones be as safe as churches—hey, Jenny?’ The speaker turned to one of the group who certainly was not ill-defined as plain.
“好吧，多一点，或者少一点，对于其他所有人来说，这件事发生在她身上，真是一千件遗憾。”但它总是最漂亮的！朴素的就和教堂一样安全——嘿，珍妮？”说话者转向人群中的一个人，他当然没有像教堂那样含糊不清。

It was a thousand pities, indeed; it was impossible for even an enemy to feel otherwise on looking at Tess as she sat there, with her flower-like mouth and large tender eyes, neither black nor blue nor grey nor violet; rather all those shades together, and a hundred others, which could be seen if one looked into their irises—shade behind shade—tint beyond tint—around pupils that had no bottom; an almost standard woman, but for the slight incautiousness of character inherited from her race.
确实，这是一千种遗憾；即使是敌人，看到苔丝坐在那里，她的嘴巴像花一样，温柔的大眼睛，既不是黑色，也不是蓝色，也不是灰色，也不是紫色。相反，所有这些阴影都在一起，还有一百个其他阴影，如果人们观察他们的虹膜，就可以看到它们——阴影后面的阴影——色彩上的色彩——围绕着没有底部的瞳孔；一个几乎标准的女人，但由于她的种族继承了轻微的不谨慎的性格。

A resolution which had surprised herself had brought her into the fields this week for the first time during many months. After wearing and wasting her palpitating heart with every engine of regret that lonely inexperience could devise, common sense had illuminated her. She felt that she would do well to be useful again—to taste anew sweet independence at any price. The past was past; whatever it had been, it was no more at hand. Whatever its consequences, time would close over them; they would all in a few years be as if they had never been, and she herself grassed down and forgotten. Meanwhile the trees were just as green as before; the birds sang and the sun shone as clearly now as ever. The familiar surroundings had not darkened because of her grief, nor sickened because of her pain.
本周，一项让她自己都感到惊讶的决定让她几个月来第一次踏入田野。在孤独的缺乏经验所产生的各种悔恨引擎耗尽了她那颗悸动的心之后，常识照亮了她。她觉得自己最好能再次变得有用——不惜任何代价重新尝到独立的甜蜜滋味。过去的已经过去了；不管它曾经是什么，现在已经不复存在了。无论后果如何，时间都会结束他们；几年后，他们就会变得好像从来没有出现过一样，而她自己则草草了事，被遗忘了。与此同时，树木还像以前一样绿。鸟儿歌唱，阳光照耀得一如既往。熟悉的环境并没有因为她的悲伤而变得黑暗，也没有因为她的痛苦而变得恶心。

She might have seen that what had bowed her head so profoundly—the thought of the world’s concern at her situation—was founded on an illusion. She was not an existence, an experience, a passion, a structure of sensations, to anybody but herself. To all humankind besides, Tess was only a passing thought. Even to friends she was no more than a frequently passing thought. If she made herself miserable the livelong night and day it was only this much to them—‘Ah, she makes herself unhappy.’ If she tried to be cheerful, to dismiss all care, to take pleasure in the daylight, the flowers, the baby, she could only be this idea to them—‘Ah, she bears it very well.’ Moreover, alone in a desert island would she have been wretched at what had happened to her? Not greatly. If she could have been but just created, to discover herself as a spouseless mother, with no experience of life except as the parent of a nameless child, would the position have caused her to despair? No, she would have taken it calmly, and found pleasure therein. Most of the misery had been generated by her conventional aspect, and not by her innate sensations.
她可能已经看到，让她深深低下头的想法——全世界都关心她的处境——只是建立在一种幻觉之上。对于除了她自己之外的任何人来说，她都不是一个存在、一种经历、一种激情、一种感觉结构。除此之外，对于全人类来说，苔丝只是一个转瞬即逝的想法。即使对朋友来说，她也不过是一个经常闪现的念头。如果她让自己整夜都痛苦不堪，对他们来说也只有这么多——“啊，她让自己不快乐。”如果她试图变得快乐，抛开所有的忧虑，享受阳光、鲜花、阳光和阳光。宝贝，她对他们来说只能是这个想法——“啊，她承受得很好。”而且，独自一人在荒岛上，她会因为发生在她身上的事情而感到悲惨吗？不是很大。如果她刚刚被创造出来，就发现自己是一个没有配偶的母亲，除了作为一个无名孩子的父母之外没有任何生活经验，这个职位会让她绝望吗？不，她会平静地接受，并从中找到乐趣。大部分的痛苦都是由她的传统方面造成的，而不是由她与生俱来的感觉造成的。

Whatever Tess’s reasoning, some spirit had induced her to dress herself up neatly as she had formerly done, and come out into the fields, harvest-hands being greatly in demand just then. This was why she had borne herself with dignity, and had looked people calmly in the face at times, even when holding the baby in her arms.
不管苔丝的理由是什么，某种精神促使她像以前那样把自己打扮得漂漂亮亮，来到田野里，因为那时正需要大量的收割工人。这就是为什么她表现得很有尊严，有时甚至在抱着孩子的时候也能平静地看着别人。

The harvest-men rose from the shock of corn, and stretched their limbs, and extinguished their pipes. The horses, which had been unharnessed and fed, were again attached to the scarlet machine. Tess, having quickly eaten her own meal, beckoned to her eldest sister to come and take away the baby, fastened her dress, put on the buff gloves again, and stooped anew to draw a bond from the last completed sheaf for the tying of the next.
收割工人从玉米的震动中站了起来，伸展四肢，熄灭了烟斗。那些被卸下马具并喂饱的马匹又被重新连接到猩红色的机器上。苔丝很快吃完了自己的饭，招手叫姐姐来接孩子，然后系好衣服，又戴上浅黄色的手套，又弯下腰，从最后完成的一捆捆里抽出一根绳子，把孩子绑起来。下一个。

In the afternoon and evening the proceedings of the morning were continued, Tess staying on till dusk with the body of harvesters. Then they all rode home in one of the largest wagons, in the company of a broad tarnished moon that had risen from the ground to the eastwards, its face resembling the outworn gold-leaf halo of some worm-eaten Tuscan saint. Tess’s female companions sang songs, and showed themselves very sympathetic and glad at her reappearance out of doors, though they could not refrain from mischievously throwing in a few verses of the ballad about the maid who went to the merry green wood and came back a changed state. There are counterpoises and compensations in life; and the event which had made of her a social warning had also for the moment made her the most interesting personage in the village to many. Their friendliness won her still farther away from herself, their lively spirits were contagious, and she became almost gay.
下午和晚上，上午的工作继续进行，苔丝和收割机的尸体一起待到黄昏。然后，他们全都乘坐一辆最大的马车回家，伴随着一轮从地面向东升起的宽阔、失去光泽的月亮，它的脸就像某个被虫蛀的托斯卡纳圣人的破旧的金箔光环。苔丝的女伴们唱起歌来，对她再次出现在门外表示非常同情和高兴，不过她们还是忍不住调皮地加入了几句歌谣，内容是关于女仆去了快乐的绿色树林，回来时却变了样。状态。人生有平衡，有补偿；这件事使她受到社会警告，同时也使她成为村里许多人最感兴趣的人物。他们的友善使她离自己更远了，他们活泼的精神具有感染力，她几乎变得快乐起来。

But now that her moral sorrows were passing away a fresh one arose on the natural side of her which knew no social law. When she reached home it was to learn to her grief that the baby had been suddenly taken ill since the afternoon. Some such collapse had been probable, so tender and puny was its frame; but the event came as a shock nevertheless.
但现在，她道德上的悲伤已经过去，一种新的悲伤在她不知道社会法则的自然方面出现了。当她回到家时，她悲痛地得知孩子从下午开始就突然生病了。类似的倒塌是有可能发生的，因为它的框架是如此脆弱和脆弱。但这一事件还是令人震惊。

The baby’s offence against society in coming into the world was forgotten by the girl-mother; her soul’s desire was to continue that offence by preserving the life of the child. However, it soon grew clear that the hour of emancipation for that little prisoner of the flesh was to arrive earlier than her worst misgiving had conjectured. And when she had discovered this she was plunged into a misery which transcended that of the child’s simple loss. Her baby had not been baptized.
婴儿来到这个世界时对社会的冒犯被女母亲忘记了。她灵魂的愿望是通过保护孩子的生命来继续这种罪行。然而，很快我们就清楚了，那个肉体的小囚徒获得解放的时刻比她最担心的还要早到来。当她发现这一点时，她陷入了一种比失去孩子更痛苦的痛苦之中。她的孩子还没有受洗。

Tess had drifted into a frame of mind which accepted passively the consideration that if she should have to burn for what she had done, burn she must, and there was an end of it. Like all village girls, she was well grounded in the Holy Scriptures, and had dutifully studied the histories of Aholah and Aholibah, and knew the inferences to be drawn therefrom. But when the same question arose with regard to the baby, it had a very different colour. Her darling was about to die, and no salvation.
苔丝已经陷入了一种消极的心态，她被动地接受了这样的想法：如果她必须为自己所做的事而燃烧，她就必须燃烧，然后事情就结束了。像所有村里的女孩一样，她对圣经有很好的了解，并尽职尽责地研究了阿荷拉和阿荷利巴的历史，并知道从中可以得出的推论。但当同样的问题出现在婴儿身上时，它的颜色就截然不同了。她的爱人快要死了，而且没有救赎。

It was nearly bedtime, but she rushed downstairs and asked if she might send for the parson. The moment happened to be one at which her father’s sense of the antique nobility of his family was highest, and his sensitiveness to the smudge which Tess had set upon that nobility most pronounced, for he had just returned from his weekly booze at Rolliver’s Inn. No parson should come inside his door, he declared, prying into his affairs, just then, when, by her shame, it had become more necessary than ever to hide them. He locked the door and put the key in his pocket.
快到睡觉时间了，但她冲下楼，询问是否可以派人去叫牧师。恰巧此时，她父亲对自己家族古老贵族的感觉最为强烈，而他对苔丝给这种贵族带来的污点的敏感度也最为明显，因为他刚刚从罗利弗旅馆每周一次的豪饮归来。他宣称，任何牧师都不应该进他的门，打探他的事务，而就在那时，由于她的羞耻，比以往任何时候都更有必要隐藏这些事务。他锁上门，把钥匙放进口袋里。

The household went to bed, and, distressed beyond measure, Tess retired also. She was continually waking as she lay, and in the middle of the night found that the baby was still worse. It was obviously dying—quietly and painlessly, but none the less surely.
一家人都上床睡觉了，苔丝也极度痛苦地退休了。她躺着时不断醒来，半夜发现孩子的情况更糟。它显然正在死去——安静地、无痛地，但仍然是确定无疑的。

In her misery she rocked herself upon the bed. The clock struck the solemn hour of one, that hour when fancy stalks outside reason, and malignant possibilities stand rock-firm as facts. She thought of the child consigned to the nethermost corner of hell, as its double doom for lack of baptism and lack of legitimacy; saw the arch-fiend tossing it with his three-pronged fork, like the one they used for heating the oven on baking days; to which picture she added many other quaint and curious details of torment sometimes taught the young in this Christian country. The lurid presentment so powerfully affected her imagination in the silence of the sleeping house that her nightgown became damp with perspiration, and the bedstead shook with each throb of her heart.
她痛苦地在床上摇晃着。时钟敲响了庄严的一小时，在这个时刻，幻想超越了理性，邪恶的可能性像事实一样坚如磐石。她想到了被打入地狱最底层的孩子，因为缺乏洗礼和缺乏合法性而遭受双重厄运；看到大恶魔用他的三叉叉子扔它，就像他们在烘烤日用来加热烤箱的叉子一样；她在这幅画中添加了许多其他古怪而好奇的折磨细节，这些细节有时会教给这个基督教国家的年轻人。在沉睡的房子里，这可怕的景象极大地影响了她的想象力，以至于她的睡衣被汗水浸湿了，床架随着她心脏的每一次跳动而摇晃。

The infant’s breathing grew more difficult, and the mother’s mental tension increased. It was useless to devour the little thing with kisses; she could stay in bed no longer, and walked feverishly about the room.
婴儿的呼吸变得更加困难，母亲的精神也更加紧张。用亲吻来吞噬这个小东西是没有用的；她再也不能躺在床上了，在房间里疯狂地走来走去。

‘O merciful God, have pity; have pity upon my poor baby!’ she cried. ‘Heap as much anger as you want to upon me, and welcome; but pity the child!’
‘仁慈的上帝啊，求你怜悯；可怜可怜我可怜的孩子吧！”她喊道。 “你想对我发多少怒就发多少怒，欢迎；但可怜这个孩子吧！

She leant against the chest of drawers, and murmured incoherent supplications for a long while, till she suddenly started up.
她靠在五斗柜上，语无伦次地低声恳求了半晌，才突然惊醒。

‘Ah! perhaps baby can be saved! Perhaps it will be just the same!’
'啊！或许宝宝还有救！也许一切都会一样！

She spoke so brightly that it seemed as though her face might have shone in the gloom surrounding her. She lit a candle, and went to a second and a third bed under the wall, where she awoke her young sisters and brothers, all of whom occupied the same room. Pulling out the washing-stand so that she could get behind it, she poured some water from a jug, and made them kneel around, putting their hands together with fingers exactly vertical. While the children, scarcely awake, awe-stricken at her manner, their eyes growing larger and larger, remained in this position, she took the baby from her bed—a child’s child—so immature as scarce to seem a sufficient personality to endow its producer with the maternal title. Tess then stood erect with the infant on her arm beside the basin; the next sister held the Prayer-Book open before her, as the clerk at church held it before the parson; and thus the girl set about baptizing her child.
她说话的声音那么明亮，就好像她的脸在周围的阴暗中闪闪发亮。她点燃了一根蜡烛，走到墙下的第二张和第三张床上，在那里她叫醒了住在同一个房间的年轻的姐妹和兄弟。她把洗脸架拉出来，躲到后面，从壶里倒了一些水，让他们跪下，双手合十，手指垂直。孩子们几乎还没醒，对她的举止感到敬畏，眼睛越来越大，保持着这个姿势，而她则把婴儿从床上抱起来——一个孩子的孩子——如此不成熟，似乎还没有足够的个性来赋予她的生命。具有母亲头衔的制片人。然后苔丝站在水盆旁边，胳膊上抱着婴儿。下一位修女将祈祷书打开放在她面前，就像教堂的职员将它放在牧师面前一样。于是女孩开始为她的孩子施洗。

Her figure looked singularly tall and imposing as she stood in her long white nightgown, a thick cable of twisted dark hair hanging straight down her back to her waist. The kindly dimness of the weak candle abstracted from her form and features the little blemishes which sunlight might have revealed—the stubble scratches upon her wrists, and the weariness of her eyes—her high enthusiasm having a transfiguring effect upon the face which had been her undoing, showing it as a thing of immaculate beauty, with a touch of dignity which was almost regal. The little ones kneeling round, their sleepy eyes blinking and red, awaited her preparations full of a suspended wonder which their physical heaviness at that hour would not allow to become active.
她穿着长长的白色睡衣，一头浓密的黑发从背后垂到腰间，身材显得异常高挑和威严。微弱的蜡烛温柔地昏暗，从她的身体上抽象出来，突出了阳光下可能会暴露的小瑕疵——她手腕上的胡茬划痕，还有她眼睛的疲倦——她的高度热情对她原本的脸产生了变形的效果。毁灭，将其展示为一件完美无瑕的美丽事物，带有一丝近乎帝王般的尊严。小孩子们跪在周围，睡眼惺忪地眨着，红红的，等待着她的准备工作，心中充满了悬而未决的惊奇，而此时他们的身体沉重，不允许他们变得活跃起来。

The most impressed of them said:
其中印象最深刻的是：

‘Be you really going to christen him, Tess?’
“你真的要给他起洗礼吗，苔丝？”

The girl-mother replied in a grave affirmative.
女孩母亲严肃地回答说是肯定的。

‘What’s his name going to be?’
“他叫什么名字？”

She had not thought of that, but a name suggested by a phrase in the book of Genesis came into her head as she proceeded with the baptismal service, and now she pronounced it:
她没有想到这一点，但当她进行洗礼时，《创世记》中的一个短语所暗示的一个名字进入了她的脑海，现在她宣布了这个名字：

‘SORROW, I baptize thee in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.’
“悲伤的是，我奉父、子、圣灵的名给你施洗。”

She sprinkled the water, and there was silence.
她洒了水，周围一片寂静。

‘Say ‘Amen,’ children.’
“孩子们，说‘阿门’。”

The tiny voices piped in obedient response, ‘Amen!’
微小的声音顺从地回应道：“阿门！”

Tess went on:
苔丝继续说道：

‘We receive this child’—and so forth—‘and do sign him with the sign of the Cross.’
“我们接收这个孩子”——等等——“并在他身上画了十字。”

Here she dipped her hand into the basin, and fervently drew an immense cross upon the baby with her forefinger, continuing with the customary sentences as to his manfully fighting against sin, the world, and the devil, and being a faithful soldier and servant unto his life’s end. She duly went on with the Lord’s Prayer, the children lisping it after her in a thin gnat-like wail, till, at the conclusion, raising their voices to clerk’s pitch, they again piped into silence, ‘Amen!’
在这里，她把手伸进盆里，用食指热切地在婴儿身上画了一个巨大的十字架，继续用惯常的句子讲述他英勇地与罪恶、世界和魔鬼作斗争，并成为一个忠实的战士和仆人。他生命的终结。她按部就班地继续念主祷文，孩子们在她后面用小虫般的细弱哀号声念着主祷文，直到结束时，他们把声音提高到书记员的音调，再次安静下来，“阿门！”

Then their sister, with much augmented confidence in the efficacy of the sacrament, poured forth from the bottom of her heart the thanksgiving that follows, uttering it boldly and triumphantly in the stopt-diapason note which her voice acquired when her heart was in her speech, and which will never be forgotten by those who knew her. The ecstasy of faith almost apotheosized her; it set upon her face a glowing irradiation, and brought a red spot into the middle of each cheek; while the miniature candle-flame inverted in her eye-pupils shone like a diamond. The children gazed up at her with more and more reverence, and no longer had a will for questioning. She did not look like Sissy to them now, but as a being large, towering, and awful—a divine personage with whom they had nothing in common.
然后他们的姐妹，对圣礼的功效更加充满信心，从心底倾注了接下来的感恩，用停顿的音调大胆而胜利地说出了这句话，当她的心在讲话时，她的声音就获得了这种效果。 ，认识她的人永远不会忘记。信仰的狂喜几乎使她神化。它在她的脸上发出了耀眼的光芒，在脸颊中央留下了一个红点。而她眼眸中倒映的微型烛火，则闪烁着钻石般的光芒。孩子们抬头看她的目光越来越敬畏，不再有询问的意思。现在在他们看来，她不再像茜茜，而是一个高大、高耸、可怕的人物——一个与他们毫无共同之处的神圣人物。

Poor Sorrow’s campaign against sin, the world, and the devil was doomed to be of limited brilliancy—luckily perhaps for himself, considering his beginnings. In the blue of the morning that fragile soldier and servant breathed his last, and when the other children awoke they cried bitterly, and begged Sissy to have another pretty baby.
可怜的悲伤对抗罪恶、世界和魔鬼的运动注定不会有辉煌——考虑到他的出身，也许对他来说是幸运的。在蓝色的早晨，那个脆弱的士兵和仆人咽下了最后一口气，当其他孩子醒来时，他们痛哭流涕，恳求茜茜再再生一个漂亮的孩子。

The calmness which had possessed Tess since the christening remained with her in the infant’s loss. In the daylight, indeed, she felt her terrors about his soul to have been somewhat exaggerated; whether well founded or not, she had no uneasiness now, reasoning that if Providence would not ratify such an act of approximation she, for one, did not value the kind of heaven lost by the irregularity—either for herself or for her child.
苔丝自洗礼以来一直保持的平静在失去婴儿后依然存在。事实上，在白天，她觉得自己对他灵魂的恐惧有些夸大了。无论是否有根据，她现在都没有感到不安，她推断，如果上帝不批准这种近似行为，她就不会珍惜因这种不规则而失去的那种天堂——无论是对她自己还是对她的孩子。

So passed away Sorrow the Undesired—that intrusive creature, that bastard gift of shameless Nature, who respects not the social law; a waif to whom eternal Time had been a matter of days merely, who knew not that such things as years and centuries ever were; to whom the cottage interior was the universe, the week’s weather climate, new-born babyhood human existence, and the instinct to suck human knowledge.
就这样，“不受欢迎的悲伤”去世了——那个侵入性的生物，那个无耻的大自然的混蛋礼物，不尊重社会法则；对一个流浪者来说，永恒的时间只不过是几天的事，他不知道岁月和世纪之类的东西是存在的。对他们来说，小屋的内部就是宇宙、一周的天气气候、新生儿时期的人类存在，以及吸取人类知识的本能。

Tess, who mused on the christening a good deal, wondered if it were doctrinally sufficient to secure a Christian burial for the child. Nobody could tell this but the parson of the parish, and he was a new-comer, and did not know her. She went to his house after dusk, and stood by the gate, but could not summon courage to go in. The enterprise would have been abandoned if she had not by accident met him coming homeward as she turned away. In the gloom she did not mind speaking freely.
苔丝对洗礼进行了很多思考，想知道在教义上是否足以确保为孩子举行基督教葬礼。除了教区的牧师外，没有人知道这一点，他是新来的，不认识她。黄昏后，她去了他家，站在门口，却鼓不起勇气进去。若不是她转身时无意中遇见了他回家的路，事业就泡汤了。在黑暗中她不介意畅所欲言。

‘I should like to ask you something, sir.’
“我想问你一件事，先生。”

He expressed his willingness to listen, and she told the story of the baby’s illness and the extemporized ordinance. ‘And now, sir,’ she added earnestly, ‘can you tell me this—will it be just the same for him as if you had baptized him?’
他表示愿意听，她则讲述了婴儿的病情和临时法令的故事。 “现在，先生，”她认真地补充道，“您能告诉我这一点吗？对他来说，这会像您为他施洗一样吗？”

Having the natural feelings of a tradesman at finding that a job he should have been called in for had been unskilfully botched by his customers among themselves, he was disposed to say no. Yet the dignity of the girl, the strange tenderness in her voice, combined to affect his nobler impulses—or rather those that he had left in him after ten years of endeavour to graft technical belief on actual scepticism. The man and the ecclesiastic fought within him, and the victory fell to the man.
作为一个商人，当他发现自己应该接受的工作被他的顾客之间不熟练地搞砸了时，他会自然而然地拒绝。然而，这个女孩的尊严，她声音中奇怪的温柔，结合起来影响了他更高尚的冲动——或者更确切地说，是他在十年努力将技术信仰移植到实际怀疑论之后留在他身上的那些冲动。人和教会在他内心进行斗争，最后胜利落在了男人身上。

‘My dear girl,’ he said, ‘it will be just the same.’
“我亲爱的女孩，”他说，“一切都会一样。”

‘Then will you give him a Christian burial?’ she asked quickly.
“那么你会给他举行基督教葬礼吗？”她很快问道。

The Vicar felt himself cornered. Hearing of the baby’s illness, he had conscientiously gone to the house after nightfall to perform the rite, and, unaware that the refusal to admit him had come from Tess’s father and not from Tess, he could not allow the plea of necessity for its irregular administration.
牧师感到自己被逼到了绝境。听说孩子生病了，夜幕降临后，他就认真地去家里举行了仪式，而且，他没有意识到拒绝接纳他的决定是苔丝的父亲而不是苔丝本人提出的，他不能允许以紧急情况为由的抗辩。行政。

‘Ah—that’s another matter,’ he said.
“啊——那是另一回事了，”他说。

‘Another matter—why?’ asked Tess, rather warmly.
“另一件事——为什么？”苔丝相当热情地问道。

‘Well—I would willingly do so if only we two were concerned. But I must not—for certain reasons.’
“好吧——只要我们两个担心的话，我很乐意这样做。但出于某些原因，我不能这样做。

‘Just for once, sir!’
“就一次，先生！”

‘Really I must not.’
“我真的不能。”

‘O sir!’ She seized his hand as she spoke.
“哦，先生！”她边说边抓住他的手。

He withdrew it, shaking his head.
他收回手，摇摇头。

‘Then I don’t like you!’ she burst out, ‘and I’ll never come to your church no more!’
“那我就不喜欢你了！”她大声说道，“我再也不会来你的教堂了！”

‘Don’t talk so rashly.’
「别说话这么鲁莽。」

‘Perhaps it will be just the same to him if you don’t? ... Will it be just the same? Don’t for God’s sake speak as saint to sinner, but as you yourself to me myself—poor me!’
‘如果你不这么做的话，也许对他来说也是一样的吧？ ……会一样吗？看在上帝的份上，不要像圣人一样对罪人说话，而要像你自己一样对我自己说话——可怜的我！

How the Vicar reconciled his answer with the strict notions he supposed himself to hold on these subjects it is beyond a layman’s power to tell, though not to excuse. Somewhat moved, he said in this case also—
牧师如何将他的回答与他认为自己对这些主题持有的严格观念相一致，这超出了外行人的能力，但不能原谅。他有些感动，在这种情况下也说道——

‘It will be just the same.’
“一切都会一样。”

So the baby was carried in a small deal box, under an ancient woman’s shawl, to the churchyard that night, and buried by lantern-light, at the cost of a shilling and a pint of beer to the sexton, in that shabby corner of God’s allotment where He lets the nettles grow, and where all unbaptized infants, notorious drunkards, suicides, and others of the conjecturally damned are laid. In spite of the untoward surroundings, however, Tess bravely made a little cross of two laths and a piece of string, and having bound it with flowers, she stuck it up at the head of the grave one evening when she could enter the churchyard without being seen, putting at the foot also a bunch of the same flowers in a little jar of water to keep them alive. What matter was it that on the outside of the jar the eye of mere observation noted the words ‘Keelwell’s Marmalade’? The eye of maternal affection did not see them in its vision of higher things.
于是，那天晚上，婴儿被装在一个小盒子里，盖着一位古代妇女的披肩，带到了教堂墓地，在灯笼的灯光下埋葬了，费用是给教堂司事一先令和一品脱啤酒，埋葬在教堂那个破旧的角落里。上帝让荨麻生长的地方，所有未受洗的婴儿、臭名昭著的酒鬼、自杀者和其他被推测该受诅咒的人都被埋葬的地方。然而，尽管环境恶劣，苔丝还是勇敢地用两块板条和一根绳子做了一个小十字架，并用鲜花把它绑起来，有一天晚上，当她可以不费力地进入墓地时，她把它插在坟墓的顶端。被看到后，还在脚下放了一束同样的花，放在一个小罐子里，让它们保持活力。仅仅观察的眼睛就注意到罐子外面写着“基尔韦尔果酱”，这有什么关系呢？母爱之眼并没有以更高尚的眼光看待他们。

XV

‘By experience,’ says Roger Ascham, ‘we find out a short way by a long wandering.’ Not seldom that long wandering unfits us for further travel, and of what use is our experience to us then? Tess Durbeyfield’s experience was of this incapacitating kind. At last she had learned what to do; but who would now accept her doing?
罗杰·阿沙姆说：“根据经验，我们通过长途跋涉找到了一条捷径。”长途跋涉常常使我们不适合进一步旅行，那么我们的经验对我们有什么用呢？苔丝·德北菲尔德的经历就是这种令人丧失能力的经历。她终于知道该做什么了。但现在谁会接受她的做法呢？

If before going to the d’Urbervilles’ she had vigorously moved under the guidance of sundry gnomic texts and phrases known to her and to the world in general, no doubt she would never have been imposed on. But it had not been in Tess’s power—nor is it in anybody’s power—to feel the whole truth of golden opinions while it is possible to profit by them. She—and how many more—might have ironically said to God with Saint Augustine: ‘Thou hast counselled a better course than Thou hast permitted.’
如果在去德伯维尔之前，她在她和全世界都知道的各种格言文本和短语的指导下积极行动，毫无疑问，她永远不会被强加。但苔丝没有能力——也没有人有能力——去感受金科玉律的全部真理，同时也有可能从中获利。她——还有多少人——可能会和圣奥古斯丁一样讽刺地对上帝说：“你所建议的做法比你所允许的更好。”

She remained at her father’s house during the winter months, plucking fowls, or cramming turkeys and geese, or making clothes for her sisters and brothers out of some finery which d’Urberville had given her, and she had put by with contempt. Apply to him she would not. But she would often clasp her hands behind her head and muse when she was supposed to be working hard.
冬天的几个月里，她留在父亲家里，拔禽类的毛，或者塞满火鸡和鹅，或者用德伯维尔给她的一些华丽衣服为她的兄弟姐妹做衣服，而她却轻蔑地搁置了。她不会向他申请。但当她应该努力工作时，她常常会双手抱在脑后沉思。

She philosophically noted dates as they came past in the revolution of the year; the disastrous night of her undoing at Trantridge with its dark background of The Chase; also the dates of the baby’s birth and death; also her own birthday; and every other day individualized by incidents in which she had taken some share. She suddenly thought one afternoon, when looking in the glass at her fairness, that there was yet another date, of greater importance to her than those; that of her own death, when all these charms would have disappeared; a day which lay sly and unseen among all the other days of the year, giving no sign or sound when she annually passed over it; but not the less surely there. When was it? Why did she not feel the chill of each yearly encounter with such a cold relation? She had Jeremy Taylor’s thought that some time in the future those who had known her would say: ‘It is the ——th, the day that poor Tess Durbeyfield died”; and there would be nothing singular to their minds in the statement. Of that day, doomed to be her terminus in time through all the ages, she did not know the place in month, week, season or year.
她哲学地记录了当年革命中过去的日期；在《追逐》的黑暗背景下，她在特兰特里奇遭遇灾难性的夜晚；还有婴儿的出生和死亡日期；还有她自己的生日；每隔一天，她都会参与一些事件。一天下午，当她看着镜子里自己的白皙肌肤时，她突然想到，还有另一个约会，对她来说比这两个约会更重要；当所有这些魅力都消失时，她自己就会死去；在一年中的所有其他日子中，这一天是狡猾地、看不见的，当她每年经过它时，没有任何迹象或声音。但同样肯定的是。那是什么时候？为何每年遇到如此冷漠的亲人，她却没有感受到一丝寒意？她有杰里米·泰勒的想法，在未来的某个时候，那些认识她的人会说：“这是可怜的苔丝·德北菲尔德去世的那天”；他们的说法中并没有什么奇怪的地方。那一天，注定是她千古时光的终点站，她不知道是月、周、季还是年。

Almost at a leap Tess thus changed from simple girl to complex woman. Symbols of reflectiveness passed into her face, and a note of tragedy at times into her voice. Her eyes grew larger and more eloquent. She became what would have been called a fine creature; her aspect was fair and arresting; her soul that of a woman whom the turbulent experiences of the last year or two had quite failed to demoralize. But for the world’s opinion those experiences would have been simply a liberal education.
苔丝几乎一下子就从单纯的女孩变成了复杂的女人。她的脸上流露出深思熟虑的表情，声音里有时也透着一丝悲剧色彩。她的眼睛变得更大，更有神情。她成了所谓的优秀人物。她的外表美丽而引人注目。她的灵魂是一个女人，过去一两年的动荡经历并没有使她士气低落。但在世人看来，这些经历只不过是一种通识教育。

She had held so aloof of late that her trouble, never generally known, was nearly forgotten in Marlott. But it became evident to her that she could never be really comfortable again in a place which had seen the collapse of her family’s attempt to ‘claim kin’—and, through her, even closer union—with the rich d’Urbervilles. At least she could not be comfortable there till long years should have obliterated her keen consciousness of it. Yet even now Tess felt the pulse of hopeful life still warm within her; she might be happy in some nook which had no memories. To escape the past and all that appertained thereto was to annihilate it, and to do that she would have to get away.
她最近表现得如此冷漠，以至于她的麻烦几乎被马洛特遗忘了，而她的麻烦从未被普遍所知。但对她来说，很明显的是，她再也无法在这个地方真正感到舒服了，因为她的家人试图与富有的德伯维尔“夺回亲缘”——并通过她建立更紧密的结合——的努力失败了。至少，在漫长的岁月磨灭了她对这里的敏锐意识之前，她在那里不会感到舒服。然而，即使是现在，苔丝仍感到她内心充满希望的生活的脉搏。她也许会在某个没有记忆的角落里感到幸福。要逃避过去以及与之相关的一切，就必须消灭它，而要做到这一点，她就必须离开。

Was once lost always lost really true of chastity? she would ask herself. She might prove it false if she could veil bygones. The recuperative power which pervaded organic nature was surely not denied to maidenhood alone.
一旦失去就永远失去贞操真的是真的吗？她会问自己。如果她能掩盖过去的事情，她可能会证明这是错误的。自然并不仅仅具有少女时期所具有的恢复能力。

She waited a long time without finding opportunity for a new departure. A particularly fine spring came round, and the stir of germination was almost audible in the buds; it moved her, as it moved the wild animals, and made her passionate to go. At last, one day in early May, a letter reached her from a former friend of her mother’s, to whom she had addressed inquiries long before—a person whom she had never seen—that a skilful milkmaid was required at a dairy-house many miles to the southward, and that the dairyman would be glad to have her for the summer months.
她等了很久，都没有找到重新出发的机会。一个特别好的春天来了，几乎可以听到花蕾中发芽的声音。它感动了她，就像感动了野生动物一样，让她充满了前往的热情。最后，五月初的一天，她收到了一封来自她母亲的前朋友的信，她很久以前就向这位朋友询问过——一个她从未见过的人——说许多奶牛场都需要一名熟练的挤奶女工。向南数英里，奶牛场老板会很高兴拥有她度过夏季。

It was not quite so far off as could have been wished; but it was probably far enough, her radius of movement and repute having been so small. To persons of limited spheres, miles are as geographical degrees, parishes as counties, counties as provinces and kingdoms.
这并不像人们所希望的那么遥远。但也许已经足够远了，她的活动半径和名声都很小。对于范围有限的人来说，英里相当于地理等级，教区相当于县，县相当于省和王国。

On one point she was resolved: there should be no more d’Urberville air-castles in the dreams and deeds of her new life. She would be the dairymaid Tess, and nothing more. Her mother knew Tess’s feeling on this point so well, though no words had passed between them on the subject, that she never alluded to the knightly ancestry now.
有一次，她下定决心：她新生活的梦想和行动中不应该再有德伯维尔空中城堡。她将是挤奶女工苔丝，仅此而已。她的母亲非常了解苔丝在这一点上的感受，尽管他们之间没有就这个问题说过话，所以她现在从未提及过骑士血统。

Yet such is human inconsistency that one of the interests of the new place to her was the accidental virtues of its lying near her forefathers’ country (for they were not Blakemore men, though her mother was Blakemore to the bone). The dairy called Talbothays, for which she was bound, stood not remotely from some of the former estates of the d’Urbervilles, near the great family vaults of her granddames and their powerful husbands. She would be able to look at them, and think not only that d’Urberville, like Babylon, had fallen, but that the individual innocence of a humble descendant could lapse as silently. All the while she wondered if any strange good thing might come of her being in her ancestral land; and some spirit within her rose automatically as the sap in the twigs. It was unexpected youth, surging up anew after its temporary check, and bringing with it hope, and the invincible instinct towards self-delight.
然而，人类的矛盾性是如此之大，以至于新地方对她的兴趣之一是它位于她祖先的国家附近的偶然优点（因为他们不是布莱克莫尔人，尽管她的母亲骨子里是布莱克莫尔人）。她要去的那家名叫塔尔博塞斯的乳品厂，距离德伯维尔家族的一些前庄园不远，靠近她的祖母和她们有权势的丈夫的大家族金库。她看着它们，不仅会想到德伯维尔像巴比伦一样已经沦陷，而且一个卑微后裔的个人纯真也可能会悄无声息地消失。她一直在想，如果她来到祖传的土地上，会不会有什么奇怪的好事呢？她内心的某种精神就像树枝中的汁液一样自动升腾。这是出人意料的青春，在暂时的抑制之后重新勃发，带来了希望，以及不可战胜的自我愉悦的本能。

END OF PHASE THE SECOND
第二阶段结束

Phase the Third: The Rally
第三阶段：集会

XVI
十六

On a thyme-scented, bird-hatching morning in May, between two and three years after the return from Trantridge—silent, reconstructive years for Tess Durbeyfield—she left her home for the second time.
五月的一个百里香芬芳、鸟儿孵化的早晨，也就是从特兰特里奇回来两三年后——对于苔丝·德北菲尔德来说，这是安静的、重建的岁月——她第二次离开了家。

Having packed up her luggage so that it could be sent to her later, she started in a hired trap for the little town of Stourcastle, through which it was necessary to pass on her journey, now in a direction almost opposite to that of her first adventuring. On the curve of the nearest hill she looked back regretfully at Marlott and her father’s house, although she had been so anxious to get away.
收拾好行李以便稍后寄给她后，她开始在一个租用的陷阱中前往斯托卡斯尔小镇，她的旅程必须经过这个小镇，现在的方向几乎与她第一次的方向相反冒险。在最近的山坡上，她遗憾地回头看了看马洛特和她父亲的房子，尽管她一直渴望离开。

Her kindred dwelling there would probably continue their daily lives as heretofore, with no great diminution of pleasure in their consciousness, although she would be far off, and they deprived of her smile. In a few days the children would engage in their games as merrily as ever, without the sense of any gap left by her departure. This leaving of the younger children she had decided to be for the best; were she to remain they would probably gain less good by her precepts than harm by her example.
她的亲人住在那里，很可能会像以前一样继续他们的日常生活，尽管她离得很远，他们也失去了她的微笑，但他们意识中的快乐并没有大大减少。几天后，孩子们就会像以前一样快乐地玩游戏，丝毫感觉不到她的离开留下的任何间隙。她决定离开年幼的孩子是为了最好的结果。如果她留下来，他们从她的戒律中获得的好处可能会比她的榜样带来的伤害更大。

She went through Stourcastle without pausing and onward to a junction of highways, where she could await a carrier’s van that ran to the south-west; for the railways which engirdled this interior tract of country had never yet struck across it. While waiting, however, there came along a farmer in his spring cart, driving approximately in the direction that she wished to pursue. Though he was a stranger to her she accepted his offer of a seat beside him, ignoring that its motive was a mere tribute to her countenance. He was going to Weatherbury, and by accompanying him thither she could walk the remainder of the distance instead of travelling in the van by way of Casterbridge.
她没有停下来，穿过斯图尔卡斯尔，继续前往高速公路的交汇处，在那里她可以等待一辆向西南方向行驶的运输车。因为环绕这片内陆地区的铁路从未穿越过它。然而，在等待的时候，一位农夫驾着春车走过来，大约朝着她要追寻的方向行驶。尽管他对她来说是个陌生人，但她接受了他在他旁边的座位，忽略了其动机仅仅是为了向她的面容致敬。他要去威瑟伯里，只要陪他去那里，她就可以步行走完剩下的路程，而不必乘坐面包车取道卡斯特桥。

Tess did not stop at Weatherbury, after this long drive, further than to make a slight nondescript meal at noon at a cottage to which the farmer recommended her. Thence she started on foot, basket in hand, to reach the wide upland of heath dividing this district from the low-lying meads of a further valley in which the dairy stood that was the aim and end of her day’s pilgrimage.
经过这么长的车程，苔丝并没有在威瑟伯里停留，只是中午在农夫推荐她去的一间小屋里吃了一顿普普通通的饭菜。从那里，她提着篮子开始步行，到达广阔的石南高地，该高地将这个地区与另一个山谷的低洼草地分开，那里的奶牛场就是她一天朝圣的目标和终点。

Tess had never before visited this part of the country, and yet she felt akin to the landscape. Not so very far to the left of her she could discern a dark patch in the scenery, which inquiry confirmed her in supposing to be trees marking the environs of Kingsbere—in the church of which parish the bones of her ancestors—her useless ancestors—lay entombed.
苔丝以前从未去过这个国家的这个地区，但她对这里的风景感到很熟悉。在她左边不远的地方，她可以看到风景中的一块黑斑，这一询问证实了她认为是标记金斯比尔周围的树木——在这个教区的教堂里，有她祖先的骨头——她无用的祖先——埋葬了。

She had no admiration for them now; she almost hated them for the dance they had led her; not a thing of all that had been theirs did she retain but the old seal and spoon. ‘Pooh—I have as much of mother as father in me!’ she said. ‘All my prettiness comes from her, and she was only a dairymaid.’
她现在对他们不再钦佩了。她几乎恨他们带领她跳舞。除了旧印章和勺子之外，她没有保留任何曾经属于他们的东西。 “呸——我身上既有父亲的影子，也有母亲的影子！”她说。 “我所有的美丽都来自于她，而她只是一个挤奶女工。”

The journey over the intervening uplands and lowlands of Egdon, when she reached them, was a more troublesome walk than she had anticipated, the distance being actually but a few miles. It was two hours, owing to sundry wrong turnings, ere she found herself on a summit commanding the long-sought-for vale, the Valley of the Great Dairies, the valley in which milk and butter grew to rankness, and were produced more profusely, if less delicately, than at her home—the verdant plain so well watered by the river Var or Froom.
当她到达埃格顿时，要穿过中间的高地和低地，这比她预想的要困难得多，距离实际上只有几英里。由于各种错误的转弯，花了两个小时，她才发现自己到达了山顶，俯瞰着一直以来寻找的山谷，伟大的乳制品山谷，牛奶和黄油在这个山谷中变得发臭，并且生产得更加丰富。 ，虽然不那么精致，但比在她的家——瓦尔河或弗鲁姆河灌溉的青翠平原。

It was intrinsically different from the Vale of Little Dairies, Blackmoor Vale, which, save during her disastrous sojourn at Trantridge, she had exclusively known till now. The world was drawn to a larger pattern here. The enclosures numbered fifty acres instead of ten, the farmsteads were more extended, the groups of cattle formed tribes hereabout; there only families. These myriads of cows stretching under her eyes from the far east to the far west outnumbered any she had ever seen at one glance before. The green lea was speckled as thickly with them as a canvas by Van Alsloot or Sallaert with burghers. The ripe hue of the red and dun kine absorbed the evening sunlight, which the white-coated animals returned to the eye in rays almost dazzling, even at the distant elevation on which she stood.
它与小乳品谷、布莱克摩尔谷有本质上的不同，除了她在特兰特里奇灾难性的逗留期间，她到现在为止都只知道布莱克摩尔谷。世界被这里更大的格局所吸引。围场的面积从十英亩变成了五十英亩，农庄更加广阔，牛群在附近形成了部落。只有家庭。这些无数的牛在她的眼前从远东延伸到远西，数量比她以前见过的任何牛都要多。绿色的草坪上布满了他们，就像范·阿尔斯洛特或萨拉特的画布上布满了市民一样。红色和暗褐色的牛的成熟色调吸收了傍晚的阳光，白色皮毛的动物以几乎令人眼花缭乱的光线返回眼睛，即使在她所站的远处高处也是如此。

The bird’s-eye perspective before her was not so luxuriantly beautiful, perhaps, as that other one which she knew so well; yet it was more cheering. It lacked the intensely blue atmosphere of the rival vale, and its heavy soils and scents; the new air was clear, bracing, ethereal. The river itself, which nourished the grass and cows of these renowned dairies, flowed not like the streams in Blackmoor. Those were slow, silent, often turbid; flowing over beds of mud into which the incautious wader might sink and vanish unawares. The Froom waters were clear as the pure River of Life shown to the Evangelist, rapid as the shadow of a cloud, with pebbly shallows that prattled to the sky all day long. There the water-flower was the lily; the crow-foot here.
也许，她面前的鸟瞰图并不像她熟悉的另一幅那样华丽美丽。但更令人欢呼雀跃。这里没有竞争对手山谷那样深蓝色的气氛，也没有厚重的土壤和气味。新的空气清澈、令人振奋、空灵。这条河本身滋养了这些著名乳品厂的草和奶牛，但它的流动与布莱克莫尔的溪流不同。那些声音缓慢、安静、常常浑浊；流过泥床，不小心涉水的人可能会不知不觉地沉入泥床并消失。弗鲁姆河的河水清澈，就像福音传教士所看到的纯净的生命之河，水流如云影般急流，卵石浅滩整天哗啦啦地响到天空。那里的水花是百合；这里的鱼尾纹。

Either the change in the quality of the air from heavy to light, or the sense of being amid new scenes where there were no invidious eyes upon her, sent up her spirits wonderfully. Her hopes mingled with the sunshine in an ideal photosphere which surrounded her as she bounded along against the soft south wind. She heard a pleasant voice in every breeze, and in every bird’s note seemed to lurk a joy.
无论是空气质量从沉重变得轻盈的变化，还是置身于新场景中的感觉，没有敌意的目光注视着她，都让她精神振奋。当她顶着柔和的南风前进时，她的希望与理想的光球层中的阳光融为一体，围绕着她。每一阵微风中，她都听到悦耳的声音，每一声鸟鸣中似乎都潜藏着欢乐。

Her face had latterly changed with changing states of mind, continually fluctuating between beauty and ordinariness, according as the thoughts were gay or grave. One day she was pink and flawless; another pale and tragical. When she was pink she was feeling less than when pale; her more perfect beauty accorded with her less elevated mood; her more intense mood with her less perfect beauty. It was her best face physically that was now set against the south wind.
她的面容随着心境的变化而变化，随着思想的欢快或严肃，不断地在美丽与平凡之间波动。有一天，她变成了粉红色，完美无瑕；另一个苍白而悲惨。当她呈粉红色时，她的感觉比苍白时要少。她更加完美的美丽与她不那么高涨的情绪相一致。她的情绪更加强烈，但她的美貌却不太完美。现在，迎着南风的是她身体最好的脸。

The irresistible, universal, automatic tendency to find sweet pleasure somewhere, which pervades all life, from the meanest to the highest, had at length mastered Tess. Being even now only a young woman of twenty, one who mentally and sentimentally had not finished growing, it was impossible that any event should have left upon her an impression that was not in time capable of transmutation.
苔丝有一种不可抗拒的、普遍的、自动的倾向，即在某个地方寻找甜蜜的快乐，这种倾向遍及所有的生活，从最卑微的到最高贵的，最终控制了苔丝。现在她还只是一个二十岁的年轻女子，精神上和情感上都还没有完成成长，任何事情都不可能给她留下不及时转变的印象。

And thus her spirits, and her thankfulness, and her hopes, rose higher and higher. She tried several ballads, but found them inadequate; till, recollecting the psalter that her eyes had so often wandered over of a Sunday morning before she had eaten of the tree of knowledge, she chanted: ‘O ye Sun and Moon ... O ye Stars ... ye Green Things upon the Earth ... ye Fowls of the Air ... Beasts and Cattle ... Children of Men ... bless ye the Lord, praise Him and magnify Him for ever!’
因此，她的精神、她的感恩、她的希望越来越高。她尝试了几首民谣，但发现都不够。直到，回忆起周日早上她在吃知识之树之前经常浏览的诗篇，她吟诵道：“太阳和月亮啊……星星啊……地球上的绿色事物”地球……你们空中的飞禽……野兽和牛……人类之子……你们赞美主，赞美他并永远尊崇他！

She suddenly stopped and murmured: ‘But perhaps I don’t quite know the Lord as yet.’
她突然停了下来，低声说道：“但也许我还不太认识主。”

And probably the half-unconscious rhapsody was a Fetishistic utterance in a Monotheistic setting; women whose chief companions are the forms and forces of outdoor Nature retain in their souls far more of the Pagan fantasy of their remote forefathers than of the systematized religion taught their race at later date. However, Tess found at least approximate expression for her feelings in the old Benedicite that she had lisped from infancy; and it was enough. Such high contentment with such a slight initial performance as that of having started towards a means of independent living was a part of the Durbeyfield temperament. Tess really wished to walk uprightly, while her father did nothing of the kind; but she resembled him in being content with immediate and small achievements, and in having no mind for laborious effort towards such petty social advancement as could alone be effected by a family so heavily handicapped as the once powerful d’Urbervilles were now.
也许半无意识的狂想曲是一神论背景下的拜物教话语；那些以户外自然的形式和力量为主要伴侣的女性，她们的灵魂中保留的远古祖先的异教幻想，远多于后来教导她们的种族的系统化宗教。然而，苔丝至少在她从小就口齿不清的老本尼迪克特语中找到了对她感情的近似表达。这就足够了。对开始独立生活这样轻微的初步表现感到如此高的满足感是德北菲尔德气质的一部分。苔丝真心希望能够直立行走，而她的父亲却没有这样做。但她与他相似，满足于眼前的小成就，不介意为这种微不足道的社会进步而付出艰苦的努力，而这种进步只能由像曾经强大的德伯维尔家族这样严重残疾的家庭才能实现。

There was, it might be said, the energy of her mother’s unexpended family, as well as the natural energy of Tess’s years, rekindled after the experience which had so overwhelmed her for the time. Let the truth be told—women do as a rule live through such humiliations, and regain their spirits, and again look about them with an interested eye. While there’s life there’s hope is a conviction not so entirely unknown to the ‘betrayed’ as some amiable theorists would have us believe.
可以说，她母亲未曾消耗的家庭的能量，以及苔丝岁月的自然能量，在经历了当时让她不知所措的经历后重新点燃。说实话——女人通常会经历这样的羞辱，然后恢复精神，并再次用感兴趣的眼光环顾四周。生命虽有希望，但“被背叛者”并不像一些和蔼可亲的理论家让我们相信的那样完全不知道这一信念。

Tess Durbeyfield, then, in good heart, and full of zest for life, descended the Egdon slopes lower and lower towards the dairy of her pilgrimage.
苔丝·德北菲尔德怀着一颗善良的心，对生活充满热情，沿着埃格顿山坡走下越来越低的山坡，朝她朝圣的奶牛场走去。

The marked difference, in the final particular, between the rival vales now showed itself. The secret of Blackmoor was best discovered from the heights around; to read aright the valley before her it was necessary to descend into its midst. When Tess had accomplished this feat she found herself to be standing on a carpeted level, which stretched to the east and west as far as the eye could reach.
在最后的细节中，竞争对手之间的显着差异现在已经显现出来。布莱克莫尔的秘密最好从周围的高处发现。为了正确地阅读她面前的山谷，就必须深入其中。当苔丝完成这一壮举时，她发现自己站在一块铺着地毯的平面上，向东和向西延伸到视线所及之处。

The river had stolen from the higher tracts and brought in particles to the vale all this horizontal land; and now, exhausted, aged, and attenuated, lay serpentining along through the midst of its former spoils.
河流从地势较高的地区偷走，将颗粒带入山谷中的所有水平土地；现在，精疲力竭、衰老、衰弱的它蜿蜒地躺在以前的战利品中间。

Not quite sure of her direction, Tess stood still upon the hemmed expanse of verdant flatness, like a fly on a billiard-table of indefinite length, and of no more consequence to the surroundings than that fly. The sole effect of her presence upon the placid valley so far had been to excite the mind of a solitary heron, which, after descending to the ground not far from her path, stood with neck erect, looking at her.
苔丝不太确定自己的方向，一动不动地站在那片青翠平坦的土地上，就像台球桌上的一只苍蝇，长度不定，对周围环境的影响并不比那只苍蝇更大。到目前为止，她出现在平静的山谷中的唯一效果就是激发了一只孤独的苍鹭的思想，这只苍鹭降落到离她的路径不远的地面后，竖起脖子站着，看着她。

Suddenly there arose from all parts of the lowland a prolonged and repeated call—‘Waow! waow! waow!’
突然，低地各处响起了一声绵长而重复的叫声——‘哇！哇！哇哦！’

From the furthest east to the furthest west the cries spread as if by contagion, accompanied in some cases by the barking of a dog. It was not the expression of the valley’s consciousness that beautiful Tess had arrived, but the ordinary announcement of milking-time—half-past four o’clock, when the dairymen set about getting in the cows.
从最东边到最西边，哭声像传染病一样蔓延开来，有时还伴有狗叫声。美丽的苔丝到来并不是山谷意识的表现，而是挤奶时间的普通宣告——四点半，挤奶工们开始挤奶牛的时候。

The red and white herd nearest at hand, which had been phlegmatically waiting for the call, now trooped towards the steading in the background, their great bags of milk swinging under them as they walked. Tess followed slowly in their rear, and entered the barton by the open gate through which they had entered before her. Long thatched sheds stretched round the enclosure, their slopes encrusted with vivid green moss, and their eaves supported by wooden posts rubbed to a glossy smoothness by the flanks of infinite cows and calves of bygone years, now passed to an oblivion almost inconceivable in its profundity. Between the post were ranged the milchers, each exhibiting herself at the present moment to a whimsical eye in the rear as a circle on two stalks, down the centre of which a switch moved pendulum-wise; while the sun, lowering itself behind this patient row, threw their shadows accurately inwards upon the wall. Thus it threw shadows of these obscure and homely figures every evening with as much care over each contour as if it had been the profile of a court beauty on a palace wall; copied them as diligently as it had copied Olympian shapes on marble façades long ago, or the outline of Alexander, Caesar, and the Pharaohs.
近在咫尺的红白相间的牛群一直在冷漠地等待召唤，现在成群结队地朝后面的马厩走去，大袋子的牛奶在它们行走时在身下摇摆。苔丝慢慢地跟在他们后面，从他们在她前面进来的那扇敞开的门进入了巴顿。长长的茅草棚在围场周围延伸，它们的斜坡上覆盖着鲜艳的绿色苔藓，它们的屋檐由木柱支撑，被过去岁月里无数的母牛和小牛的侧面摩擦得光滑光滑，现在已经被遗忘了，其深度几乎是不可想象的。立柱之间排列着挤奶工，每个挤奶工现在都在后面异想天开的眼睛面前展示自己，就像两根茎上的一个圆圈，在茎的中心有一个开关以钟摆的方式移动。而太阳则在这耐心的行列后面落下，将它们的影子准确地投向内侧的墙上。因此，每天晚上，它都会在每一个轮廓上投射出这些不起眼而朴素的人物的影子，就像宫墙上宫廷美人的侧影一样。就像很久以前在大理石外墙上复制奥林匹亚形状或亚历山大、凯撒和法老的轮廓一样勤奋地复制它们。

They were the less restful cows that were stalled. Those that would stand still of their own will were milked in the middle of the yard, where many of such better behaved ones stood waiting now—all prime milchers, such as were seldom seen out of this valley, and not always within it; nourished by the succulent feed which the water-meads supplied at this prime season of the year. Those of them that were spotted with white reflected the sunshine in dazzling brilliancy, and the polished brass knobs of their horns glittered with something of military display. Their large-veined udders hung ponderous as sandbags, the teats sticking out like the legs of a gipsy’s crock; and as each animal lingered for her turn to arrive the milk oozed forth and fell in drops to the ground.
它们是被圈养的不太安宁的奶牛。那些愿意站着不动的奶工在院子中央挤奶，许多表现较好的奶工现在就站在那里等待——全都是顶级挤奶工，比如在这个山谷中很少见到的人，而且并不总是在山谷里；一年中的这个黄金季节，水草提供了多汁的饲料，为它们提供了营养。它们身上有白色斑点，在阳光下反射出耀眼的光彩，角上抛光的黄铜旋钮闪闪发光，散发着军事气息。她们的乳房血管粗大，像沙袋一样笨重地悬挂着，奶头像吉普赛瓦罐的腿一样伸出来。当每只动物都在等待轮到时，牛奶就会渗出，滴落到地上。

XVII
十七

The dairymaids and men had flocked down from their cottages and out of the dairy-house with the arrival of the cows from the meads; the maids walking in pattens, not on account of the weather, but to keep their shoes above the mulch of the barton. Each girl sat down on her three-legged stool, her face sideways, her right cheek resting against the cow, and looked musingly along the animal’s flank at Tess as she approached. The male milkers, with hat-brims turned down, resting flat on their foreheads and gazing on the ground, did not observe her.
随着来自草地的奶牛的到来，挤奶女工和男人们纷纷从小屋和奶牛场涌出。女仆们穿着帕滕斯走路，不是因为天气，而是为了让鞋子露出巴顿的覆盖物。每个女孩都坐在她的三脚凳上，脸侧向一边，右脸靠在牛身上，当苔丝走近时，她沿着牛的侧腹若有所思地看着她。挤奶工们帽子帽檐朝下，额头平放在地上，眼睛盯着地面，没有注意到她。

One of these was a sturdy middle-aged man—whose long white ‘pinner’ was somewhat finer and cleaner than the wraps of the others, and whose jacket underneath had a presentable marketing aspect—the master-dairyman, of whom she was in quest, his double character as a working milker and butter maker here during six days, and on the seventh as a man in shining broad-cloth in his family pew at church, being so marked as to have inspired a rhyme:
其中一个是一位身材魁梧的中年男子——他的长长的白色“领针”比其他人的裹布更精致、更干净，他里面的夹克有一种像样的营销风格——她正在寻找的奶牛大师，他的双重性格在六天里是一名挤奶工和黄油制造商，第七天则是穿着闪亮的宽布衣服坐在教堂的家庭长椅上，如此明显，以至于激发了一首押韵：

Dairyman Dick
奶牛场迪克

All the week:—
整周：—

On Sundays Mister Richard Crick.
周日理查德·克里克先生。

Seeing Tess standing at gaze he went across to her.
看到苔丝站在那里注视着他，他走到她身边。

The majority of dairymen have a cross manner at milking time, but it happened that Mr Crick was glad to get a new hand—for the days were busy ones now—and he received her warmly; inquiring for her mother and the rest of the family—(though this as a matter of form merely, for in reality he had not been aware of Mrs Durbeyfield’s existence till apprised of the fact by a brief business-letter about Tess).
大多数奶牛场老板在挤奶时都会表现得脾气暴躁，但碰巧克里克先生很高兴得到一个新帮手——因为现在日子很忙——他热情地接待了她；询问她母亲和其他家庭成员的情况——（尽管这只是一个形式问题，因为事实上，他直到通过一封关于苔丝的简短商业信函才知道德北菲尔德夫人的存在）。

‘Oh—ay, as a lad I knowed your part o’ the country very well,’ he said terminatively. ‘Though I’ve never been there since. And a aged woman of ninety that use to live nigh here, but is dead and gone long ago, told me that a family of some such name as yours in Blackmoor Vale came originally from these parts, and that ‘twere a old ancient race that had all but perished off the earth—though the new generations didn’t know it. But, Lord, I took no notice of the old woman’s ramblings, not I.’
“哦——哎呀，作为一个小伙子，我非常了解你所在的国家，”他最后说道。 “虽然从那以后我就再也没有去过那里。一位九十岁的老妇人曾经住在这附近，但很久以前就去世了，她告诉我，布莱克莫尔谷有一个像你这样的名字的家庭最初来自这些地区，那是一个古老的种族，几乎全部从地球上消失了——尽管新一代人并不知道这一点。但是，主啊，我没有注意到老妇人的胡言乱语，不是我自己。

‘Oh no—it is nothing,’ said Tess.
“哦，不——没什么，”苔丝说。

Then the talk was of business only.
然后谈话就只剩下生意了。

‘You can milk ‘em clean, my maidy? I don’t want my cows going azew at this time o’ year.’
“你能把它们挤干净吗，我的女仆？我不想让我的奶牛在每年的这个时候发呆。

She reassured him on that point, and he surveyed her up and down. She had been staying indoors a good deal, and her complexion had grown delicate.
她在这一点上向他保证，他上下打量着她。她长时间待在室内，脸色变得娇嫩。

‘Quite sure you can stand it? ‘Tis comfortable enough here for rough folk; but we don’t live in a cowcumber frame.’
‘你确定你能忍受吗？ “对于粗鲁的人来说，这里已经足够舒适了；但我们并不生活在一个牛角框架里。”

She declared that she could stand it, and her zest and willingness seemed to win him over.
她宣称她可以忍受，她的热情和意愿似乎赢得了他的支持。

‘Well, I suppose you’ll want a dish o’ tay, or victuals of some sort, hey? Not yet? Well, do as ye like about it. But faith, if ‘twas I, I should be as dry as a kex wi’ travelling so far.’
“好吧，我想你会想要一份泰式菜肴，或者某种食物，嘿？还没有？好吧，你喜欢怎么做就怎么做吧。但我相信，如果‘是我的话’，我应该会像一个 kex 一样干燥，旅行这么远。”

‘I’ll begin milking now, to get my hand in,’ said Tess.
“我现在就开始挤奶，把手伸进去，”苔丝说。

She drank a little milk as temporary refreshment—to the surprise—indeed, slight contempt—of Dairyman Crick, to whose mind it had apparently never occurred that milk was good as a beverage.
她喝了一点牛奶作为暂时的提神——这让奶牛场老板克里克感到惊讶——实际上是有点蔑视，在克里克看来，牛奶显然从来没有想过牛奶是一种很好的饮料。

‘Oh, if ye can swaller that, be it so,’ he said indifferently, while holding up the pail that she sipped from. ‘‘Tis what I hain’t touched for years—not I. Rot the stuff; it would lie in my innerds like lead. You can try your hand upon she,’ he pursued, nodding to the nearest cow. ‘Not but what she do milk rather hard. We’ve hard ones and we’ve easy ones, like other folks. However, you’ll find out that soon enough.’
“哦，如果你能咽下这个，那就这样吧，”他冷漠地说，同时举起了她喝的水桶。 “这就是我多年来没有碰过的东西——不是我。把这些东西腐烂；它会像铅一样埋藏在我的内心。你可以试试她，”他继续说道，并向最近的一头牛点点头。 “不是，但她挤奶的时候相当辛苦。”和其他人一样，我们有困难的事情，也有容易的事情。不过，你很快就会发现这一点。

When Tess had changed her bonnet for a hood, and was really on her stool under the cow, and the milk was squirting from her fists into the pail, she appeared to feel that she really had laid a new foundation for her future. The conviction bred serenity, her pulse slowed, and she was able to look about her.
当苔丝把帽子换成了头巾，真正坐在牛下面的凳子上，牛奶从她的拳头里喷到桶里时，她似乎觉得自己真的为自己的未来奠定了新的基础。这种信念使她平静下来，脉搏减慢，她能够环顾四周。

The milkers formed quite a little battalion of men and maids, the men operating on the hard-teated animals, the maids on the kindlier natures. It was a large dairy. There were nearly a hundred milchers under Crick’s management, all told; and of the herd the master-dairyman milked six or eight with his own hands, unless away from home. These were the cows that milked hardest of all; for his journey-milkmen being more or less casually hired, he would not entrust this half-dozen to their treatment, lest, from indifference, they should not milk them fully; nor to the maids, lest they should fail in the same way for lack of finger-grip; with the result that in course of time the cows would ‘go azew’—that is, dry up. It was not the loss for the moment that made slack milking so serious, but that with the decline of demand there came decline, and ultimately cessation, of supply.
挤奶工们组成了一个由男人和女仆组成的小营，男人们负责饲养坚硬的牲畜，女仆们负责善良的动物。那是一家大型乳品厂。克里克管理下的牛奶厂总共有近一百家。奶牛场大师亲手从牛群中挤奶六到八只，除非离家在外。这些奶牛挤奶最辛苦。因为他的旅途送奶工或多或少都是临时雇佣的，他不会把这六个人托付给他们，以免他们因为冷漠而无法充分挤奶。也不对女仆说，以免她们因缺乏手指的抓握而以同样的方式失败。结果，随着时间的推移，奶牛会“变得 azew”，即干涸。造成挤奶不足的原因并不是暂时的损失，而是随着需求的下降，供应也随之减少，并最终停止。

After Tess had settled down to her cow there was for a time no talk in the barton, and not a sound interfered with the purr of the milk-jets into the numerous pails, except a momentary exclamation to one or other of the beasts requesting her to turn round or stand still. The only movements were those of the milkers’ hands up and down, and the swing of the cows’ tails. Thus they all worked on, encompassed by the vast flat mead which extended to either slope of the valley—a level landscape compounded of old landscapes long forgotten, and, no doubt, differing in character very greatly from the landscape they composed now.
苔丝在她的奶牛身边安顿下来后，巴顿里有一段时间没有说话，没有任何声音干扰牛奶喷射到无数桶中的咕噜声，除了向一只或另一只请求她的野兽发出短暂的感叹。转身或站立不动。唯一的动作就是挤奶工的手上下移动，以及牛尾巴的摆动。就这样，他们都在工作，周围是一片广阔平坦的草地，一直延伸到山谷的两边——这是一片由早已被遗忘的古老风景组成的平坦景观，毫无疑问，在性质上与他们现在所组成的景观有很大不同。

‘To my thinking,’ said the dairyman, rising suddenly from a cow he had just finished off, snatching up his three-legged stool in one hand and the pail in the other, and moving on to the next hard-yielder in his vicinity, ‘to my thinking, the cows don’t gie down their milk to-day as usual. Upon my life, if Winker do begin keeping back like this, she’ll not be worth going under by midsummer.’
“据我所知，”奶牛场老板说，他突然从一头刚吃完的奶牛身上站起来，一手抓起他的三足凳子，另一只手抓起桶，朝附近的下一个硬产者走去。 ”，“据我所知，奶牛今天没有像往常一样喝下牛奶。在我的一生中，如果温克真的开始像这样退缩，那么到仲夏节她就不值得被埋没了。

‘‘Tis because there’s a new hand come among us,’ said Jonathan Kail. ‘I’ve noticed such things afore.’
“这是因为我们中间来了一位新人，”乔纳森·凯尔说。 “我以前就注意到过这样的事情。”

‘To be sure. It may be so. I didn’t think o’t.’
'为了确定。也许是这样。我没想到。

‘I’ve been told that it goes up into their horns at such times,’ said a dairymaid.
“有人告诉我，这种时候它会升到它们的角上，”一位挤奶女工说。

‘Well, as to going up into their horns,’ replied Dairyman Crick dubiously, as though even witchcraft might be limited by anatomical possibilities, ‘I couldn’t say; I certainly could not. But as nott cows will keep it back as well as the horned ones, I don’t quite agree to it. Do ye know that riddle about the nott cows, Jonathan? Why do nott cows give less milk in a year than horned?’
“好吧，至于进入它们的角，”奶牛场老板克里克半信半疑地回答道，就好像巫术也可能受到解剖学可能性的限制一样，“我不能说；我当然不能。但由于非特牛会像有角的牛一样保留它，所以我不太同意它。乔纳森，你知道关于诺特牛的谜语吗？为什么奶牛一年的产奶量不比有角的奶牛少呢？

‘I don’t!’ interposed the milkmaid, ‘Why do they?’
“我不这么认为！”挤奶女工插嘴道，“他们为什么这么做呢？”

‘Because there bain’t so many of ‘em,’ said the dairyman. ‘Howsomever, these gam’sters do certainly keep back their milk to-day. Folks, we must lift up a stave or two—that’s the only cure for’t.’
“因为它们没有那么多，”奶牛场老板说。 “不过，这些赌徒今天确实保留了他们的牛奶。伙计们，我们必须举起一两根棍子——这是唯一的治疗方法。”

Songs were often resorted to in dairies hereabout as an enticement to the cows when they showed signs of withholding their usual yield; and the band of milkers at this request burst into melody—in purely business-like tones, it is true, and with no great spontaneity; the result, according to their own belief, being a decided improvement during the song’s continuance. When they had gone through fourteen or fifteen verses of a cheerful ballad about a murderer who was afraid to go to bed in the dark because he saw certain brimstone flames around him, one of the male milkers said—
当奶牛表现出抑制正常产量的迹象时，这里的奶牛场经常用歌曲来诱惑奶牛。挤奶工的乐队应了这个要求，突然奏起了旋律——确实是用纯粹的公务音调，而且没有什么太大的自发性。根据他们自己的信念，结果是在歌曲的延续过程中取得了明显的进步。当他们听完一首欢快的民谣的十四或十五节时，其中一个男挤奶工说：一个杀人犯不敢在黑暗中上床睡觉，因为他看到周围有硫磺的火焰。

‘I wish singing on the stoop didn’t use up so much of a man’s wind! You should get your harp, sir; not but what a fiddle is best.’
“我希望在门廊上唱歌不会消耗那么多男人的气！先生，你应该拿上你的竖琴；不是，而是小提琴最好。”

Tess, who had given ear to this, thought the words were addressed to the dairyman, but she was wrong. A reply, in the shape of ‘Why?’ came as it were out of the belly of a dun cow in the stalls; it had been spoken by a milker behind the animal, whom she had not hitherto perceived.
苔丝听到了这句话，以为这句话是对奶牛场老板说的，但她错了。 “为什么？”的回答仿佛是从牛栏里一头暗褐色母牛的肚子里发出来的。这是奶牛后面的一个挤奶工说的，但她迄今为止还没有认出他来。

‘Oh yes; there’s nothing like a fiddle,’ said the dairyman. ‘Though I do think that bulls are more moved by a tune than cows—at least that’s my experience. Once there was an old aged man over at Mellstock—William Dewy by name—one of the family that used to do a good deal of business as tranters over there—Jonathan, do ye mind?—I knowed the man by sight as well as I know my own brother, in a manner of speaking. Well, this man was a coming home along from a wedding, where he had been playing his fiddle, one fine moonlight night, and for shortness’ sake he took a cut across Forty-acres, a field lying that way, where a bull was out to grass. The bull seed William, and took after him, horns aground, begad; and though William runned his best, and hadn’t MUCH drink in him (considering ‘twas a wedding, and the folks well off), he found he’d never reach the fence and get over in time to save himself. Well, as a last thought, he pulled out his fiddle as he runned, and struck up a jig, turning to the bull, and backing towards the corner. The bull softened down, and stood still, looking hard at William Dewy, who fiddled on and on; till a sort of a smile stole over the bull’s face. But no sooner did William stop his playing and turn to get over hedge than the bull would stop his smiling and lower his horns towards the seat of William’s breeches. Well, William had to turn about and play on, willy-nilly; and ‘twas only three o’clock in the world, and ‘a knowed that nobody would come that way for hours, and he so leery and tired that ‘a didn’t know what to do. When he had scraped till about four o’clock he felt that he verily would have to give over soon, and he said to himself, ‘There’s only this last tune between me and eternal welfare! Heaven save me, or I’m a done man.’ Well, then he called to mind how he’d seen the cattle kneel o’ Christmas Eves in the dead o’ night. It was not Christmas Eve then, but it came into his head to play a trick upon the bull. So he broke into the ‘Tivity Hymm, just as at Christmas carol-singing; when, lo and behold, down went the bull on his bended knees, in his ignorance, just as if ‘twere the true ‘Tivity night and hour. As soon as his horned friend were down, William turned, clinked off like a long-dog, and jumped safe over hedge, before the praying bull had got on his feet again to take after him. William used to say that he’d seen a man look a fool a good many times, but never such a fool as that bull looked when he found his pious feelings had been played upon, and ‘twas not Christmas Eve. ... Yes, William Dewy, that was the man’s name; and I can tell you to a foot where’s he a-lying in Mellstock Churchyard at this very moment—just between the second yew-tree and the north aisle.’
'哦是的;没有什么比小提琴更好的了，”奶牛场老板说。 “虽然我确实认为公牛比奶牛更容易被音乐所感动——至少这是我的经验。从前，梅尔斯托克有一位老人，名叫威廉·杜伊，是过去在那里做很多生意的家族之一，乔纳森，你介意吗？从某种意义上说，我了解我自己的兄弟。好吧，这个人刚从一场婚礼回家，在一个美好的月光之夜，他一直在拉小提琴，为了简短起见，他在四十英亩的土地上开辟了一条田地，那块田地就在那边，那里有一头公牛。到草地上。公牛种子威廉，追随他，角搁浅，乞讨；尽管威廉竭尽全力，也没有喝太多酒（考虑到这是一场婚礼，人们都很富裕），但他发现自己永远无法到达栅栏并及时越过以拯救自己。好吧，作为最后一个念头，他一边跑一边掏出小提琴，弹起一支吉格舞，转向公牛，然后退到街角。公牛软了下来，一动不动地站着，死死地盯着威廉·杜伊，后者不停地拨弄着琴弦。直到公牛的脸上露出一丝微笑。但威廉一停止玩耍，转身越过树篱，公牛就会停止微笑，将角低向威廉的马裤座位。好吧，威廉不得不转身继续玩，不管愿意与否。当时才凌晨三点，他知道几个小时内都没有人会来这里，他如此警惕和疲惫，以至于“他不知道该怎么办”。当他熬到四点钟左右时，他觉得自己真的很快就要放弃了，他对自己说：“我和永恒的幸福之间就只有这最后的曲调了！”上帝保佑我，否则我就完蛋了。’好吧，然后他想起了他是如何在平安夜看到牛在夜深人静时跪下的。那时还不是平安夜，但他却想到要捉弄一下公牛。于是他开始唱起《Tivity Hymm》，就像圣诞颂歌一样；就在这时，你瞧，那头公牛在他的无知中双膝跪地，仿佛“那是真正的‘活动’夜晚和时刻”。他的长角朋友一倒下，威廉就转身，像一只长狗一样叮当作响，安全地跳过树篱，然后祈祷的公牛再次站起来追赶他。威廉常说，他曾多次见过一个人看起来像个傻瓜，但当他发现自己的虔诚感情被利用时，从来没有像那头公牛那样愚蠢，而且“这不是圣诞夜”。 ……是的，威廉·杜伊，那就是这个人的名字；我可以告诉你此刻他躺在梅尔斯托克墓地的什么地方——就在第二棵紫杉树和北过道之间。’

‘It’s a curious story; it carries us back to medieval times, when faith was a living thing!’
“这是一个奇怪的故事；它把我们带回到中世纪，那时信仰是有生命的！”

The remark, singular for a dairy-yard, was murmured by the voice behind the dun cow; but as nobody understood the reference, no notice was taken, except that the narrator seemed to think it might imply scepticism as to his tale.
这句话对于奶牛场来说是很罕见的，是由暗褐色奶牛背后的声音低声说出来的。但由于没有人理解这个提法，所以没有人注意到，除了叙述者似乎认为这可能意味着对他的故事的怀疑。

‘Well, ‘tis quite true, sir, whether or no. I knowed the man well.’
“嗯，这确实是事实，先生，无论是否如此。我很了解这个人。

‘Oh yes; I have no doubt of it,’ said the person behind the dun cow.
'哦是的;我对此毫不怀疑。”黄褐色牛背后的人说道。

Tess’s attention was thus attracted to the dairyman’s interlocutor, of whom she could see but the merest patch, owing to his burying his head so persistently in the flank of the milcher. She could not understand why he should be addressed as ‘sir’ even by the dairyman himself. But no explanation was discernible; he remained under the cow long enough to have milked three, uttering a private ejaculation now and then, as if he could not get on.
苔丝的注意力就这样被挤奶工的对话者吸引了，她只能看到他的一小部分，因为他总是把头埋在挤奶工的侧面。她不明白为什么即使是奶牛场老板本人也要称呼他为“先生”。但没有任何明显的解释；他在牛下面待了很长时间，足以挤完三头奶，时不时地私下里发出一声精液，好像他无法继续前进。

‘Take it gentle, sir; take it gentle,’ said the dairyman. ‘‘Tis knack, not strength, that does it.’
“请温柔点，先生；放轻松点，”奶牛场老板说。 “能做到这一点的是技巧，而不是力量。”

‘So I find,’ said the other, standing up at last and stretching his arms. ‘I think I have finished her, however, though she made my fingers ache.’
“我也是这么认为的，”另一个说着，终于站了起来，伸展了双臂。 “不过，我想我已经完成了她，尽管她让我的手指疼痛。”

Tess could then see him at full length. He wore the ordinary white pinner and leather leggings of a dairy-farmer when milking, and his boots were clogged with the mulch of the yard; but this was all his local livery. Beneath it was something educated, reserved, subtle, sad, differing.
苔丝就能看到他的全貌了。挤奶时，他穿着奶农的普通白色紧身衣和皮裤，他的靴子被院子里的覆盖物堵塞了。但这都是他当地的制服。在它的下面是一些有教养的、保守的、微妙的、悲伤的、与众不同的东西。

But the details of his aspect were temporarily thrust aside by the discovery that he was one whom she had seen before. Such vicissitudes had Tess passed through since that time that for a moment she could not remember where she had met him; and then it flashed upon her that he was the pedestrian who had joined in the club-dance at Marlott—the passing stranger who had come she knew not whence, had danced with others but not with her, and slightingly left her, and gone on his way with his friends.
但由于发现他是她以前见过的人，他的外貌细节暂时被抛在了一边。从那时起，苔丝经历了如此多的沧桑，以至于她一时记不起在哪里见过他。然后她突然意识到，他就是参加马洛特俱乐部舞会的那个行人——那个路过的陌生人，她不知道从哪里来，和其他人一起跳舞，但没有和她一起跳舞，然后轻轻地离开了她，继续前行。他与朋友相处的方式。

The flood of memories brought back by this revival of an incident anterior to her troubles produced a momentary dismay lest, recognizing her also, he should by some means discover her story. But it passed away when she found no sign of remembrance in him. She saw by degrees that since their first and only encounter his mobile face had grown more thoughtful, and had acquired a young man’s shapely moustache and beard—the latter of the palest straw colour where it began upon his cheeks, and deepening to a warm brown farther from its root. Under his linen milking-pinner he wore a dark velveteen jacket, cord breeches and gaiters, and a starched white shirt. Without the milking-gear nobody could have guessed what he was. He might with equal probability have been an eccentric landowner or a gentlemanly ploughman. That he was but a novice at dairy work she had realized in a moment, from the time he had spent upon the milking of one cow.
她遇到麻烦之前发生的一件事的重现，带回了大量的记忆，产生了短暂的沮丧，生怕他也认识了她，会以某种方式发现她的故事。但当她在他身上找不到任何记忆的迹象时，一切就消失了。她逐渐发现，自从他们第一次也是唯一一次见面以来，他那张灵活的脸变得更加深思熟虑，并且长出了年轻人形状的小胡子和胡须——后者从他的脸颊开始是最浅的稻草色，逐渐加深为温暖的棕色。离它的根越来越远。他的亚麻挤奶帽下面穿着一件深色平绒夹克、灯芯裤和绑腿，以及一件浆过的白衬衫。如果没有挤奶设备，没有人能猜出他是谁。他可能是一个古怪的地主，也可能是一个绅士的农夫。从他为一头奶牛挤奶开始，她立刻就意识到他只是乳制品工作的新手。

Meanwhile many of the milkmaids had said to one another of the newcomer, ‘How pretty she is!’ with something of real generosity and admiration, though with a half hope that the auditors would qualify the assertion—which, strictly speaking, they might have done, prettiness being an inexact definition of what struck the eye in Tess. When the milking was finished for the evening they straggled indoors, where Mrs Crick, the dairyman’s wife—who was too respectable to go out milking herself, and wore a hot stuff gown in warm weather because the dairymaids wore prints—was giving an eye to the leads and things.
与此同时，许多挤奶女工都带着某种真正的慷慨和钦佩之情互相对新来的人说：“她多漂亮啊！”尽管他们还抱有一丝希望，希望审计员能够证实这一说法——严格来说，他们可能已经证实了这一点。完成了，漂亮对于苔丝来说是一个不准确的定义。晚上挤奶结束后，他们在室内闲逛，奶牛场老板的妻子克里克太太——她太受人尊敬了，不会自己出去挤奶，在温暖的天气里，因为挤奶女工都穿着印花衣服，所以她在温暖的天气里穿着一件热料长袍——正在留意着奶牛场的情况。线索和事情。

Only two or three of the maids, Tess learnt, slept in the dairy-house besides herself, most of the helpers going to their homes. She saw nothing at supper-time of the superior milker who had commented on the story, and asked no questions about him, the remainder of the evening being occupied in arranging her place in the bed-chamber. It was a large room over the milk-house, some thirty feet long; the sleeping-cots of the other three indoor milkmaids being in the same apartment. They were blooming young women, and, except one, rather older than herself. By bedtime Tess was thoroughly tired, and fell asleep immediately.
苔丝了解到，除了她自己之外，只有两三个女仆睡在奶牛场里，大多数帮工都回家了。晚饭时间，她没有看到对这个故事发表评论的高级挤奶工，也没有问任何关于他的问题，晚上剩下的时间都在安排她在卧室里的位置。这是牛奶房上方的一个大房间，大约三十英尺长。其他三个室内挤奶女工的睡床就在同一间公寓里。她们都是风华正茂的年轻女性，而且，除了一位之外，她们都比她年长。到了睡觉的时候，苔丝已经彻底累了，很快就睡着了。

But one of the girls, who occupied an adjoining bed, was more wakeful than Tess, and would insist upon relating to the latter various particulars of the homestead into which she had just entered. The girl’s whispered words mingled with the shades, and, to Tess’s drowsy mind, they seemed to be generated by the darkness in which they floated.
但其中一个住在隔壁床上的女孩比苔丝更清醒，并且坚持要向后者讲述她刚刚进入的宅基地的各种细节。女孩的低语与阴影混杂在一起，在苔丝昏昏欲睡的头脑中，它们似乎是由它们漂浮在其中的黑暗产生的。

‘Mr Angel Clare—he that is learning milking, and that plays the harp—never says much to us. He is a pa’son’s son, and is too much taken up wi’ his own thoughts to notice girls. He is the dairyman’s pupil—learning farming in all its branches. He has learnt sheep-farming at another place, and he’s now mastering dairy-work.... Yes, he is quite the gentleman-born. His father is the Reverent Mr Clare at Emminster—a good many miles from here.’
“安吉尔·克莱尔先生——他正在学习挤奶，还会弹竖琴——从来不跟我们说太多话。他是一个牧师的儿子，太专注于自己的想法而忽视了女孩。他是奶牛场老板的学生，在各个部门学习农业。他在外地学会了养羊，现在正在掌握奶牛工作……是的，他真是绅士出身。他的父亲是埃明斯特的尊敬的克莱尔先生——距离这里有很多英里。

‘Oh—I have heard of him,’ said her companion, now awake. ‘A very earnest clergyman, is he not?’
“哦——我听说过他，”她的同伴现在醒了，说道。 “他是一位非常热心的牧师，不是吗？”

‘Yes—that he is—the earnestest man in all Wessex, they say—the last of the old Low Church sort, they tell me—for all about here be what they call High. All his sons, except our Mr Clare, be made pa’sons too.’
“是的——他是——他们说，他是整个威塞克斯最热心的人——他们告诉我，他是旧低等教会中的最后一个——因为这里的一切都是他们所谓的高教。”他所有的儿子，除了我们的克莱尔先生，也都被任命为牧师。

Tess had not at this hour the curiosity to ask why the present Mr Clare was not made a parson like his brethren, and gradually fell asleep again, the words of her informant coming to her along with the smell of the cheeses in the adjoining cheeseloft, and the measured dripping of the whey from the wrings downstairs.
苔丝此时并没有好奇心去问为什么现在的克莱尔先生不像他的弟兄们那样被任命为牧师，她渐渐地又睡着了，她的线人的话伴随着隔壁奶酪阁楼里奶酪的气味而来，楼下的绞肉机里滴下的乳清也有规律地滴落。

XVIII
十八

Angel Clare rises out of the past not altogether as a distinct figure, but as an appreciative voice, a long regard of fixed, abstracted eyes, and a mobility of mouth somewhat too small and delicately lined for a man’s, though with an unexpectedly firm close of the lower lip now and then; enough to do away with any inference of indecision. Nevertheless, something nebulous, preoccupied, vague, in his bearing and regard, marked him as one who probably had no very definite aim or concern about his material future. Yet as a lad people had said of him that he was one who might do anything if he tried.
安吉尔·克莱尔从过去中脱颖而出，并不完全是一个独特的人物，而是一种欣赏的声音，一双凝视着、心不在焉的眼睛，以及一张对男人来说有点小而精致的嘴唇，尽管他的嘴巴出人意料地坚定。时不时的下唇；足以消除任何犹豫不决的推论。然而，在他的举止和态度中，有一种模糊的、全神贯注的、模糊的感觉，表明他可能对自己的物质未来没有非常明确的目标或关心。然而，当他还是个小伙子时，人们都说他是一个只要努力就可以做任何事情的人。

He was the youngest son of his father, a poor parson at the other end of the county, and had arrived at Talbothays Dairy as a six months’ pupil, after going the round of some other farms, his object being to acquire a practical skill in the various processes of farming, with a view either to the Colonies or the tenure of a home-farm, as circumstances might decide.
他是他父亲最小的儿子，是县城另一端的一名贫穷牧师，在参观了其他一些农场后，来到塔尔博塞斯乳品厂当了六个月的学生，他的目标是获得一项实用技能在农业的各个过程中，要么是殖民地，要么是家庭农场的保有权，视情况而定。

His entry into the ranks of the agriculturists and breeders was a step in the young man’s career which had been anticipated neither by himself nor by others.
进入农学家和饲养员的行列是这个年轻人职业生涯中的一步，这是他本人和其他人都没有预料到的。

Mr Clare the elder, whose first wife had died and left him a daughter, married a second late in life. This lady had somewhat unexpectedly brought him three sons, so that between Angel, the youngest, and his father the Vicar there seemed to be almost a missing generation. Of these boys the aforesaid Angel, the child of his old age, was the only son who had not taken a University degree, though he was the single one of them whose early promise might have done full justice to an academical training.
老克莱尔先生的第一任妻子去世了，留下了一个女儿，后来又娶了第二任妻子。这位女士有些出乎意料地给他带来了三个儿子，所以最小的安吉尔和他的父亲牧师之间似乎几乎缺失了一代。在这些男孩中，上述安吉尔是他晚年生下的孩子，是唯一一个没有获得大学学位的儿子，尽管他是他们中唯一一个早年许下的诺言可能完全公正地接受学术培训的人。

Some two or three years before Angel’s appearance at the Marlott dance, on a day when he had left school and was pursuing his studies at home, a parcel came to the Vicarage from the local bookseller’s, directed to the Reverend James Clare. The Vicar having opened it and found it to contain a book, read a few pages; whereupon he jumped up from his seat and went straight to the shop with the book under his arm.
大约两三年前，安吉尔出现在马洛特舞会上，那天他离开学校，在家继续学业，一个包裹从当地书店寄到牧师住宅，寄给詹姆斯·克莱尔牧师。牧师打开它，发现里面有一本书，读了几页。于是他从座位上跳了起来，腋下夹着书直奔商店而去。

‘Why has this been sent to my house?’ he asked peremptorily, holding up the volume.
“为什么这本书会送到我家？”他举起书本，专横地问道。

‘It was ordered, sir.’
“这是命令，先生。”

‘Not by me, or any one belonging to me, I am happy to say.’
“我很高兴地说，这不是我做的，也不是我的任何人做的。”

The shopkeeper looked into his order-book.
店主查看了他的订单簿。

‘Oh, it has been misdirected, sir,’ he said. ‘It was ordered by Mr Angel Clare, and should have been sent to him.’
“哦，它被误导了，先生，”他说。 “这是安吉尔·克莱尔先生订购的，应该寄给他。”

Mr Clare winced as if he had been struck. He went home pale and dejected, and called Angel into his study.
克莱尔先生皱起眉头，仿佛受到了打击。他脸色苍白、沮丧地回到家，把安吉尔叫进书房。

‘Look into this book, my boy,’ he said. ‘What do you know about it?’
“看看这本书，我的孩子，”他说。 “你对此了解多少？”

‘I ordered it,’ said Angel simply.
“我订的。”安吉尔简单地说。

‘What for?’
'做什么的？'

‘To read.’
'读书。'

‘How can you think of reading it?’
“你怎么会想到读它呢？”

‘How can I? Why—it is a system of philosophy. There is no more moral, or even religious, work published.’
'我怎么能够？为什么——这是一个哲学体系。没有更多的道德甚至宗教作品出版。

‘Yes—moral enough; I don’t deny that. But religious!—and for YOU, who intend to be a minister of the Gospel!’
“是的——足够道德；我不否认这一点。但是宗教！——对于那些想要成为福音牧师的你来说！”

‘Since you have alluded to the matter, father,’ said the son, with anxious thought upon his face, ‘I should like to say, once for all, that I should prefer not to take Orders. I fear I could not conscientiously do so. I love the Church as one loves a parent. I shall always have the warmest affection for her. There is no institution for whose history I have a deeper admiration; but I cannot honestly be ordained her minister, as my brothers are, while she refuses to liberate her mind from an untenable redemptive theolatry.’
“既然你提到了这件事，父亲，”儿子脸上带着焦急的思绪说道，“我想说，我宁愿不接受命令。”我担心我不能认真地这样做。我爱教会，就像爱父母一样。我将永远对她怀有最热烈的感情。没有哪个机构的历史让我更加钦佩。但当她拒绝将自己的思想从站不住脚的救赎理论中解放出来时，我就不能像我的兄弟们那样被诚实地任命为她的牧师。

It had never occurred to the straightforward and simple-minded Vicar that one of his own flesh and blood could come to this! He was stultified, shocked, paralysed. And if Angel were not going to enter the Church, what was the use of sending him to Cambridge? The University as a step to anything but ordination seemed, to this man of fixed ideas, a preface without a volume. He was a man not merely religious, but devout; a firm believer—not as the phrase is now elusively construed by theological thimble-riggers in the Church and out of it, but in the old and ardent sense of the Evangelical school: one who could
耿直单纯的牧师怎么也没有想到，自己的亲骨肉竟然会走到这一步！他感到呆滞、震惊、瘫痪。如果安吉尔不打算进入教会，送他去剑桥有什么用呢？对于这个思想固定的人来说，大学作为除了任命之外的任何一步，似乎是一本没有卷的序言。他不仅是一个虔诚的人，而且是一个虔诚的人。坚定的信徒——不是像教会内外的神学顶针操纵者现在对这句话的难以捉摸的解释，而是按照福音派学校古老而热情的含义：一个能够

 Indeed opine
确实认为

That the Eternal and Divine
那永恒和神圣的

Did, eighteen centuries ago
十八世纪前确实如此

In very truth...
事实上...

Angel’s father tried argument, persuasion, entreaty.
安吉尔的父亲尝试过争论、劝说、恳求。

‘No, father; I cannot underwrite Article Four (leave alone the rest), taking it ‘in the literal and grammatical sense’ as required by the Declaration; and, therefore, I can’t be a parson in the present state of affairs,’ said Angel. ‘My whole instinct in matters of religion is towards reconstruction; to quote your favorite Epistle to the Hebrews, ‘the removing of those things that are shaken, as of things that are made, that those things which cannot be shaken may remain.’’
“不，父亲；我不能赞同第四条（更不用说其余部分），按照《宣言》的要求“从字面和语法意义上”理解它；因此，在目前的情况下，我不能成为一名牧师。”安吉尔说道。 “我在宗教问题上的全部本能是重建；引用你最喜欢的希伯来书，“那些被震动的东西，如被造的东西，要被除去，使那些不能震动的东西可以留下来。”

His father grieved so deeply that it made Angel quite ill to see him.
他的父亲悲痛欲绝，安吉尔一见到他就很难受。

‘What is the good of your mother and me economizing and stinting ourselves to give you a University education, if it is not to be used for the honour and glory of God?’ his father repeated.
“如果不是为了上帝的荣誉和荣耀，你母亲和我省吃俭用让你接受大学教育有什么好处呢？”他的父亲重复道。

‘Why, that it may be used for the honour and glory of man, father.’
“哎呀，它可以用来维护人类的荣誉和荣耀，父亲。”

Perhaps if Angel had persevered he might have gone to Cambridge like his brothers. But the Vicar’s view of that seat of learning as a stepping-stone to Orders alone was quite a family tradition; and so rooted was the idea in his mind that perseverance began to appear to the sensitive son akin to an intent to misappropriate a trust, and wrong the pious heads of the household, who had been and were, as his father had hinted, compelled to exercise much thrift to carry out this uniform plan of education for the three young men.
也许如果安吉尔坚持下去，他可能会像他的兄弟们一样去剑桥。但牧师认为学习场所只是通向教团的垫脚石，这是一种家族传统。这种想法在他的脑海中根深蒂固，以至于对敏感的儿子来说，坚持不懈开始出现类似于意图挪用信托的意图，并冤枉了虔诚的一家之主，正如他父亲所暗示的那样，他们过去和现在都被迫这样做非常节俭地执行这三个年轻人的统一教育计划。

‘I will do without Cambridge,’ said Angel at last. ‘I feel that I have no right to go there in the circumstances.’
“我不需要剑桥，”安吉尔最后说道。 “我觉得在这种情况下我没有权利去那里。”

The effects of this decisive debate were not long in showing themselves. He spent years and years in desultory studies, undertakings, and meditations; he began to evince considerable indifference to social forms and observances. The material distinctions of rank and wealth he increasingly despised. Even the ‘good old family’ (to use a favourite phrase of a late local worthy) had no aroma for him unless there were good new resolutions in its representatives. As a balance to these austerities, when he went to live in London to see what the world was like, and with a view to practising a profession or business there, he was carried off his head, and nearly entrapped by a woman much older than himself, though luckily he escaped not greatly the worse for the experience.
这场决定性辩论的影响很快就显现出来了。他年复一年地进行断断续续的学习、事业和冥想。他开始对社会形式和习俗表现出相当的漠不关心。他越来越鄙视等级和财富的物质差别。即使是“好老家族”（用一位已故当地伟人最喜欢的一句话）也对他没有吸引力，除非其代表有新的好决议。为了平衡这些苦行，当他去伦敦生活，看看世界是什么样子，并打算在那里从事一项职业或生意时，他被一个比他年长得多的女人迷住了。幸运的是，他自己逃脱了，并没有因为这次经历而变得更糟。

Early association with country solitudes had bred in him an unconquerable, and almost unreasonable, aversion to modern town life, and shut him out from such success as he might have aspired to by following a mundane calling in the impracticability of the spiritual one. But something had to be done; he had wasted many valuable years; and having an acquaintance who was starting on a thriving life as a Colonial farmer, it occurred to Angel that this might be a lead in the right direction. Farming, either in the Colonies, America, or at home—farming, at any rate, after becoming well qualified for the business by a careful apprenticeship—that was a vocation which would probably afford an independence without the sacrifice of what he valued even more than a competency—intellectual liberty.
早期与乡村孤独的交往使他对现代城市生活产生了一种无法克服的、几乎不合理的厌恶，并使他无法通过追求一种不切实际的精神召唤而追求世俗的召唤而获得成功。但必须做点什么；他已经浪费了许多宝贵的岁月；安吉尔认识了一位正在开始作为殖民地农民过上繁荣生活的熟人，他突然想到这可能是一条通往正确方向的线索。务农，无论是在殖民地、美国，还是在家里——无论如何，在通过仔细的学徒训练获得了足够的资格后，从事农业——这种职业可能会提供独立，而无需牺牲他更看重的东西而不是一种能力——智力自由。

So we find Angel Clare at six-and-twenty here at Talbothays as a student of kine, and, as there were no houses near at hand in which he could get a comfortable lodging, a boarder at the dairyman’s.
因此，我们在塔尔博塞斯找到了六岁二十岁的安吉尔·克莱尔，他是一名牛的学生，而且，由于附近没有房子可以让他住得舒适，所以他在奶牛场寄宿。

His room was an immense attic which ran the whole length of the dairy-house. It could only be reached by a ladder from the cheese-loft, and had been closed up for a long time till he arrived and selected it as his retreat. Here Clare had plenty of space, and could often be heard by the dairy-folk pacing up and down when the household had gone to rest. A portion was divided off at one end by a curtain, behind which was his bed, the outer part being furnished as a homely sitting-room.
他的房间是一个巨大的阁楼，与奶牛场一样长。它只能从奶酪阁楼通过梯子到达，并且已经关闭了很长一段时间，直到他到达并选择它作为他的撤退。克莱尔在这里有足够的空间，当家人休息时，经常可以听到奶牛场工人来回踱步的声音。一部分的一端被帘子隔开，帘子后面是他的床，外面的部分布置成一间温馨的客厅。

At first he lived up above entirely, reading a good deal, and strumming upon an old harp which he had bought at a sale, saying when in a bitter humour that he might have to get his living by it in the streets some day. But he soon preferred to read human nature by taking his meals downstairs in the general dining-kitchen, with the dairyman and his wife, and the maids and men, who all together formed a lively assembly; for though but few milking hands slept in the house, several joined the family at meals. The longer Clare resided here the less objection had he to his company, and the more did he like to share quarters with them in common.
起初，他完全生活在上面，读了很多书，弹奏着他在拍卖会上买的一把旧竖琴，在苦涩的幽默中说，有一天他可能不得不在街上靠它谋生。但很快他就喜欢在楼下的普通餐厅厨房里吃饭，与奶牛场老板和他的妻子、女仆和男人一起吃饭，他们一起组成了一个热闹的聚会，以了解人性。虽然只有很少的挤奶工人睡在房子里，但也有几个人和家人一起吃饭。克莱尔在这里住的时间越长，他对自己的陪伴就越少，也越喜欢与他们共用宿舍。

Much to his surprise he took, indeed, a real delight in their companionship. The conventional farm-folk of his imagination— personified in the newspaper-press by the pitiable dummy known as Hodge—were obliterated after a few days’ residence. At close quarters no Hodge was to be seen. At first, it is true, when Clare’s intelligence was fresh from a contrasting society, these friends with whom he now hobnobbed seemed a little strange. Sitting down as a level member of the dairyman’s household seemed at the outset an undignified proceeding. The ideas, the modes, the surroundings, appeared retrogressive and unmeaning. But with living on there, day after day, the acute sojourner became conscious of a new aspect in the spectacle. Without any objective change whatever, variety had taken the place of monotonousness. His host and his host’s household, his men and his maids, as they became intimately known to Clare, began to differentiate themselves as in a chemical process. The thought of Pascal’s was brought home to him: ‘A mesure qu’on a plus d’esprit, on trouve qu’il y a plus d’hommes originaux. Les gens du commun ne trouvent pas de différence entre les hommes.’ The typical and unvarying Hodge ceased to exist.
