“我就知道你受不了！”玛丽安喊道。 “为了这项工作，它需要比你更硬的肉。”

Just then the farmer entered. ‘Oh, that’s how you get on when I am away,’ he said to her.
就在这时，农夫进来了。 “哦，我不在的时候你就是这样相处的，”他对她说。

‘But it is my own loss,’ she pleaded. ‘Not yours.’
“但这是我自己的损失，”她恳求道。 '不是你的。'

‘I want it finished,’ he said doggedly, as he crossed the barn and went out at the other door.
“我希望它完成，”他固执地说，穿过谷仓，从另一扇门出去。

‘Don’t ‘ee mind him, there’s a dear,’ said Marian. ‘I’ve worked here before. Now you go and lie down there, and Izz and I will make up your number.’
“别管他，有一个亲爱的，”玛丽安说。 “我以前在这里工作过。现在你去那里躺下，我和伊兹会给你补上号码。”

‘I don’t like to let you do that. I’m taller than you, too.’
‘我不想让你这么做。我也比你高。

However, she was so overcome that she consented to lie down awhile, and reclined on a heap of pull-tails—the refuse after the straight straw had been drawn—thrown up at the further side of the barn. Her succumbing had been as largely owning to agitation at the re-opening the subject of her separation from her husband as to the hard work. She lay in a state of percipience without volition, and the rustle of the straw and the cutting of the ears by the others had the weight of bodily touches.
然而，她实在太受不了了，同意躺一会儿，斜靠在谷仓另一边扔的一堆拉尾草上——直稻草被拉过后的垃圾。她的屈服在很大程度上归因于重新公开她与丈夫分居的话题所引起的不安，以及工作的艰辛。她躺在那里，处于一种无意识的感知状态，稻草的沙沙声和其他人割耳朵的声音有身体接触的重量。

She could hear from her corner, in addition to these noises, the murmur of their voices. She felt certain that they were continuing the subject already broached, but their voices were so low that she could not catch the words. At last Tess grew more and more anxious to know what they were saying, and, persuading herself that she felt better, she got up and resumed work.
从她的角落里，除了这些噪音之外，她还能听到他们的低语声。她确信他们还在继续刚才已经提到的话题，但他们的声音太低了，她听不清他们在说什么。最后，苔丝越来越想知道他们在说什么，她说服自己感觉好多了，然后站起来继续工作。

Then Izz Huett broke down. She had walked more than a dozen miles the previous evening, had gone to bed at midnight, and had risen again at five o’clock. Marian alone, thanks to her bottle of liquor and her stoutness of build, stood the strain upon back and arms without suffering. Tess urged Izz to leave off, agreeing, as she felt better, to finish the day without her, and make equal division of the number of sheaves.
然后伊兹·休特崩溃了。前一天晚上她走了十几英里，半夜上床睡觉，五点钟又起床。玛丽安独自一人，凭借她那瓶酒和她强壮的体格，毫无痛苦地承受了背部和手臂的压力。苔丝催促伊兹停下来，并同意，当她感觉好一些时，在没有她的情况下结束这一天，并平均分配禾捆的数量。

Izz accepted the offer gratefully, and disappeared through the great door into the snowy track to her lodging. Marian, as was the case every afternoon at this time on account of the bottle, began to feel in a romantic vein.
伊兹感激地接受了这个提议，然后穿过大门消失在通往她住处的雪道上。玛丽安，就像每天下午这个时候，因为这瓶酒的缘故，开始感到浪漫起来。

‘I should not have thought it of him—never!’ she said in a dreamy tone. ‘And I loved him so! I didn’t mind his having YOU. But this about Izz is too bad!’
“我不应该想到他——不应该！”她用一种梦幻般的语气说道。 ‘我是如此爱他！我不介意他拥有你。但伊兹的这件事太糟糕了！”

Tess, in her start at the words, narrowly missed cutting off a finger with the bill-hook.
苔丝一听这话，差点没用钩子砍断一根手指。

‘Is it about my husband?’ she stammered.
“是关于我丈夫的事吗？”她结结巴巴地说。

‘Well, yes. Izz said, ‘Don’t ‘ee tell her’; but I am sure I can’t help it! It was what he wanted Izz to do. He wanted her to go off to Brazil with him.’
'嗯，是。伊兹说：“别‘告诉她’；”但我确信我无能为力！这就是他想让伊兹做的事。他希望她和他一起去巴西。

Tess’s face faded as white as the scene without, and its curves straightened. ‘And did Izz refuse to go?’ she asked.
苔丝的脸色变得和外面的景色一样苍白，曲线也变直了。 “伊兹拒绝去吗？”她问道。

‘I don’t know. Anyhow he changed his mind.’
'我不知道。不管怎样，他改变了主意。

‘Pooh—then he didn’t mean it! ‘Twas just a man’s jest!’
‘呸——那他不是故意的！ “这只是一个男人的玩笑！”

‘Yes he did; for he drove her a good-ways towards the station.’
'是他做的;因为他开车送她去了车站。

‘He didn’t take her!’
“他没有带走她！”

They pulled on in silence till Tess, without any premonitory symptoms, burst out crying.
他们默默地继续前行，直到没有任何先兆症状的苔丝突然哭了起来。

‘There!’ said Marian. ‘Now I wish I hadn’t told ‘ee!’
“那儿！”玛丽安说。 “现在我希望我没有告诉‘哎呀！’”

‘No. It is a very good thing that you have done! I have been living on in a thirtover, lackaday way, and have not seen what it may lead to! I ought to have sent him a letter oftener. He said I could not go to him, but he didn’t say I was not to write as often as I liked. I won’t dally like this any longer! I have been very wrong and neglectful in leaving everything to be done by him!’
'不。你所做的真是一件非常好的事情！我一直过着疲倦乏力的生活，却没有看到这会导致什么结果！我应该经常给他写信。他说我不能去找他，但他并没有说我不能随心所欲地写信。我不会再这样磨​​磨蹭蹭了！我把一切都交给他来完成，这是非常错误和疏忽的！”

The dim light in the barn grew dimmer, and they could see to work no longer. When Tess had reached home that evening, and had entered into the privacy of her little white-washed chamber, she began impetuously writing a letter to Clare. But falling into doubt, she could not finish it. Afterwards she took the ring from the ribbon on which she wore it next her heart, and retained it on her finger all night, as if to fortify herself in the sensation that she was really the wife of this elusive lover of hers, who could propose that Izz should go with him abroad, so shortly after he had left her. Knowing that, how could she write entreaties to him, or show that she cared for him any more?
谷仓里昏暗的灯光越来越暗，他们看不清干活了。那天晚上，苔丝回到家，走进她粉刷成白色的小房间，开始急躁地给克莱尔写信。但陷入怀疑，她无法完成。随后，她从丝带上取下戒指，把它戴在胸前，整晚都把它戴在手指上，仿佛是为了强化自己的感觉，她真的是这个难以捉摸的情人的妻子，她可以向她求婚。在他离开伊兹后不久，她就应该和他一起去国外。知道了这一点，她还怎么给他写信恳求，或者表明她再关心他了呢？

XLIV
第四十四章

By the disclosure in the barn her thoughts were led anew in the direction which they had taken more than once of late—to the distant Emminster Vicarage. It was through her husband’s parents that she had been charged to send a letter to Clare if she desired; and to write to them direct if in difficulty. But that sense of her having morally no claim upon him had always led Tess to suspend her impulse to send these notes; and to the family at the Vicarage, therefore, as to her own parents since her marriage, she was virtually non-existent. This self-effacement in both directions had been quite in consonance with her independent character of desiring nothing by way of favour or pity to which she was not entitled on a fair consideration of her deserts. She had set herself to stand or fall by her qualities, and to waive such merely technical claims upon a strange family as had been established for her by the flimsy fact of a member of that family, in a season of impulse, writing his name in a church-book beside hers.
谷仓里的真相让她的思绪重新回到了最近不止一次的方向——遥远的埃明斯特牧师住宅。正是通过她丈夫的父母，她被要求给克莱尔寄一封信，如果她愿意的话。如果遇到困难，请直接写信给他们。但苔丝觉得自己在道义上对他没有任何要求，所以她一直克制住寄这些纸条的冲动。因此，对于牧师住宅的家人来说，对于她自己的父母来说，自从她结婚以来，她几乎不存在。这种双向的自我贬低非常符合她独立的性格，她不希望得到任何恩惠或怜悯，而公平地考虑她的应得，她无权获得这些恩惠或怜悯。她已经决定自己的成败取决于她的品质，并放弃对一个陌生家庭的这种纯粹技术性的要求，因为这个家庭的一个成员在冲动的季节里把他的名字写在了她的脆弱的事实上。她的旁边有一本教堂书籍。

But now that she was stung to a fever by Izz’s tale, there was a limit to her powers of renunciation. Why had her husband not written to her? He had distinctly implied that he would at least let her know of the locality to which he had journeyed; but he had not sent a line to notify his address. Was he really indifferent? But was he ill? Was it for her to make some advance? Surely she might summon the courage of solicitude, call at the Vicarage for intelligence, and express her grief at his silence. If Angel’s father were the good man she had heard him represented to be, he would be able to enter into her heart-starved situation. Her social hardships she could conceal.
但现在她被伊兹的故事刺痛了，她放弃的力量已经有限了。为什么她的丈夫不给她写信？他明确暗示，他至少会让她知道他所到的地方；但他没有发电话通知他的地址。他真的冷漠吗？但他生病了吗？难道是为了让她垫底吗？当然，她可能会鼓起关心的勇气，向牧师住宅寻求情报，并对他的沉默表达她的悲伤。如果安吉尔的父亲是她所听到的好人，他就能进入她内心饥饿的境地。她可以掩盖她的社交困难。

To leave the farm on a week-day was not in her power; Sunday was the only possible opportunity. Flintcomb-Ash being in the middle of the cretaceous tableland over which no railway had climbed as yet, it would be necessary to walk. And the distance being fifteen miles each way she would have to allow herself a long day for the undertaking by rising early.
她无权在工作日离开农场。周日是唯一可能的机会。燧石库姆-阿什位于白垩纪高原中部，目前还没有铁路通行，因此必须步行。而且单程有十五英里，她必须早起，为这项任务留出漫长的一天。

A fortnight later, when the snow had gone, and had been followed by a hard black frost, she took advantage of the state of the roads to try the experiment. At four o’clock that Sunday morning she came downstairs and stepped out into the starlight. The weather was still favourable, the ground ringing under her feet like an anvil.
两周后，雪停了，接着又下了一层硬黑的霜，她利用路况进行了实验。那个周日早上四点，她下了楼，踏入星光之中。天气依然宜人，脚下的大地像铁砧一样轰鸣。

Marian and Izz were much interested in her excursion, knowing that the journey concerned her husband. Their lodgings were in a cottage a little further along the lane, but they came and assisted Tess in her departure, and argued that she should dress up in her very prettiest guise to captivate the hearts of her parents-in-law; though she, knowing of the austere and Calvinistic tenets of old Mr Clare, was indifferent, and even doubtful. A year had now elapsed since her sad marriage, but she had preserved sufficient draperies from the wreck of her then full wardrobe to clothe her very charmingly as a simple country girl with no pretensions to recent fashion; a soft gray woollen gown, with white crape quilling against the pink skin of her face and neck, and a black velvet jacket and hat.
玛丽安和伊兹对她的旅行很感兴趣，因为他们知道这次旅行与她的丈夫有关。他们的住处是在小巷稍远一点的一间小屋里，但他们来帮助苔丝离开，并主张她应该打扮成最漂亮的样子，以吸引她公婆的心。尽管她知道老克莱尔先生的严厉和加尔文主义信条，但她却漠不关心，甚至怀疑。距离她悲伤的婚姻已经过去一年了，但她从当时满是衣柜的残骸中保留了足够的窗帘，让她把自己打扮得非常迷人，就像一个简单的乡村女孩，没有任何新时尚的矫饰。一件柔软的灰色羊毛礼服，白色的绉纱衬托着她脸上和脖子上粉红色的皮肤，还有一件黑色天鹅绒夹克和帽子。

‘‘Tis a thousand pities your husband can’t see ‘ee now—you do look a real beauty!’ said Izz Huett, regarding Tess as she stood on the threshold between the steely starlight without and the yellow candlelight within. Izz spoke with a magnanimous abandonment of herself to the situation; she could not be—no woman with a heart bigger than a hazel-nut could be—antagonistic to Tess in her presence, the influence which she exercised over those of her own sex being of a warmth and strength quite unusual, curiously overpowering the less worthy feminine feelings of spite and rivalry.
“你丈夫现在看不到了，真可惜——你看起来确实很美！”伊兹·休特看着站在门外钢铁般的星光和屋内黄色烛光之间的门槛上的苔丝说道。伊兹说话时表现出一种宽宏大量的、对这种情况的放纵态度。她不可能——没有一个心胸比榛子更大的女人——当着苔丝的面与她对立，她对同性的影响力是一种非常不寻常的温暖和力量，奇怪的是压倒了那些次要的人。值得女性的怨恨和竞争的感觉。

With a final tug and touch here, and a slight brush there, they let her go; and she was absorbed into the pearly air of the fore-dawn. They heard her footsteps tap along the hard road as she stepped out to her full pace. Even Izz hoped she would win, and, though without any particular respect for her own virtue, felt glad that she had been prevented wronging her friend when momentarily tempted by Clare.
最后用力一拉，碰触这里，轻轻拂过那里，他们就放开了她。她沉浸在黎明的珍珠般的空气中。当她全速迈出步伐时，他们听到她的脚步声沿着坚硬的道路敲击着。就连伊兹也希望她能获胜，尽管她对自己的美德没有任何特别的尊重，但她很高兴自己没有在受到克莱尔短暂诱惑时冤枉了她的朋友。

It was a year ago, all but a day, that Clare had married Tess, and only a few days less than a year that he had been absent from her. Still, to start on a brisk walk, and on such an errand as hers, on a dry clear wintry morning, through the rarefied air of these chalky hogs’-backs, was not depressing; and there is no doubt that her dream at starting was to win the heart of her mother-in-law, tell her whole history to that lady, enlist her on her side, and so gain back the truant.
一年前，仅仅一天，克莱尔就与苔丝结婚了，而他离开她也只有不到一年的时间了。尽管如此，在一个干燥、晴朗的冬日早晨，穿过这些白垩猪背的稀薄空气，开始轻快地散步，执行像她这样的差事，并不令人沮丧;毫无疑问，她一开始的梦想就是赢得婆婆的心，把自己的全部历史告诉那位女士，拉拢她站在自己一边，从而挽回逃学的人。

In time she reached the edge of the vast escarpment below which stretched the loamy Vale of Blackmoor, now lying misty and still in the dawn. Instead of the colourless air of the uplands, the atmosphere down there was a deep blue. Instead of the great enclosures of a hundred acres in which she was now accustomed to toil, there were little fields below her of less than half-a-dozen acres, so numerous that they looked from this height like the meshes of a net. Here the landscape was whitey-brown; down there, as in Froom Valley, it was always green. Yet it was in that vale that her sorrow had taken shape, and she did not love it as formerly. Beauty to her, as to all who have felt, lay not in the thing, but in what the thing symbolized.
她及时到达了巨大悬崖的边缘，悬崖下面延伸着肥沃的布莱克莫尔山谷，现在在黎明时分，雾气蒙蒙，寂静无声。那里的空气不是高地无色的，而是深蓝色的。她现在习惯于在一百英亩的大围场里劳作，取而代之的是她下面只有不到六英亩的小田地，田地如此之多，从这个高度看起来就像一张网。这里的风景是白褐色的；那里，就像弗鲁姆谷一样，总是绿色的。然而她的悲伤就是在那个山谷里形成的，她不再像以前那样热爱它了。对她来说，就像对所有有过这种感觉的人一样，美不在于事物，而在于事物所象征的东西。

Keeping the Vale on her right, she steered steadily westward; passing above the Hintocks, crossing at right-angles the high-road from Sherton-Abbas to Casterbridge, and skirting Dogbury Hill and High-Stoy, with the dell between them called ‘The Devil’s Kitchen”. Still following the elevated way she reached Cross-in-Hand, where the stone pillar stands desolate and silent, to mark the site of a miracle, or murder, or both. Three miles further she cut across the straight and deserted Roman road called Long-Ash Lane; leaving which as soon as she reached it she dipped down a hill by a transverse lane into the small town or village of Evershead, being now about halfway over the distance. She made a halt here, and breakfasted a second time, heartily enough—not at the Sow-and-Acorn, for she avoided inns, but at a cottage by the church.
她保持山谷在她的右侧，稳步向西航行。穿过欣托克斯山脉，以直角穿过从谢尔顿-阿巴斯到卡斯特布里奇的公路，绕过多格伯里山和海斯托伊，它们之间的山谷被称为“魔鬼厨房”。继续沿着高架路，她到达了手十字，那里的石柱荒凉而寂静，标志着奇迹或谋杀或两者兼而有之的地点。再往前走了三英里，她穿过了一条笔直而荒凉的罗马道路，名叫长灰巷。她一到达目的地就离开了那里，沿着一条横向小路下了山，进入了埃弗斯黑德小镇或村庄，现在大约已经走了一半的距离。她在这里停下来，第二次吃早餐，吃得很丰盛——不是在母猪和橡子店，因为她避开了旅馆，而是在教堂旁边的一间小屋。

The second half of her journey was through a more gentle country, by way of Benvill Lane. But as the mileage lessened between her and the spot of her pilgrimage, so did Tess’s confidence decrease, and her enterprise loom out more formidably. She saw her purpose in such staring lines, and the landscape so faintly, that she was sometimes in danger of losing her way. However, about noon she paused by a gate on the edge of the basin in which Emminster and its Vicarage lay.
她旅程的后半段是途经本维尔巷，穿过一个更加温和的国家。但随着苔丝与朝圣地之间的距离越来越短，她的信心也随之下降，她的事业也变得更加艰巨。她从如此凝视的线条和如此模糊的风景中看到了自己的目的，以至于有时她有迷失方向的危险。然而，中午时分，她在盆地边缘的一扇门前停了下来，埃明斯特及其牧师住宅就位于盆地边缘。

The square tower, beneath which she knew that at that moment the Vicar and his congregation were gathered, had a severe look in her eyes. She wished that she had somehow contrived to come on a week-day. Such a good man might be prejudiced against a woman who had chosen Sunday, never realizing the necessities of her case. But it was incumbent upon her to go on now. She took off the thick boots in which she had walked thus far, put on her pretty thin ones of patent leather, and, stuffing the former into the hedge by the gatepost where she might readily find them again, descended the hill; the freshness of colour she had derived from the keen air thinning away in spite of her as she drew near the parsonage.
她知道牧师和他的会众此刻正聚集在这座方形塔楼下，她的眼神里充满了严厉。她希望自己能在工作日来。这样一个好男人可能会对一个选择周日的女人抱有偏见，却从未意识到她案件的必要性。但现在她有责任继续下去。她脱下迄今为止走路所穿的厚靴子，穿上漂亮的薄漆皮靴子，然后把靴子塞进门柱旁的树篱里，这样她就可以很容易地再次找到它们，然后下了山。尽管她不顾一切，当她走近牧师住宅时，她从强烈的空气中获得的清新色彩就逐渐消失了。

Tess hoped for some accident that might favour her, but nothing favoured her. The shrubs on the Vicarage lawn rustled uncomfortably in the frosty breeze; she could not feel by any stretch of imagination, dressed to her highest as she was, that the house was the residence of near relations; and yet nothing essential, in nature or emotion, divided her from them: in pains, pleasures, thoughts, birth, death, and after-death, they were the same.
苔丝希望发生一些对她有利的意外事件，但没有任何事情对她有利。牧师公馆草坪上的灌木在凛冽的微风中发出令人不安的沙沙声。尽管她穿着最华丽的衣服，但她无论如何也无法想象这座房子是近亲的住所。然而，在本质上或情感上，没有任何本质的东西将她与他们分开：在痛苦、快乐、思想、出生、死亡和死后，他们都是一样的。

She nerved herself by an effort, entered the swing-gate, and rang the door-bell. The thing was done; there could be no retreat. No; the thing was not done. Nobody answered to her ringing. The effort had to be risen to and made again. She rang a second time, and the agitation of the act, coupled with her weariness after the fifteen miles’ walk, led her support herself while she waited by resting her hand on her hip, and her elbow against the wall of the porch. The wind was so nipping that the ivy-leaves had become wizened and gray, each tapping incessantly upon its neighbour with a disquieting stir of her nerves. A piece of blood-stained paper, caught up from some meat-buyer’s dust-heap, beat up and down the road without the gate; too flimsy to rest, too heavy to fly away; and a few straws kept it company.
她努力鼓起勇气，走进平开门，按响了门铃。事情已经完成了；没有退路。不;事情还没有完成。没有人接听她的铃声。必须重新努力。她第二次按响了电话，这一行为的激动，加上十五英里步行后的疲倦，导致她在等待时将手放在臀部上，肘部靠在门廊的墙上。风刮得很厉害，常春藤叶子变得枯萎、变灰，每片叶子都不停地拍打着相邻的叶子，让她的神经不安。一张从买肉者的垃圾堆里捡起的沾满血迹的纸片，在大门外的路上来来回回地敲打着；太脆弱而无法休息，太重而无法飞走；几根吸管陪伴着它。

The second peal had been louder, and still nobody came. Then she walked out of the porch, opened the gate, and passed through. And though she looked dubiously at the house-front as if inclined to return, it was with a breath of relied that she closed the gate. A feeling haunted her that she might have been recognized (though how she could not tell), and orders been given not to admit her.
第二声钟声更大了，但仍然没有人来。然后她走出门廊，打开大门，走了进去。尽管她疑惑地看着房子的正面，似乎想回去，但她还是带着一丝信任关上了门。她有一种感觉，她可能被认出来了（尽管她不知道是怎么认出来的），并接到命令不让她进来。

Tess went as far as the corner. She had done all she could do; but determined not to escape present trepidation at the expense of future distress, she walked back again quite past the house, looking up at all the windows.
苔丝一直走到拐角处。她已经做了她能做的一切；但她决心不以未来的痛苦为代价来逃避眼前的恐惧，她又走回来，穿过房子，抬头看着所有的窗户。

Ah—the explanation was that they were all at church, every one. She remembered her husband saying that his father always insisted upon the household, servants included, going to morning-service, and, as a consequence, eating cold food when they came home. It was, therefore, only necessary to wait till the service was over. She would not make herself conspicuous by waiting on the spot, and she started to get past the church into the lane. But as she reached the churchyard-gate the people began pouring out, and Tess found herself in the midst of them.
啊——解释是他们所有人都在教堂。她记得她的丈夫说，他的父亲总是坚持全家人，包括仆人，去参加早间服务，因此，他们回家后必须吃冷食。因此，只需等到仪式结束即可。她为了不让自己在原地等待而显得引人注目，她开始穿过教堂进入小巷。但当她到达教堂墓地大门时，人们开始涌出来，苔丝发现自己就在他们中间。

The Emminster congregation looked at her as only a congregation of small country-townsfolk walking home at its leisure can look at a woman out of the common whom it perceives to be a stranger. She quickened her pace, and ascended the the road by which she had come, to find a retreat between its hedges till the Vicar’s family should have lunched, and it might be convenient for them to receive her. She soon distanced the churchgoers, except two youngish men, who, linked arm-in-arm, were beating up behind her at a quick step.
埃明斯特教会的会众看待她的方式就像只有一群闲暇时步行回家的小乡镇居民才能看待一个在他们看来是陌生人的不平凡的女人。她加快了脚步，顺着来时的路而上，在树篱之间寻找一处休息处，等牧师一家吃完午饭，也许他们会方便接待她。她很快就疏远了去教堂的人，除了两个年轻男子，他们手挽着手，快步在她身后殴打。

As they drew nearer she could hear their voices engaged in earnest discourse, and, with the natural quickness of a woman in her situation, did not fail to recognize in those noises the quality of her husband’s tones. The pedestrians were his two brothers. Forgetting all her plans, Tess’s one dread was lest they should overtake her now, in her disorganized condition, before she was prepared to confront them; for though she felt that they could not identify her, she instinctively dreaded their scrutiny. The more briskly they walked, the more briskly walked she. They were plainly bent upon taking a short quick stroll before going indoors to lunch or dinner, to restore warmth to limbs chilled with sitting through a long service.
当他们走近时，她能听到他们正在认真交谈的声音，而且，以她所处的处境中女人天生的敏捷性，她在这些声音中辨认出了她丈夫的语气。行人是他的两个兄弟。苔丝忘记了她所有的计划，唯一的恐惧就是，在她准备好面对他们之前，在她混乱的情况下，他们会追上她。因为虽然她觉得他们无法认出她，但她本能地害怕他们的审视。他们走得越快，她也走得越快。他们显然一心想在进屋吃午饭或晚饭之前快速散步，让因长时间坐着做礼拜而冰冷的四肢恢复温暖。

Only one person had preceded Tess up the hill—a ladylike young woman, somewhat interesting, though, perhaps, a trifle guindée and prudish. Tess had nearly overtaken her when the speed of her brothers-in-law brought them so nearly behind her back that she could hear every word of their conversation. They said nothing, however, which particularly interested her till, observing the young lady still further in front, one of them remarked, ‘There is Mercy Chant. Let us overtake her.’
只有一个人比苔丝先上山——一位淑女般的年轻女子，虽然也许有点拘谨和拘谨，但有点有趣。苔丝差点就超过了她，这时她姐夫的速度几乎把他们带到了她身后，她可以听到他们谈话的每一个字。然而，他们什么也没说，这让她特别感兴趣，直到观察更前面的那位年轻女士，其中一个人说道：“有慈悲圣歌。”让我们追上她吧。

Tess knew the name. It was the woman who had been destined for Angel’s life-companion by his and her parents, and whom he probably would have married but for her intrusive self. She would have known as much without previous information if she had waited a moment, for one of the brothers proceeded to say: ‘Ah! poor Angel, poor Angel! I never see that nice girl without more and more regretting his precipitancy in throwing himself away upon a dairymaid, or whatever she may be. It is a queer business, apparently. Whether she has joined him yet or not I don’t know; but she had not done so some months ago when I heard from him.’
苔丝知道这个名字。这个女人被他和她的父母注定为安吉尔的终身伴侣，如果不是她的侵入性自我，他可能会嫁给她。如果她稍等片刻，即使没有事先的信息，她也会知道这么多，因为其中一个兄弟接着说：“啊！可怜的天使，可怜的天使！我每次见到那个好女孩，都会愈来愈后悔他草率地爱上了一个挤奶女工，或者不管她是什么。显然，这是一件奇怪的事情。我不知道她是否已经加入了他；但几个月前我收到他的消息时，她还没有这样做。”

‘I can’t say. He never tells me anything nowadays. His ill-considered marriage seems to have completed that estrangement from me which was begun by his extraordinary opinions.’
” “我不能说。他现在从来不告诉我任何事情。他考虑不周的婚姻似乎已经完成了与我的疏远，而这种疏远是由他非凡的观点开始的。

Tess beat up the long hill still faster; but she could not outwalk them without exciting notice. At last they outsped her altogether, and passed her by. The young lady still further ahead heard their footsteps and turned. Then there was a greeting and a shaking of hands, and the three went on together.
苔丝更快地爬上了长山。但她无法在不引起令人兴奋的注意的情况下超越他们。最后，他们的速度完全超过了她，超越了她。前方的少女听到他们的脚步声，转过身来。然后互相寒暄、握手，三人就一起继续前行。

They soon reached the summit of the hill, and, evidently intending this point to be the limit of their promenade, slackened pace and turned all three aside to the gate whereat Tess had paused an hour before that time to reconnoitre the town before descending into it. During their discourse one of the clerical brothers probed the hedge carefully with his umbrella, and dragged something to light.
他们很快就到达了山顶，显然打算把这个点作为他​​们散步的终点，于是放慢了脚步，把三个人都转到了大门前，一小时前苔丝曾在那里停下来侦察一下小镇，然后才下山进去。 。在他们的谈话中，一位牧师兄弟用雨伞仔细地探查了树篱，并拖了一些东西去照明。

‘Here’s a pair of old boots,’ he said. ‘Thrown away, I suppose, by some tramp or other.’
“这是一双旧靴子，”他说。 “我想，是被某个流浪汉或其他什么人扔掉的。”

‘Some imposter who wished to come into the town barefoot, perhaps, and so excite our sympathies,’ said Miss Chant. ‘Yes, it must have been, for they are excellent walking-boots—by no means worn out. What a wicked thing to do! I’ll carry them home for some poor person.’
“也许是某个冒名顶替者希望赤脚进城，从而引起我们的同情，”钱特小姐说。 “是的，一定是这样，因为它们是极好的步行靴——决不会磨损。这是多么缺德的事啊！我会把它们带回家送给穷人。”

Cuthbert Clare, who had been the one to find them, picked them up for her with the crook of his stick; and Tess’s boots were appropriated.
卡斯伯特·克莱尔是第一个发现它们的人，他用拐杖帮她捡起了它们。苔丝的靴子被挪用了。

She, who had heard this, walked past under the screen of her woollen veil till, presently looking back, she perceived that the church party had left the gate with her boots and retreated down the hill.
她听了这话，从羊毛纱帘下走过，回头一看，发现教堂里的人已经穿着靴子离开了大门，退到了山下。

Thereupon our heroine resumed her walk. Tears, blinding tears, were running down her face. She knew that it was all sentiment, all baseless impressibility, which had caused her to read the scene as her own condemnation; nevertheless she could not get over it; she could not contravene in her own defenceless person all those untoward omens. It was impossible to think of returning to the Vicarage. Angel’s wife felt almost as if she had been hounded up that hill like a scorned thing by those—to her—superfine clerics. Innocently as the slight had been inflicted, it was somewhat unfortunate that she had encountered the sons and not the father, who, despite his narrowness, was far less starched and ironed than they, and had to the full the gift of charity. As she again thought of her dusty boots she almost pitied those habiliments for the quizzing to which they had been subjected, and felt how hopeless life was for their owner.
于是我们的女主人公又继续行走。泪水，令人眼花缭乱的泪水，从她的脸上流下来。她知道这一切都是感情用事，都是毫无根据的印象，这让她把这一幕解读为对自己的谴责；尽管如此，她还是无法克服这个念头。她无法以她自己毫无防备的身份去违背所有这些不祥的预兆。想回到牧师住宅是不可能的。安吉尔的妻子感觉自己就像被那些——对她来说——超级优秀的神职人员蔑视的东西一样，被赶上了那座山。尽管受到的轻视是无辜的，但不幸的是，她遇到的是儿子们，而不是父亲，父亲尽管心胸狭隘，却远没有他们那么刻板和熨烫，并且完全具有慈善的天赋。当她再次想起她那双沾满灰尘的靴子时，她几乎为这些装备所遭受的考验而感到怜悯，并感到它们的主人的生活是多么绝望。

‘Ah!’ she said, still sighing in pity of herself, ‘THEY didn’t know that I wore those over the roughest part of the road to save these pretty ones HE bought for me—no—they did not know it! And they didn’t think that HE chose the colour o’ my pretty frock—no—how could they? If they had known perhaps they would not have cared, for they don’t care much for him, poor thing!’
“啊！”她说道，仍然自怜自叹，“他们不知道我在最崎岖的路段穿着这些衣服是为了拯救他给我买的这些漂亮的衣服——不——他们不知道！”他们不认为他选择了我漂亮连衣裙的颜色——不——他们怎么可能呢？如果他们知道的话，也许就不会在乎了，因为他们不太关心他，可怜的家伙！

Then she grieved for the beloved man whose conventional standard of judgement had caused her all these latter sorrows; and she went her way without knowing that the greatest misfortune of her life was this feminine loss of courage at the last and critical moment through her estimating her father-in-law by his sons. Her present condition was precisely one which would have enlisted the sympathies of old Mr and Mrs Clare. Their hearts went out of them at a bound towards extreme cases, when the subtle mental troubles of the less desperate among mankind failed to win their interest or regard. In jumping at Publicans and Sinners they would forget that a word might be said for the worries of Scribes and Pharisees; and this defect or limitation might have recommended their own daughter-in-law to them at this moment as a fairly choice sort of lost person for their love.
然后她为心爱的男人感到悲伤，他的传统判断标准给她带来了所有这些后来的悲伤。她走了自己的路，却不知道她一生中最大的不幸就是在最后的关键时刻，通过儿子们对公公的评价而丧失了女性的勇气。她现在的处境正是值得老克莱尔夫妇同情的。当人类中不那么绝望的人的微妙精神困扰未能赢得他们的兴趣或尊重时，他们的心就会立即走向极端的情况。当他们攻击税吏和罪人时，他们会忘记可以对文士和法利赛人的忧虑说一句话。而这种缺陷或限制可能会在此时向他们推荐自己的儿媳妇，作为他们的爱的一个公平选择的迷失者。

Thereupon she began to plod back along the road by which she had come not altogether full of hope, but full of a conviction that a crisis in her life was approaching. No crisis, apparently, had supervened; and there was nothing left for her to do but to continue upon that starve-acre farm till she could again summon courage to face the Vicarage. She did, indeed, take sufficient interest in herself to throw up her veil on this return journey, as if to let the world see that she could at least exhibit a face such as Mercy Chant could not show. But it was done with a sorry shake of the head. ‘It is nothing—it is nothing!’ she said. ‘Nobody loves it; nobody sees it. Who cares about the looks of a castaway like me!’
于是，她开始沿着这条路艰难地往回走，她来时并不完全充满希望，但充满了她生命中的危机正在逼近的信念。显然，并没有发生任何危机。她别无选择，只能继续在那片饥饿的农场里生活，直到她再次鼓起勇气面对牧师住宅。她确实对自己有足够的兴趣，在这次回程中揭开了面纱，仿佛要让世人看到她至少可以展现出慈悲·颂特无法展现的面孔。但这是在抱歉地摇摇头之后完成的。 “没什么——没什么！”她说。 “没有人喜欢它；没有人看到它。谁在乎像我这样的漂​​流者的外表呢！

Her journey back was rather a meander than a march. It had no sprightliness, no purpose; only a tendency. Along the tedious length of Benvill Lane she began to grow tired, and she leant upon gates and paused by milestones.
她回来的旅程与其说是行军，不如说是蜿蜒曲折。它没有活力，没有目的；只是一种倾向。沿着本维尔巷那段乏味的路，她开始感到疲倦，她靠在大门上，在里程碑处停下来。

She did not enter any house till, at the seventh or eighth mile, she descended the steep long hill below which lay the village or townlet of Evershead, where in the morning she had breakfasted with such contrasting expectations. The cottage by the church, in which she again sat down, was almost the first at that end of the village, and while the woman fetched her some milk from the pantry, Tess, looking down the street, perceived that the place seemed quite deserted.
她没有进入任何房子，直到第七或第八英里时，她下了陡峭的长山，下面是埃弗斯黑德的村庄或小镇，早上她怀着截然不同的期望吃过早餐。她再次坐下的教堂旁的小屋，几乎是村子那头的第一间小屋，当那个女人从食品储藏室给她拿一些牛奶时，苔丝朝街道望去，发现这个地方似乎很荒凉。 。

‘The people are gone to afternoon service, I suppose?’ she said.
“我想人们都去参加下午的礼拜了吧？”她说。

‘No, my dear,’ said the old woman. ‘‘Tis too soon for that; the bells hain’t strook out yet. They be all gone to hear the preaching in yonder barn. A ranter preaches there between the services—an excellent, fiery, Christian man, they say. But, Lord, I don’t go to hear’n! What comes in the regular way over the pulpit is hot enough for I.’
“不，亲爱的，”老妇人说。 “现在还为时过早；钟声还没有敲响。他们都去那边谷仓听布道了。礼拜间隙，一名咆哮者在那里布道——他们说，他是一位优秀、热情的基督徒。但是，主啊，我不会去听！讲坛上常见的东西对我来说已经足够热了。

Tess soon went onward into the village, her footsteps echoing against the houses as though it were a place of the dead. Nearing the central part, her echoes were intruded on by other sounds; and seeing the barn not far off the road, she guessed these to be the utterances of the preacher.
苔丝很快就进了村子，她的脚步声在房屋间回响，仿佛那里是死人的地方。接近中央的时候，她的回声就被其他声音干扰了。看到路边不远处的谷仓，她猜这是传教士的话。

His voice became so distinct in the still clear air that she could soon catch his sentences, though she was on the closed side of the barn. The sermon, as might be expected, was of the extremest antinomian type; on justification by faith, as expounded in the theology of St Paul. This fixed idea of the rhapsodist was delivered with animated enthusiasm, in a manner entirely declamatory, for he had plainly no skill as a dialectician. Although Tess had not heard the beginning of the address, she learnt what the text had been from its constant iteration—
他的声音在依然清澈的空气中变得如此清晰，尽管她是在谷仓封闭的一侧，但她很快就能听清他的句子。不出所料，这次布道是最极端的反律法主义类型。正如圣保罗神学中所阐述的那样，因信称义。狂想曲家的这种固定观念是以一种充满激情的热情，以一种完全雄辩的方式表达出来的，因为他显然没有辩证法家的技巧。虽然苔丝没有听到这句话的开头，但她从不断的重复中得知了正文的内容——

“O foolish galatians, who hath bewitched you, that ye
“愚蠢的加拉太人啊，谁迷惑了你们，以致你们

should not obey the truth, before whose eyes Jesus Christ
不应该在耶稣基督的眼前服从真理

hath been evidently set forth, crucified among you?’
已经明显地在你们中间被钉在十字架上了吗？

Tess was all the more interested, as she stood listening behind, in finding that the preacher’s doctrine was a vehement form of the view of Angel’s father, and her interest intensified when the speaker began to detail his own spiritual experiences of how he had come by those views. He had, he said, been the greatest of sinners. He had scoffed; he had wantonly associated with the reckless and the lewd. But a day of awakening had come, and, in a human sense, it had been brought about mainly by the influence of a certain clergyman, whom he had at first grossly insulted; but whose parting words had sunk into his heart, and had remained there, till by the grace of Heaven they had worked this change in him, and made him what they saw him.
苔丝站在后面听，发现传教士的教义是安吉尔父亲观点的强烈形式，她的兴趣更加浓厚，当演讲者开始详细讲述他自己的精神经历以及他如何成长时，她的兴趣更加浓厚。那些观点。他说，他是最大的罪人。他对此嗤之以鼻；他曾肆意与鲁莽和淫荡的人交往。但觉醒的一天已经到来，从人类的意义上来说，这主要是由于某位牧师的影响所带来的，他一开始曾严重侮辱过这位牧师。但他的临别赠言已经深深地印在他的心里，一直留在那里，直到上天的恩典使他发生了这种变化，使他变成了他们所看到的样子。

But more startling to Tess than the doctrine had been the voice, which, impossible as it seemed, was precisely that of Alec d’Urberville. Her face fixed in painful suspense, she came round to the front of the barn, and passed before it. The low winter sun beamed directly upon the great double-doored entrance on this side; one of the doors being open, so that the rays stretched far in over the threshing-floor to the preacher and his audience, all snugly sheltered from the northern breeze. The listeners were entirely villagers, among them being the man whom she had seen carrying the red paint-pot on a former memorable occasion. But her attention was given to the central figure, who stood upon some sacks of corn, facing the people and the door. The three o’clock sun shone full upon him, and the strange enervating conviction that her seducer confronted her, which had been gaining ground in Tess ever since she had heard his words distinctly, was at last established as a fact indeed.
但比这个学说更让苔丝吃惊的是那个声音，尽管看起来不可能，但那声音正是亚历克·德伯维尔的声音。她的脸露出痛苦的悬念，她绕到谷仓前面，从它前面经过。冬日的低照直接照在这边巨大的双门入口上。其中一扇门开着，光线从打谷场的上方延伸到牧师和他的听众身上，他们都被舒适地遮挡住了北风。听众全是村民，其中就有她在一次难忘的场合看到的那个拿着红色油漆罐的男人。但她的注意力集中在中心人物身上，他站在几袋玉米上，面向人群和门。三点钟的阳光照在他身上，自从苔丝清楚地听到他的话以来，她心里就一直有一种奇怪的、令人沮丧的信念，那就是她的诱惑者正在面对她，这种信念最终被证实为事实。

END OF PHASE THE FIFTH
第五阶段结束

Phase the Sixth: The Convert
第六阶段：皈依

XLV

Till this moment she had never seen or heard from d’Urberville since her departure from Trantridge.
自从她离开特兰特里奇以来，直到此刻，她还没有见过德伯维尔，也没有听到过他的消息。

The rencounter came at a heavy moment, one of all moments calculated to permit its impact with the least emotional shock. But such was unreasoning memory that, though he stood there openly and palpably a converted man, who was sorrowing for his past irregularities, a fear overcame her, paralyzing her movement so that she neither retreated nor advanced.
这次相遇发生在一个沉重的时刻，这是所有精心设计的时刻之一，以使其影响力最小化。但这是一种不合理的记忆，尽管他站在那儿，明显地是一个悔改的人，为自己过去的不道德行为而悲伤，但恐惧却战胜了她，麻痹了她的行动，使她既不后退也不前进。

To think of what emanated from that countenance when she saw it last, and to behold it now! ... There was the same handsome unpleasantness of mien, but now he wore neatly trimmed, old-fashioned whiskers, the sable moustache having disappeared; and his dress was half-clerical, a modification which had changed his expression sufficiently to abstract the dandyism from his features, and to hinder for a second her belief in his identity.
想想她上次看到那张脸时的表情，现在再看看它！ ……他的面容依然英俊但令人不快，但现在他留着修剪整齐的老式胡须，黑貂胡子已经消失了；他的着装是半教士式的，这种改变足以改变他的表情，足以从他的容貌中抽象出花花公子的气质，并暂时阻碍了她对他身份的信念。

To Tess’s sense there was, just at first, a ghastly bizarrerie, a grim incongruity, in the march of these solemn words of Scripture out of such a mouth. This too familiar intonation, less than four years earlier, had brought to her ears expressions of such divergent purpose that her heart became quite sick at the irony of the contrast.
在苔丝看来，从这样的嘴里说出这些庄严的圣经话语，一开始就充满了可怕的怪异和严酷的不协调。不到四年前，这种过于熟悉的语调给她带来了如此不同目的的表达，以至于她的心因这种反差而感到非常恶心。

It was less a reform than a transfiguration. The former curves of sensuousness were now modulated to lines of devotional passion. The lip-shapes that had meant seductiveness were now made to express supplication; the glow on the cheek that yesterday could be translated as riotousness was evangelized to-day into the splendour of pious rhetoric; animalism had become fanaticism; Paganism, Paulinism; the bold rolling eye that had flashed upon her form in the old time with such mastery now beamed with the rude energy of a theolatry that was almost ferocious. Those black angularities which his face had used to put on when his wishes were thwarted now did duty in picturing the incorrigible backslider who would insist upon turning again to his wallowing in the mire.
与其说这是一次改革，不如说这是一次变形。以前的感性曲线现在被调整为虔诚激情的线条。原本意味着诱惑的唇形，现在变成了表达恳求的唇形。昨天脸上的光彩还可以被翻译为狂欢，今天却变成了虔诚的言辞的辉煌。兽性主义已经变成了狂热主义；异教、保林主义；昔日那双大胆的转动的眼睛在她的身材上闪现出如此熟练的光芒，现在闪烁着一种近乎凶猛的理论的粗鲁能量。当他的愿望遭到挫败时，他脸上的那些黑色棱角现在确实有责任描绘出那个不可救药的后退者，他会坚持再次在泥潭中打滚。

The lineaments, as such, seemed to complain. They had been diverted from their hereditary connotation to signify impressions for which Nature did not intend them. Strange that their very elevation was a misapplication, that to raise seemed to falsify.
轮廓本身似乎在抱怨。它们已经脱离了其遗传内涵，转而表示大自然无意的印象。奇怪的是，他们的抬高本身就是一种误用，抬高似乎是伪造的。

Yet could it be so? She would admit the ungenerous sentiment no longer. D’Urberville was not the first wicked man who had turned away from his wickedness to save his soul alive, and why should she deem it unnatural in him? It was but the usage of thought which had been jarred in her at hearing good new words in bad old notes. The greater the sinner, the greater the saint; it was not necessary to dive far into Christian history to discover that.
但事情可能是这样吗？她不会再承认这种不慷慨的情绪了。德伯维尔并不是第一个为了拯救自己的灵魂而放弃邪恶的恶人，她为什么会认为他这样做是不自然的呢？当她在糟糕的旧音符中听到好听的新词时，这只是她的思维使用方式感到不舒服。罪人越伟大，圣人就越伟大；无需深入研究基督教历史就能发现这一点。

Such impressions as these moved her vaguely, and without strict definiteness. As soon as the nerveless pause of her surprise would allow her to stir, her impulse was to pass on out of his sight. He had obviously not discerned her yet in her position against the sun.
这些印象让她模糊地感动，而且没有严格的确定性。一旦她因惊讶而毫无勇气地停下来，一动起来，她就会冲动地想离开他的视线。显然，他还没有认出她在阳光下的位置。

But the moment that she moved again he recognized her. The effect upon her old lover was electric, far stronger than the effect of his presence upon her. His fire, the tumultuous ring of his eloquence, seemed to go out of him. His lip struggled and trembled under the words that lay upon it; but deliver them it could not as long as she faced him. His eyes, after their first glance upon her face, hung confusedly in every other direction but hers, but came back in a desperate leap every few seconds. This paralysis lasted, however, but a short time; for Tess’s energies returned with the atrophy of his, and she walked as fast as she was able past the barn and onward.
但当她再次动弹的那一刻，他就认出了她。这对她的旧情人的影响是强烈的，比他的出现对她的影响要强烈得多。他的热情，他雄辩的喧嚣，似乎都从他身上消失了。他的嘴唇因上面的话而挣扎、颤抖。但只要她面对他，就无法传递它们。他的眼睛在第一眼看到她的脸后，就迷茫地朝除了她的方向以外的其他方向看去，但每隔几秒钟就会绝望地跳回来。然而，这种瘫痪只持续了很短的时间。因为苔丝的精力随着他的萎缩而恢复了，她尽可能快地走过谷仓，继续前进。

As soon as she could reflect, it appalled her, this change in their relative platforms. He who had wrought her undoing was now on the side of the Spirit, while she remained unregenerate. And, as in the legend, it had resulted that her Cyprian image had suddenly appeared upon his altar, whereby the fire of the priest had been well nigh extinguished.
当她回想起来时，他们相对平台的这种变​​化让她感到震惊。那个毁掉她的人现在站在圣灵一边，而她却仍未重生。而且，正如传说中的那样，结果是她的西普里安形象突然出现在他的祭坛上，牧师的火焰几乎被扑灭了。

She went on without turning her head. Her back seemed to be endowed with a sensitiveness to ocular beams—even her clothing—so alive was she to a fancied gaze which might be resting upon her from the outside of that barn. All the way along to this point her heart had been heavy with an inactive sorrow; now there was a change in the quality of its trouble. That hunger for affection too long withheld was for the time displaced by an almost physical sense of an implacable past which still engirdled her. It intensified her consciousness of error to a practical despair; the break of continuity between her earlier and present existence, which she had hoped for, had not, after all, taken place. Bygones would never be complete bygones till she was a bygone herself.
她头也不回地继续往前走。她的后背似乎对光线——甚至是她的衣服——都非常敏感，她对可能从谷仓外面落在她身上的幻想目光如此活跃。一直以来，她的心都被一种无为的悲伤所沉重。现在麻烦的性质发生了变化。那种对感情的渴望被压抑得太久，暂时被一种几乎是身体上的、难以平复的过去的感觉所取代，而这种感觉仍然包围着她。这让她更加意识到自己的错误，甚至陷入了绝望。她所希望的她以前和现在的存在之间的连续性的断裂毕竟没有发生。除非她自己成为过去，否则过去的事永远不会完全过去。

Thus absorbed, she recrossed the northern part of Long-Ash Lane at right angles, and presently saw before her the road ascending whitely to the upland along whose margin the remainder of her journey lay. Its dry pale surface stretched severely onward, unbroken by a single figure, vehicle, or mark, save some occasional brown horse-droppings which dotted its cold aridity here and there. While slowly breasting this ascent Tess became conscious of footsteps behind her, and turning she saw approaching that well-known form—so strangely accoutred as the Methodist—the one personage in all the world she wished not to encounter alone on this side of the grave.
就这样，她全神贯注地重新以直角穿过了长灰巷的北部，不久就看到了她面前的道路呈白色上升到高地，她剩下的旅程就沿着高地的边缘而行。它干燥苍白的表面严重地向前延伸，没有任何一个人影、车辆或标记，除了偶尔有一些棕色的马粪点缀在寒冷干燥的土地上。当苔丝慢慢地攀登时，她意识到身后有脚步声，转身时，她看到那个众所周知的身影正在接近——与卫理公会教徒一样奇怪的装扮——世界上她不希望在坟墓的这一边单独遇到的人物。 。

There was not much time, however, for thought or elusion, and she yielded as calmly as she could to the necessity of letting him overtake her. She saw that he was excited, less by the speed of his walk than by the feelings within him.
然而，没有太多时间思考或逃避，她尽可能平静地屈服于让他超越她的必要性。她看到他很兴奋，与其说是因为他走路的速度，不如说是因为他内心的感受。

‘Tess!’ he said.
“苔丝！”他说。

She slackened speed without looking round.
她放慢了速度，没有回头看。

‘Tess!’ he repeated. ‘It is I—Alec d’Urberville.’
“苔丝！”他重复道。 “是我——亚历克·德伯维尔。”

She then looked back at him, and he came up.
然后她回头看了他一眼，他就走了过来。

‘I see it is,’ she answered coldly.
“我明白了，”她冷冷地回答。

‘Well—is that all? Yet I deserve no more! Of course,’ he added, with a slight laugh, ‘there is something of the ridiculous to your eyes in seeing me like this. But—I must put up with that. ... I heard you had gone away; nobody knew where. Tess, you wonder why I have followed you?’
‘嗯——就这些了吗？但我不配再这样了！当然，”他微微一笑，补充道，“在你看来，我这个样子有些可笑。但是——我必须忍受。 ……我听说你走了；没有人知道在哪里。苔丝，你想知道我为什么跟着你吗？

‘I do, rather; and I would that you had not, with all my heart!’
“我确实如此；我真心希望你没有这么做！

‘Yes—you may well say it,’ he returned grimly, as they moved onward together, she with unwilling tread. ‘But don’t mistake me; I beg this because you may have been led to do so in noticing—if you did notice it—how your sudden appearance unnerved me down there. It was but a momentary faltering; and considering what you have been to me, it was natural enough. But will helped me through it—though perhaps you think me a humbug for saying it—and immediately afterwards I felt that of all persons in the world whom it was my duty and desire to save from the wrath to come—sneer if you like—the woman whom I had so grievously wronged was that person. I have come with that sole purpose in view—nothing more.’
“是的——你可以这么说，”他冷酷地回答道，他们一起向前走，而她则不情愿地迈着脚步。 “但请不要误会我；我之所以这么请求，是因为你可能是在注意到——如果你确实注意到了——你的突然出现让我在那里感到不安时才这么做的。这只是一时的摇摇欲坠；考虑到你对我的影响，这是很自然的。但威尔帮助我度过了难关——尽管也许你认为我这么说是个骗子——之后我立即感到，在世界上所有的人中，我有责任和愿望将他们从即将到来的愤怒中拯救出来——如果你愿意，可以嘲笑——那个被我冤枉的女人就是那个人。我来这里的唯一目的就是——仅此而已。”

There was the smallest vein of scorn in her words of rejoinder: ‘Have you saved yourself? Charity begins at home, they say.’
她反驳的话语中带着一丝轻蔑：‘你救了自己吗？他们说，慈善始于家庭。

‘I have done nothing!’ said he indifferently. ‘Heaven, as I have been telling my hearers, has done all. No amount of contempt that you can pour upon me, Tess, will equal what I have poured upon myself—the old Adam of my former years! Well, it is a strange story; believe it or not; but I can tell you the means by which my conversion was brought about, and I hope you will be interested enough at least to listen. Have you ever heard the name of the parson of Emminster—you must have done do?—old Mr Clare; one of the most earnest of his school; one of the few intense men left in the Church; not so intense as the extreme wing of Christian believers with which I have thrown in my lot, but quite an exception among the Established clergy, the younger of whom are gradually attenuating the true doctrines by their sophistries, till they are but the shadow of what they were. I only differ from him on the question of Church and State—the interpretation of the text, ‘Come out from among them and be ye separate, saith the Lord’—that’s all. He is one who, I firmly believe, has been the humble means of saving more souls in this country than any other man you can name. You have heard of him?’
“我什么也没做！”他冷漠地说。 ‘正如我一直告诉听众的那样，天堂已经完成了一切。苔丝，你对我的蔑视再多，也抵不过我对自己——我早年的老亚当——的蔑视！嗯，这是一个奇怪的故事；信不信由你;但我可以告诉你我转变的方式，我希望你至少有足够的兴趣来听。你听说过埃明斯特牧师的名字吗——你一定听说过吧？——老克莱尔先生；他的学校里最认真的人之一；教会中仅存的少数坚强的人之一；不像我所加入的基督教信徒的极端派那么强烈，但在国教神职人员中却是一个例外，他们中的年轻人正在通过他们的诡辩逐渐削弱真正的教义，直到他们只是什么的影子。他们是。我与他的不同之处仅在于教会与国家的问题上——对文本的解释，“主说，从他们中间出来，与他们分开”——仅此而已。我坚信，他是这个国家拯救更多灵魂的卑微手段，比任何你能说出名字的人都要多。你听说过他吗？

‘I have,’ she said.
“我有，”她说。

‘He came to Trantridge two or three years ago to preach on behalf of some missionary society; and I, wretched fellow that I was, insulted him when, in his disinterestedness, he tried to reason with me and show me the way. He did not resent my conduct, he simply said that some day I should receive the first-fruits of the Spirit—that those who came to scoff sometimes remained to pray. There was a strange magic in his words. They sank into my mind. But the loss of my mother hit me most; and by degrees I was brought to see daylight. Since then my one desire has been to hand on the true view to others, and that is what I was trying to do to-day; though it is only lately that I have preached hereabout. The first months of my ministry have been spent in the North of England among strangers, where I preferred to make my earliest clumsy attempts, so as to acquire courage before undergoing that severest of all tests of one’s sincerity, addressing those who have known one, and have been one’s companions in the days of darkness. If you could only know, Tess, the pleasure of having a good slap at yourself, I am sure—‘
“两三年前，他来到特兰特里奇，代表某个传教团体传教；当他无私地试图跟我讲道理并给我指路时，我这个可怜的家伙就侮辱了他。他并不怨恨我的行为，他只是说有一天我会领受圣灵初熟的果子——那些前来嘲笑的人有时会留下来祈祷。他的话里有一种奇怪的魔力。他们深深地印在我的脑海里。但失去母亲对我打击最大。渐渐地，我看到了阳光。从那时起，我的一个愿望就是将正见传授给他人，这就是我今天所做的努力；尽管我只是最近才在这方面宣讲。我事工的头几个月是在英格兰北部的陌生人中间度过的，在那里我宁愿做出最早的笨拙尝试，以便在接受对一个人的诚意最严格的考验之前获得勇气，向那些认识的人讲话，并在黑暗的日子里成为人们的同伴。苔丝，如果你能知道扇自己一巴掌是多么快乐，我相信——”

‘Don’t go on with it!’ she cried passionately, as she turned away from him to a stile by the wayside, on which she bent herself. ‘I can’t believe in such sudden things! I feel indignant with you for talking to me like this, when you know—when you know what harm you’ve done me! You, and those like you, take your fill of pleasure on earth by making the life of such as me bitter and black with sorrow; and then it is a fine thing, when you have had enough of that, to think of securing your pleasure in heaven by becoming converted! Out upon such—I don’t believe in you—I hate it!’
“不要再这样下去了！”她激动地喊道，同时转身走到路边的一个栅栏上，弯下腰。 ‘我简直不敢相信这么突然的事情！我对你这样跟我说话感到愤怒，当你知道——当你知道你对我造成了多大的伤害！你和那些像你一样的人，在地球上享受快乐，却让像我这样的人的生活充满悲伤和痛苦；当你受够了这些之后，想到通过皈依来确保你在天堂的快乐，这是一件好事！就这样——我不相信你——我讨厌它！

‘Tess,’ he insisted; ‘don’t speak so! It came to me like a jolly new idea! And you don’t believe me? What don’t you believe?’
“苔丝，”他坚持道。 ‘别这么说！这对我来说就像一个令人愉快的新想法！你不相信我吗？你不相信什么？

‘Your conversion. Your scheme of religion.’
‘你的转变。你的宗教计划。

‘Why?’
'为什么？'

She dropped her voice. ‘Because a better man than you does not believe in such.’
她压低了声音。 “因为比你更好的人不会相信这样的事。”

‘What a woman’s reason! Who is this better man?’
‘这是多么女人的理由啊！这个更好的人是谁？

‘I cannot tell you.’
'我不能告诉你。'

‘Well,’ he declared, a resentment beneath his words seeming ready to spring out at a moment’s notice, ‘God forbid that I should say I am a good man—and you know I don’t say any such thing. I am new to goodness, truly; but newcomers see furthest sometimes.’
“好吧，”他宣称，言语中的怨恨似乎随时会爆发出来，“上帝禁止我说我是一个好人——你知道我不会说任何这样的话。确实，我对善良还很陌生；但有时新人看得最远。”

‘Yes,’ she replied sadly. ‘But I cannot believe in your conversion to a new spirit. Such flashes as you feel, Alec, I fear don’t last!’
“是的，”她悲伤地回答。 “但我无法相信你会转变为新的精神。亚历克，你所感受到的这种闪光恐怕不会持续太久！

Thus speaking she turned from the stile over which she had been leaning, and faced him; whereupon his eyes, falling casually upon the familiar countenance and form, remained contemplating her. The inferior man was quiet in him now; but it was surely not extracted, nor even entirely subdued.
说着，她从原来靠着的栏杆上转过身来，面对着他。于是，他的目光漫不经心地落在那张熟悉的面容和身材上，仍然注视着她。现在，他内心的低等人已经安静下来了。但它肯定没有被提取出来，甚至也没有被完全抑制。

‘Don’t look at me like that!’ he said abruptly.
“别这样看着我！”他突然说道。

Tess, who had been quite unconscious of her action and mien, instantly withdrew the large dark gaze of her eyes, stammering with a flush, ‘I beg your pardon!’ And there was revived in her the wretched sentiment which had often come to her before, that in inhabiting the fleshly tabernacle with which Nature had endowed her she was somehow doing wrong.
苔丝完全没有意识到自己的举动和神情，立刻收回了那双乌黑的大眼睛，满脸通红，结结巴巴地说：“请原谅！”她身上又恢复了以前常有的悲惨情绪。以前，她居住在大自然赋予她的肉身圣殿中，不知何故做错了。

‘No, no! Don’t beg my pardon. But since you wear a veil to hide your good looks, why don’t you keep it down?’
'不，不！不要乞求我的原谅。但既然你戴面纱是为了隐藏你的美貌，为什么不把它低调一点呢？

She pulled down the veil, saying hastily, ‘It was mostly to keep off the wind.’
她拉下面纱，急忙道：“主要是为了挡风。”

‘It may seem harsh of me to dictate like this,’ he went on; ‘but it is better that I should not look too often on you. It might be dangerous.’
“这样发号施令似乎对我来说很苛刻，”他继续说道。 ‘但我最好不要经常看你。这可能很危险。

‘Ssh!’ said Tess.
“嘘！”苔丝说。

‘Well, women’s faces have had too much power over me already for me not to fear them! An evangelist has nothing to do with such as they; and it reminds me of the old times that I would forget!’
“嗯，女人的脸对我来说已经有太多的力量了，我不能再害怕她们了！”传福音的人与他们无关。它让我想起了我会忘记的旧时光！

After this their conversation dwindled to a casual remark now and then as they rambled onward, Tess inwardly wondering how far he was going with her, and not liking to send him back by positive mandate. Frequently when they came to a gate or stile they found painted thereon in red or blue letters some text of Scripture, and she asked him if he knew who had been at the pains to blazon these announcements. He told her that the man was employed by himself and others who were working with him in that district, to paint these reminders that no means might be left untried which might move the hearts of a wicked generation.
此后，他们的谈话逐渐减少为时不时的闲聊，他们继续前行，苔丝内心想知道他和她到底要走多远，而且不喜欢以明确的命令把他送回来。通常，当他们来到大门或栅栏时，他们会发现上面用红色或蓝色的字母画着一些经文，她问他是否知道是谁煞费苦心地张贴了这些公告。他告诉她，这个人受雇于他自己和在那个地区与他一起工作的其他人，画这些提醒人们，任何可能感动邪恶一代人的心的方法都不能不尝试。

At length the road touched the spot called ‘Cross-in-Hand.’ Of all spots on the bleached and desolate upland this was the most forlorn. It was so far removed from the charm which is sought in landscape by artists and view-lovers as to reach a new kind of beauty, a negative beauty of tragic tone. The place took its name from a stone pillar which stood there, a strange rude monolith, from a stratum unknown in any local quarry, on which was roughly carved a human hand. Differing accounts were given of its history and purport. Some authorities stated that a devotional cross had once formed the complete erection thereon, of which the present relic was but the stump; others that the stone as it stood was entire, and that it had been fixed there to mark a boundary or place of meeting. Anyhow, whatever the origin of the relic, there was and is something sinister, or solemn, according to mood, in the scene amid which it stands; something tending to impress the most phlegmatic passer-by.
最后，道路到达了一个叫做“交叉手”的地方。在这片白化、荒凉的高地上的所有地方中，这是最荒凉的地方。它与艺术家和观赏者所追求的风景魅力相差甚远，而达到了一种新的美，一种悲剧基调的消极美。这个地方得名于矗立在那里的一根石柱，这是一块奇怪的粗制巨石，来自当地采石场未知的地层，上面粗略地刻着一个人的手。关于它的历史和主旨，人们有不同的说法。一些权威人士称，一个虔诚的十字架曾经在其上完整地竖立起来，现在的遗迹只是其树桩；另一些人则认为，这块石头是完整的，它被固定在那里是为了标记边界或聚会地点。无论如何，无论这件遗物的起源如何，它所处的场景过去和现在都存在着某种险恶或庄严的东西，这取决于心情；往往会给最冷漠的路人留下深刻印象的东西。

‘I think I must leave you now,’ he remarked, as they drew near to this spot. ‘I have to preach at Abbot’s-Cernel at six this evening, and my way lies across to the right from here. And you upset me somewhat too, Tessy—I cannot, will not, say why. I must go away and get strength. ... How is it that you speak so fluently now? Who has taught you such good English?’
“我想我现在必须离开你了，”当他们接近这个地方时，他说道。 “今天晚上六点我必须在方丈中心讲道，我的路就在这儿的右边。你也让我有些不安，泰西——我不能也不会说出为什么。我必须离开并获得力量。 ……你现在说话怎么这么流利了？谁教你这么好的英语？

‘I have learnt things in my troubles,’ she said evasively.
“我从麻烦中学到了东西，”她闪烁其词地说。

‘What troubles have you had?’
“你遇到过什么麻烦吗？”

She told him of the first one—the only one that related to him.
她告诉他第一个——唯一一个与他有关的。

D’Urberville was struck mute. ‘I knew nothing of this till now!’ he next murmured. ‘Why didn’t you write to me when you felt your trouble coming on?’
德伯维尔哑口无言。 “到目前为止我对此一无所知！”他接着低声说道。 “当你感到麻烦来临时，为什么不写信给我？”

She did not reply; and he broke the silence by adding: ‘Well—you will see me again.’
她没有回答；他打破了沉默，补充道：“好吧——你会再见到我的。”

‘No,’ she answered. ‘Do not again come near me!’
“不，”她回答。 “不要再靠近我！”

‘I will think. But before we part come here.’ He stepped up to the pillar. ‘This was once a Holy Cross. Relics are not in my creed; but I fear you at moments—far more than you need fear me at present; and to lessen my fear, put your hand upon that stone hand, and swear that you will never tempt me—by your charms or ways.’
'我会想。但在我们分手之前，先来这里吧。”他走到柱子前。 “这曾经是一个圣十字。我的信条里没有遗物；但我有时会害怕你——远远超过你现在需要害怕我的程度；为了减轻我的恐惧，请将你的手放在那只石头手上，并发誓你永远不会用你的魅力或方式来诱惑我。

‘Good God—how can you ask what is so unnecessary! All that is furthest from my thought!’
‘天啊——你怎么能问这么不必要的事情呢！这一切都与我的想法相去甚远！

‘Yes—but swear it.’
“是的——但是发誓。”

Tess, half frightened, gave way to his importunity; placed her hand upon the stone and swore.
苔丝有些害怕，屈服于他的恳求。她把手放在石头上并发誓。

‘I am sorry you are not a believer,’ he continued; ‘that some unbeliever should have got hold of you and unsettled your mind. But no more now. At home at least I can pray for you; and I will; and who knows what may not happen? I’m off. Goodbye!’
“我很抱歉你不是信徒，”他继续说道。 ‘某个不信者应该抓住你并扰乱你的思想。但现在不再了。至少在家里我可以为你祈祷；我会的;谁知道什么可能不会发生呢？我走了。再见！'

He turned to a hunting-gate in the hedge and, without letting his eyes again rest upon her, leapt over and struck out across the down in the direction of Abbot’s-Cernel. As he walked his pace showed perturbation, and by-and-by, as if instigated by a former thought, he drew from his pocket a small book, between the leaves of which was folded a letter, worn and soiled, as from much re-reading. D’Urberville opened the letter. It was dated several months before this time, and was signed by Parson Clare.
他转向树篱中的一扇狩猎门，眼睛没有再停留在她身上，而是跳了过去，穿过低地，朝修道院院长的方向走去。他走路时步伐显得慌乱，渐渐地，仿佛受到了先前的想法的煽动，他从口袋里掏出一本小书，书页之间夹着一封信，又旧又脏，好像是从很长的时间里写下来的。 -阅读。德伯维尔打开了信。它的日期是在此之前几个月，并由克莱尔牧师签署。

The letter began by expressing the writer’s unfeigned joy at d’Urberville’s conversion, and thanked him for his kindness in communicating with the parson on the subject. It expressed Mr Clare’s warm assurance of forgiveness for d’Urberville’s former conduct and his interest in the young man’s plans for the future. He, Mr Clare, would much have liked to see d’Urberville in the Church to whose ministry he had devoted so many years of his own life, and would have helped him to enter a theological college to that end; but since his correspondent had possibly not cared to do this on account of the delay it would have entailed, he was not the man to insist upon its paramount importance. Every man must work as he could best work, and in the method towards which he felt impelled by the Spirit.
这封信首先表达了作者对德伯维尔皈依的由衷的喜悦，并感谢他在这个问题上与牧师沟通的善意。它表达了克莱尔先生对德伯维尔以前的行为的热情宽恕，以及他对这个年轻人未来计划的兴趣。他，克莱尔先生，非常希望看到德伯维尔加入教会，他为教会的事工奉献了自己多年的生命，并会为此帮助他进入一所神学院。但由于他的通讯员可能因为会造成延误而不愿意这样做，所以他不是坚持这一点至高无上的人。每个人都必须尽其所能地工作，并以他感受到圣灵推动的方式工作。

D’Urberville read and re-read this letter, and seemed to quiz himself cynically. He also read some passages from memoranda as he walked till his face assumed a calm, and apparently the image of Tess no longer troubled his mind.
德伯维尔读了又读这封信，似乎在愤世嫉俗地自问。他一边走一边读着备忘录中的一些段落，直到他的脸色变得平静，显然苔丝的形象不再困扰他的脑海。

She meanwhile had kept along the edge of the hill by which lay her nearest way home. Within the distance of a mile she met a solitary shepherd.
与此同时，她一直沿着山边走，那里是她最近回家的路。不到一英里的距离，她遇到了一个孤独的牧羊人。

‘What is the meaning of that old stone I have passed?’ she asked of him. ‘Was it ever a Holy Cross?’
“我经过的那块老石头有什么意义？”她问他。 “它曾经是一个圣十字吗？”

‘Cross—no; ‘twer not a cross! ‘Tis a thing of ill-omen, Miss. It was put up in wuld times by the relations of a malefactor who was tortured there by nailing his hand to a post and afterwards hung. The bones lie underneath. They say he sold his soul to the devil, and that he walks at times.’
‘十字——不； ‘不是十字架！ “这是一个不祥之物，小姐。这是一个恶棍在荒世时的亲戚们竖起的，他在那里受到了酷刑，把他的手钉在柱子上，然后被绞死。骨头就在下面。他们说他把灵魂出卖给了魔鬼，而且他有时会走路。

She felt the petite mort at this unexpectedly gruesome information, and left the solitary man behind her. It was dusk when she drew near to Flintcomb-Ash, and in the lane at the entrance to the hamlet she approached a girl and her lover without their observing her. They were talking no secrets, and the clear unconcerned voice of the young woman, in response to the warmer accents of the man, spread into the chilly air as the one soothing thing within the dusky horizon, full of a stagnant obscurity upon which nothing else intruded. For a moment the voices cheered the heart of Tess, till she reasoned that this interview had its origin, on one side or the other, in the same attraction which had been the prelude to her own tribulation. When she came close, the girl turned serenely and recognized her, the young man walking off in embarrassment. The woman was Izz Huett, whose interest in Tess’s excursion immediately superseded her own proceedings. Tess did not explain very clearly its results, and Izz, who was a girl of tact, began to speak of her own little affair, a phase of which Tess had just witnessed.
听到这个出人意料的可怕信息，她感到心如死灰，把那个孤独的男人留在了身后。当她接近弗林特库姆·阿什时，已是黄昏时分，在村庄入口处的小巷里，她走近一个女孩和她的情人，而她们却没有注意到她。他们没有秘密地谈论着，年轻女子清晰而漠不关心的声音，回应着男人温暖的口音，蔓延到寒冷的空气中，就像昏暗的地平线上唯一令人舒缓的东西，充满了一种停滞的模糊，没有其他东西。闯入了。有一瞬间，这些声音让苔丝的心欢欣鼓舞，直到她推断这次采访的起源，无论从哪一方面，都与她自己的苦难前奏的吸引力相同。当她走近时，女孩平静地转过身，认出了她，而年轻人则尴尬地走开了。这个女人就是伊兹·休特（Izz Huett），她对苔丝旅行的兴趣立即取代了她自己的兴趣。苔丝并没有很清楚地解释其结果，而机智的伊兹则开始讲述她自己的小事，苔丝刚刚目睹了这一过程。

‘He is Amby Seedling, the chap who used to sometimes come and help at Talbothays,’ she explained indifferently. ‘He actually inquired and found out that I had come here, and has followed me. He says he’s been in love wi’ me these two years. But I’ve hardly answered him.’
“他是安比·西德林（Amby Seedling），以前有时会来塔尔博塞斯帮忙的小伙子，”她冷漠地解释道。 ‘他居然打探过，得知我来过这里，而且还跟着我。他说他这两年一直爱着我。但我几乎没有回答他。

XLVI
四十六

Several days had passed since her futile journey, and Tess was afield. The dry winter wind still blew, but a screen of thatched hurdles erected in the eye of the blast kept its force away from her. On the sheltered side was a turnip-slicing machine, whose bright blue hue of new paint seemed almost vocal in the otherwise subdued scene. Opposite its front was a long mound or ‘grave’, in which the roots had been preserved since early winter. Tess was standing at the uncovered end, chopping off with a bill-hook the fibres and earth from each root, and throwing it after the operation into the slicer. A man was turning the handle of the machine, and from its trough came the newly-cut swedes, the fresh smell of whose yellow chips was accompanied by the sounds of the snuffling wind, the smart swish of the slicing-blades, and the choppings of the hook in Tess’s leather-gloved hand.
距离这次徒劳无功的旅程已经过去了好几天，苔丝还在外地。干燥的冬风仍然吹着，但风眼里竖起的茅草栅栏屏障挡住了她的力量。受庇护的一侧是一台萝卜切片机，其新油漆的亮蓝色调在原本柔和的场景中几乎显得很响亮。它的正面对面是一个长长的土堆或“坟墓”，自初冬以来，树根就一直保存在其中。苔丝站在没有覆盖的一端，用钩子把每根根部的纤维和泥土砍下来，然后把它扔进切片机里。一个男人正在转动机器的手柄，刚切好的瑞典薯片从槽里出来，黄色薯片的新鲜气味伴随着呼呼的风声、切片刀片的聪明的嗖嗖声和切菜的声音。苔丝戴着皮手套的手上的钩子。

The wide acreage of blank agricultural brownness, apparent where the swedes had been pulled, was beginning to be striped in wales of darker brown, gradually broadening to ribands. Along the edge of each of these something crept upon ten legs, moving without haste and without rest up and down the whole length of the field; it was two horses and a man, the plough going between them, turning up the cleared ground for a spring sowing.
瑞典人被拖走的地方，大片空白的农业棕色土地开始出现深棕色的条纹，逐渐扩大为罗纹。沿着每条路的边缘，有东西用十条腿爬行，在整个田野上不紧不慢地走来走去。那是两匹马和一个人，犁在他们之间穿行，翻开清理过的土地，准备春播。

For hours nothing relieved the joyless monotony of things. Then, far beyond the ploughing-teams, a black speck was seen. It had come from the corner of a fence, where there was a gap, and its tendency was up the incline, towards the swede-cutters. From the proportions of a mere point it advanced to the shape of a ninepin, and was soon perceived to be a man in black, arriving from the direction of Flintcomb-Ash. The man at the slicer, having nothing else to do with his eyes, continually observed the comer, but Tess, who was occupied, did not perceive him till her companion directed her attention to his approach.
几个小时以来，没有任何事情可以缓解单调乏味的气氛。然后，在犁地队的远处，看到了一个黑点。它来自栅栏的一角，那里有一个缺口，它的趋势是沿着斜坡向上，朝向瑞典切割机。它从一个点的比例发展到九柱球的形状，很快就被认为是一个黑衣人，从弗林特科姆·阿什的方向而来。切片机旁的那个人，眼睛无事可做，不断地观察着角落，但正忙着的苔丝没有注意到他，直到她的同伴将注意力集中到他的走近上。

It was not her hard taskmaster, Farmer Groby; it was one in a semi-clerical costume, who now represented what had once been the free-and-easy Alec d’Urberville. Not being hot at his preaching there was less enthusiasm about him now, and the presence of the grinder seemed to embarrass him. A pale distress was already on Tess’s face, and she pulled her curtained hood further over it.
这不是她严厉的监工农夫格罗比；而是她的父亲。那是一个穿着半教士服装的人，现在代表的是曾经自由自在的亚历克·德伯维尔。他不再热衷于他的讲道，现在对他的热情也减少了，磨床的出现似乎让他感到尴尬。苔丝的脸上已经出现了苍白的痛苦，她把带帘子的兜帽拉得更深了。

D’Urberville came up and said quietly—
德伯维尔走过来，轻声说道——

‘I want to speak to you, Tess.’
“我想和你谈谈，苔丝。”

‘You have refused my last request, not to come near me!’ said she.
“你拒绝了我最后的请求，不要靠近我！”她说。

‘Yes, but I have a good reason.’
“是的，但我有充分的理由。”

‘Well, tell it.’
“好吧，说吧。”

‘It is more serious than you may think.’
“这比你想象的更严重。”

He glanced round to see if he were overheard. They were at some distance from the man who turned the slicer, and the movement of the machine, too, sufficiently prevented Alec’s words reaching other ears. D’Urberville placed himself so as to screen Tess from the labourer, turning his back to the latter.
他环顾四周，看看他的话是否被人听见。他们距离转动切片机的人还有一段距离，而机器的移动也足以阻止亚历克的话传到其他人的耳朵里。德伯维尔转身背对着工人，把苔丝与工人隔开。

‘It is this,’ he continued, with capricious compunction. ‘In thinking of your soul and mine when we last met, I neglected to inquire as to your worldly condition. You were well dressed, and I did not think of it. But I see now that it is hard—harder than it used to be when I—knew you—harder than you deserve. Perhaps a good deal of it is owning to me!’
“就是这个，”他带着反复无常的悔恨继续说道。 “当我们上次见面时，我想起了你我的灵魂，却忽略了询问你们的世俗状况。你穿得很好，我没想到。但我现在发现这很难——比我认识你的时候更难——比你应得的更难。也许其中很大一部分都属于我！

She did not answer, and he watched her inquiringly, as, with bent head, her face completely screened by the hood, she resumed her trimming of the swedes. By going on with her work she felt better able to keep him outside her emotions.
她没有回答，他询问地看着她，她低着头，脸完全被兜帽遮住，继续修剪瑞典人的头发。通过继续工作，她感觉能够更好地让他远离自己的情绪。

‘Tess,’ he added, with a sigh of discontent,—‘yours was the very worst case I ever was concerned in! I had no idea of what had resulted till you told me. Scamp that I was to foul that innocent life! The whole blame was mine—the whole unconventional business of our time at Trantridge. You, too, the real blood of which I am but the base imitation, what a blind young thing you were as to possibilities! I say in all earnestness that it is a shame for parents to bring up their girls in such dangerous ignorance of the gins and nets that the wicked may set for them, whether their motive be a good one or the result of simple indifference.’
“苔丝，”他不满地叹了口气，补充道，“你的案子是我处理过的最糟糕的案子！”在你告诉我之前我不知道发生了什么。恶棍说我玷污了这个无辜的生命！全部责任都在我身上——我们在特兰特里奇时代的所有非传统事务。你也一样，我只是你的真血脉的仿制品，你对可能性是多么盲目的年轻人啊！我郑重地说，父母在对恶人可能为她们设置的杜松子酒和渔网如此危险的无知的情况下抚养自己的女儿是一种耻辱，无论他们的动机是好的还是纯粹的冷漠。

Tess still did no more than listen, throwing down one globular root and taking up another with automatic regularity, the pensive contour of the mere fieldwoman alone marking her.
苔丝仍然只是听着，自动有规律地扔下一根球状根，又拿起另一根，那是一个田野女工独自沉思的轮廓。

‘But it is not that I came to say,’ d’Urberville went on. ‘My circumstances are these. I have lost my mother since you were at Trantridge, and the place is my own. But I intend to sell it, and devote myself to missionary work in Africa. A devil of a poor hand I shall make at the trade, no doubt. However, what I want to ask you is, will you put it in my power to do my duty—to make the only reparation I can make for the trick played you: that is, will you be my wife, and go with me? ... I have already obtained this precious document. It was my old mother’s dying wish.’
“但这并不是我来要说的，”德伯维尔继续说道。 ‘我的情况是这样的。自从你来到特兰特里奇之后，我就失去了我的母亲，而这个地方就是我自己的了。但我打算卖掉它，投身于非洲的传教工作。毫无疑问，我在这行生意上将是一个可怜的人。然而，我想问你的是，你愿意让我尽我的职责吗——为我对你的恶作剧做出唯一的补偿：那就是，你愿意做我的妻子，跟我走吗？ ……这份珍贵的文件我已经拿到了。这是我老母亲的遗愿。

He drew a piece of parchment from his pocket, with a slight fumbling of embarrassment.
他从口袋里掏出一张羊皮纸，有点尴尬地摸索着。

‘What is it?’ said she.
“这是什么？”她说。

‘A marriage licence.’
“结婚证。”

‘O no, sir—no!’ she said quickly, starting back.
“哦，不，先生——不！”她迅速说道，同时向后退了一步。

‘You will not? Why is that?’
'你不会？这是为什么？'

And as he asked the question a disappointment which was not entirely the disappointment of thwarted duty crossed d’Urberville’s face. It was unmistakably a symptom that something of his old passion for her had been revived; duty and desire ran hand-in-hand.
当他问这个问题的时候，德伯维尔的脸上掠过一种失望，这种失望并不完全是因为职责受阻而感到的失望。毫无疑问，这是他对她旧日热情的某种征兆。责任和欲望齐头并进。

‘Surely,’ he began again, in more impetuous tones, and then looked round at the labourer who turned the slicer.
“当然，”他又开始说道，语气更加急躁，然后转身看着转动切片机的工人。

Tess, too, felt that the argument could not be ended there. Informing the man that a gentleman had come to see her, with whom she wished to walk a little way, she moved off with d’Urberville across the zebra-striped field. When they reached the first newly-ploughed section he held out his hand to help her over it; but she stepped forward on the summits of the earth-rolls as if she did not see him.
苔丝也觉得争论不能就此结束。她告诉那个男人，有一位绅士来看望她，她想和他一起走一段路，然后她和德伯维尔一起穿过斑马条纹的田野。当他们到达第一个新耕地时，他伸出手来帮助她翻过去。但她在土卷顶上向前迈步，仿佛没有看到他。

‘You will not marry me, Tess, and make me a self-respecting man?’ he repeated, as soon as they were over the furrows.
“苔丝，你不愿意嫁给我，让我成为一个有自尊的男人吗？”他们一跨过犁沟，他就重复道。

‘I cannot.’
'我不能。'

‘But why?’
'但为什么？'

‘You know I have no affection for you.’
“你知道我对你没有感情。”

‘But you would get to feel that in time, perhaps—as soon as you really could forgive me?’
“但你也许会及时感受到这一点——一旦你真的能够原谅我？”

‘Never!’
'绝不！'

‘Why so positive?’
“为什么这么积极？”

‘I love somebody else.’
“我爱别人。”

The words seemed to astonish him.
这句话似乎让他吃了一惊。

‘You do?’ he cried. ‘Somebody else? But has not a sense of what is morally right and proper any weight with you?’
“你知道吗？”他喊道。 '其他人？但你难道不知道什么是道德上正确和适当的吗？

‘No, no, no—don’t say that!’
“不，不，不——别这么说！”

‘Anyhow, then, your love for this other man may be only a passing feeling which you will overcome—‘
“无论如何，你对另一个男人的爱可能只是一种短暂的感觉，你会克服它——”

‘No—no.’
'不，不。'

‘Yes, yes! Why not?’
'是的是的！为什么不？'

‘I cannot tell you.’
'我不能告诉你。'

‘You must in honour!’
“你必须尊重！”

‘Well then ... I have married him.’
“那么……我就嫁给了他。”

‘Ah!’ he exclaimed; and he stopped dead and gazed at her.
“啊！”他惊呼道。他停了下来，凝视着她。

‘I did not wish to tell—I did not mean to!’ she pleaded. ‘It is a secret here, or at any rate but dimly known. So will you, PLEASE will you, keep from questioning me? You must remember that we are now strangers.’
“我不想告诉——我不是故意的！”她恳求道。 “这是这里的一个秘密，或者至少是一个隐秘的秘密。那么，请你不要再质疑我好吗？你必须记住，我们现在是陌生人了。”

‘Strangers—are we? Strangers!’
“我们是陌生人吗？陌生人！’

For a moment a flash of his old irony marked his face; but he determinedly chastened it down.
有一瞬间，他的脸上闪过一丝古老的讽刺意味。但他坚决将其抑制住。

‘Is that man your husband?’ he asked mechanically, denoting by a sign the labourer who turned the machine.
“那个人是你的丈夫吗？”他机械地问道，并用一个标志来表示转动机器的工人。

‘That man!’ she said proudly. ‘I should think not!’
“那个男人！”她自豪地说。 “我想不会！”

‘Who, then?’
“那么谁呢？”

‘Do not ask what I do not wish to tell!’ she begged, and flashed her appeal to him from her upturned face and lash-shadowed eyes.
“不要问我不想告诉的事情！”她恳求道，并从她仰起的脸和浓密的睫毛中闪现出对他的恳求。

D’Urberville was disturbed.
德伯维尔感到不安。

‘But I only asked for your sake!’ he retorted hotly. ‘Angels of heaven!—God forgive me for such an expression—I came here, I swear, as I thought for your good. Tess—don’t look at me so—I cannot stand your looks! There never were such eyes, surely, before Christianity or since! There—I won’t lose my head; I dare not. I own that the sight of you had waked up my love for you, which, I believed, was extinguished with all such feelings. But I thought that our marriage might be a sanctification for us both. ‘The unbelieving husband is sanctified by the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified by the husband,’ I said to myself. But my plan is dashed from me; and I must bear the disappointment!’
“但我只是为了你才要求的！”他激烈地反驳道。 “天上的天使们！——上帝原谅我这样的表达——我发誓，我来到这里，是为了你们好。苔丝——别这样看着我——我受不了你的眼神！当然，在基督教之前或之后从未有过这样的眼睛！在那里——我不会失去理智；我不敢。我承认，看到你就唤醒了我对你的爱，我相信，这种爱已经随着所有这些感情而消失了。但我认为我们的婚姻对我们俩来说可能都是神圣的。 “不信的丈夫因妻子而成圣，不信的妻子因丈夫而成圣，”我对自己说。但我的计划落空了；我必须承受失望！

He moodily reflected with his eyes on the ground.
他眼睛盯着地面，心情郁闷地思考着。

‘Married. Married! ... Well, that being so,’ he added, quite calmly, tearing the licence slowly into halves and putting them in his pocket; ‘that being prevented, I should like to do some good to you and your husband, whoever he may be. There are many questions that I am tempted to ask, but I will not do so, of course, in opposition to your wishes. Though, if I could know your husband, I might more easily benefit him and you. Is he on this farm?’
'已婚。已婚！ ……好吧，既然如此，”他相当平静地补充道，慢慢地将许可证撕成两半，放进口袋里； “既然被阻止了，我想为你和你的丈夫做点好事，无论他是谁。我有很多问题想问，但我当然不会违背你们的意愿。不过，如果我能了解你的丈夫，我可能会更容易使他和你受益。他在这个农场吗？

‘No,’ she murmured. ‘He is far away.’
“不，”她低声说。 “他离得很远。”

‘Far away? From YOU? What sort of husband can he be?’
'离这很远？来自你？他能成为什么样的丈夫？

‘O, do not speak against him! It was through you! He found out—‘
‘哦，不要反对他！是通过你！他发现——‘

‘Ah, is it so! ... That’s sad, Tess!’
‘啊，是这样吗！ ......这太悲伤了，苔丝！

‘Yes.’
'是的。'

‘But to stay away from you—to leave you to work like this!’
“但是要远离你——让你这样工作！”

‘He does not leave me to work!’ she cried, springing to the defence of the absent one with all her fervour. ‘He don’t know it! It is by my own arrangement.’
“他不让我干活！”她喊道，并用全部热情跳起来为缺席的人辩护。 ‘他不知道！这是我自己安排的。”

‘Then, does he write?’
“那么，他写字吗？”

‘I—I cannot tell you. There are things which are private to ourselves.’
“我——我不能告诉你。有些事情是我们自己私人的。

‘Of course that means that he does not. You are a deserted wife, my fair Tess—‘
‘当然，这意味着他不这样做。你是一个被遗弃的妻子，我美丽的苔丝——”

In an impulse he turned suddenly to take her hand; the buff-glove was on it, and he seized only the rough leather fingers which did not express the life or shape of those within.
他一时冲动，突然转身握住她的手。上面戴着浅黄色手套，他只抓住了粗糙的皮革手指，这些手指并不能表现出里面的生物的生命或形状。

‘You must not—you must not!’ she cried fearfully, slipping her hand from the glove as from a pocket, and leaving it in his grasp. ‘O, will you go away—for the sake of me and my husband—go, in the name of your own Christianity!’
“你不可以——你不可以！”她恐惧地喊道，把手从手套里抽出来，就像从口袋里抽出来一样，把它留在他的手里。 “哦，为了我和我丈夫的缘故，你愿意走开吗？以你自己基督教的名义，走开吧！”

‘Yes, yes; I will,’ he said abruptly, and thrusting the glove back to her he turned to leave. Facing round, however, he said, ‘Tess, as God is my judge, I meant no humbug in taking your hand!’
'是的是的;我会的。”他突然说道，然后把手套推回给她，然后转身离开。然而，他转过身来，说道：“苔丝，上帝是我的法官，我握住你的手并不是有意欺骗！”

A pattering of hoofs on the soil of the field, which they had not noticed in their preoccupation, ceased close behind them; and a voice reached her ear:
田野上的马蹄声在他们全神贯注的时候没有注意到，在他们身后停止了。一个声音传到了她的耳边：

‘What the devil are you doing away from your work at this time o’ day?’
“这个时候你工作之余到底在做什么？”

Farmer Groby had espied the two figures from the distance, and had inquisitively ridden across, to learn what was their business in his field.
农夫格罗比从远处看到了两个人影，好奇地骑马过去，想了解他们在他的田地里做什么。

‘Don’t speak like that to her!’ said d’Urberville, his face blackening with something that was not Christianity.
“别这样对她说话！”德伯维尔说，他的脸因某种非基督教的东西而变黑。

‘Indeed, Mister! And what mid Methodist pa’sons have to do with she?’
‘确实如此，先生！卫理公会中间的信徒和她有什么关系？

‘Who is the fellow?’ asked d’Urberville, turning to Tess.
“这家伙是谁？”德伯维尔转向苔丝问道。

She went close up to him.
她靠近他。

‘Go—I do beg you!’ she said.
“走吧——我求你了！”她说。

‘What! And leave you to that tyrant? I can see in his face what a churl he is.’
'什么！然后把你留给那个暴君？我从他的脸上看出他是个多么粗鲁的人。

‘He won’t hurt me. HE’S not in love with me. I can leave at Lady-Day.’
‘他不会伤害我。他不爱我。我可以在女士节那天离开。

‘Well, I have no right but to obey, I suppose. But—well, goodbye!’
“好吧，我想我除了服从之外没有权利。但是——好吧，再见！

Her defender, whom she dreaded more than her assailant, having reluctantly disappeared, the farmer continued his reprimand, which Tess took with the greatest coolness, that sort of attack being independent of sex. To have as a master this man of stone, who would have cuffed her if he had dared, was almost a relief after her former experiences. She silently walked back towards the summit of the field that was the scene of her labour, so absorbed in the interview which had just taken place that she was hardly aware that the nose of Groby’s horse almost touched her shoulders.
她的保护者，她比袭击者更害怕的农夫不情愿地消失了，农夫继续他的斥责，苔丝以极大的冷静对待，这种攻击与性别无关。有了这个石人当主人，如果他敢的话，他就会给她戴上手铐，这让她在经历了之前的经历之后几乎松了口气。她默默地走回田野的山顶，那是她的劳动现场，她全神贯注于刚刚进行的采访，几乎没有意识到格罗比的马的鼻子几乎碰到了她的肩膀。

‘If so be you make an agreement to work for me till Lady-Day, I’ll see that you carry it out,’ he growled. ‘‘Od rot the women—now ‘tis one thing, and then ‘tis another. But I’ll put up with it no longer!’
“如果你同意为我工作直到情人节，我会确保你执行它，”他咆哮道。 “女人会腐烂——现在是一回事，然后又是另一回事。但我不会再忍受了！

Knowing very well that he did not harass the other women of the farm as he harassed her out of spite for the flooring he had once received, she did for one moment picture what might have been the result if she had been free to accept the offer just made her of being the monied Alec’s wife. It would have lifted her completely out of subjection, not only to her present oppressive employer, but to a whole world who seemed to despise her. ‘But no, no!’ she said breathlessly; ‘I could not have married him now! He is so unpleasant to me.’
她很清楚，他骚扰农场里的其他妇女并不是因为他曾经收到的地板而骚扰她，她有那么一刻想象，如果她可以自由地接受这个提议，可能会出现什么结果。刚刚让她成为了有钱人亚历克的妻子。这将使她完全摆脱屈服，不仅是对她目前的压迫性雇主，而且是对整个似乎鄙视她的世界。 “但是不，不！”她气喘吁吁地说。 “我现在不可能嫁给他！他对我来说太不愉快了。

That very night she began an appealing letter to Clare, concealing from him her hardships, and assuring him of her undying affection. Any one who had been in a position to read between the lines would have seen that at the back of her great love was some monstrous fear—almost a desperation—as to some secret contingencies which were not disclosed. But again she did not finish her effusion; he had asked Izz to go with him, and perhaps he did not care for her at all. She put the letter in her box, and wondered if it would ever reach Angel’s hands.
那天晚上，她开始给克莱尔写了一封恳求信，向他隐瞒了她的艰辛，并向他保证了她永恒的爱。任何一个有能力读懂字里行间的人都会发现，在她伟大的爱情背后，隐藏着某种可怕的恐惧——几乎是绝望——对一些未透露的秘密意外事件。但她又没有把话吐完。他邀请伊兹和他一起去，也许他根本不关心她。她把信放进盒子里，想知道它是否会到达安吉尔的手中。

After this her daily tasks were gone through heavily enough, and brought on the day which was of great import to agriculturists—the day of the Candlemas Fair. It was at this fair that new engagements were entered into for the twelve months following the ensuing Lady-Day, and those of the farming population who thought of changing their places duly attended at the county-town where the fair was held. Nearly all the labourers on Flintcomb-Ash farm intended flight, and early in the morning there was a general exodus in the direction of the town, which lay at a distance of from ten to a dozen miles over hilly country. Though Tess also meant to leave at the quarter-day, she was one of the few who did not go to the fair, having a vaguely-shaped hope that something would happen to render another outdoor engagement unnecessary.
此后，她的日常任务完成得足够繁重，并在对农学家来说非常重要的一天——圣烛节那天完成。正是在这个集市上，在随后的女士节之后的十二个月里，新的约定得以签订，而那些想要改变自己位置的农民也正式来到了集市举办的县城。弗林特科姆-阿什农场的几乎所有工人都打算逃走，清晨，人们普遍向城镇方向逃亡，城镇距离丘陵地带十到十几英里。尽管苔丝也打算在季度日离开，但她是少数没有去集市的人之一，她隐隐约约地希望会发生什么事情，使另一次户外活动变得不必要。

It was a peaceful February day, of wonderful softness for the time, and one would almost have thought that winter was over. She had hardly finished her dinner when d’Urberville’s figure darkened the window of the cottage wherein she was a lodger, which she had all to herself to-day.
那是二月里一个宁静的日子，当时的天气非常柔和，人们几乎以为冬天已经结束了。她刚吃完晚饭，德伯维尔的身影就遮住了她寄宿的小屋的窗户，而今天，她独享了这座小屋。

Tess jumped up, but her visitor had knocked at the door, and she could hardly in reason run away. D’Urberville’s knock, his walk up to the door, had some indescribable quality of difference from his air when she last saw him. They seemed to be acts of which the doer was ashamed. She thought that she would not open the door; but, as there was no sense in that either, she arose, and having lifted the latch stepped back quickly. He came in, saw her, and flung himself down into a chair before speaking.
苔丝跳了起来，但她的客人已经敲门了，她根本无法逃跑。德伯维尔的敲门声，他走向门口的动作，与她上次见到他时的神态有着难以形容的不同。这些行为似乎让行为者感到羞耻。她以为自己不会开门，没想到却是这样。但是，因为这也毫无意义，她站了起来，打开门闩后迅速向后退了一步。他走进来，看到了她，然后一屁股坐到了椅子上，然后才开口说话。

‘Tess—I couldn’t help it!’ he began desperately, as he wiped his heated face, which had also a superimposed flush of excitement. ‘I felt that I must call at least to ask how you are. I assure you I had not been thinking of you at all till I saw you that Sunday; now I cannot get rid of your image, try how I may! It is hard that a good woman should do harm to a bad man; yet so it is. If you would only pray for me, Tess!’
“苔丝——我没办法！”他绝望地说道，同时擦了擦发烫的脸，脸上还夹杂着兴奋的红晕。 “我觉得我至少必须打电话问问你怎么样。我向你保证，在那个周日见到你之前，我根本就没在想你。现在我无法摆脱你的形象，试试我能做的吧！好女人很难伤害坏男人；但事实确实如此。如果你能为我祈祷就好了，苔丝！

The suppressed discontent of his manner was almost pitiable, and yet Tess did not pity him.
他的态度中压抑着的不满几乎是可怜的，但苔丝并不怜悯他。

‘How can I pray for you,’ she said, ‘when I am forbidden to believe that the great Power who moves the world would alter His plans on my account?’
“当我被禁止相信推动世界的伟大力量会因为我而改变他的计划时，我该如何为你祈祷呢？”她说。

‘You really think that?’
“你真的这么认为吗？”

‘Yes. I have been cured of the presumption of thinking otherwise.’
'是的。我已经摆脱了不这样想的假设。

‘Cured? By whom?’
‘治愈了？通过谁？'

‘By my husband, if I must tell.’
“如果我必须告诉的话，是我丈夫的。”

‘Ah—your husband—your husband! How strange it seems! I remember you hinted something of the sort the other day. What do you really believe in these matters, Tess?’ he asked. ‘You seem to have no religion—perhaps owing to me.’
‘啊——你的丈夫——你的丈夫！看起来多么奇怪啊！我记得前几天你暗示过类似的事情。 “苔丝，你对这些事情到底相信什么？”他问道。 “你似乎没有宗教信仰——也许是因为我。”

‘But I have. Though I don’t believe in anything supernatural.’
'但我有。虽然我不相信任何超自然的东西。

D’Urberville looked at her with misgiving.
德伯维尔疑惑地看着她。

‘Then do you think that the line I take is all wrong?’
“那你认为我采取的路线是错误的吗？”

‘A good deal of it.’
“很多。”

‘H’m—and yet I’ve felt so sure about it,’ he said uneasily.
“嗯——但我对此非常确定，”他不安地说。

‘I believe in the SPIRIT of the Sermon on the Mount, and so did my dear husband... But I don’t believe—‘
“我相信登山宝训的精神，我亲爱的丈夫也是如此……但我不相信——”

Here she gave her negations.
在这里她给出了否定。

‘The fact is,’ said d’Urberville drily, ‘whatever your dear husband believed you accept, and whatever he rejected you reject, without the least inquiry or reasoning on your own part. That’s just like you women. Your mind is enslaved to his.’
“事实是，”德伯维尔冷冷地说，“无论你亲爱的丈夫相信什么，你都接受，无论他拒绝什么，你都拒绝，而你自己却没有丝毫询问或推理。这就像你们女人一样。你的思想被他的思想所奴役。

‘Ah, because he knew everything!’ said she, with a triumphant simplicity of faith in Angel Clare that the most perfect man could hardly have deserved, much less her husband.
“啊，因为他什么都知道！”她说道，带着对安吉尔·克莱尔的一种胜利般的简单信念，这是最完美的男人都难以配得上的，更不用说她的丈夫了。

‘Yes, but you should not take negative opinions wholesale from another person like that. A pretty fellow he must be to teach you such scepticism!’
“是的，但你不应该像这样从另一个人那里接受大量的负面意见。他一定是个漂亮的小伙子，竟然教你这样的怀疑态度！

‘He never forced my judgement! He would never argue on the subject with me! But I looked at it in this way; what he believed, after inquiring deep into doctrines, was much more likely to be right than what I might believe, who hadn’t looked into doctrines at all.’
‘他从来没有强迫我做出判断！他永远不会和我争论这个问题！但我是这样看的；在深入探究教义之后，他所相信的东西比我根本没有研究过教义的人所相信的更有可能是正确的。

‘What used he to say? He must have said something?’
‘他说什么？他一定说了些什么吧？

She reflected; and with her acute memory for the letter of Angel Clare’s remarks, even when she did not comprehend their spirit, she recalled a merciless polemical syllogism that she had heard him use when, as it occasionally happened, he indulged in a species of thinking aloud with her at his side. In delivering it she gave also Clare’s accent and manner with reverential faithfulness.
她反思道：她对安吉尔·克莱尔的言论有着敏锐的记忆，即使她不理解他们的精神，她也记得她曾听到他使用过一种无情的辩论三段论，当时他偶尔会沉迷于一种大声思考的情况。她在他身边。在讲话时，她还带着虔诚的忠诚表现出了克莱尔的口音和举止。

‘Say that again,’ asked d’Urberville, who had listened with the greatest attention.
“再说一遍，”德伯维尔问道，他全神贯注地听着。

She repeated the argument, and d’Urberville thoughtfully murmured the words after her.
她重复了一遍这个论点，德伯维尔在她身后若有所思地低声说道。

‘Anything else?’ he presently asked.
“还有什么事吗？”他立即问道。

‘He said at another time something like this”; and she gave another, which might possibly have been paralleled in many a work of the pedigree ranging from the Dictionnaire Philosophique to Huxley’s Essays.
“他在另一次说过这样的话”；她还给出了另一本，这可能在从《哲学词典》到赫胥黎的《随笔集》等许多谱系著作中都有相似之处。

‘Ah—ha! How do you remember them?’
‘啊——哈！你怎么记得他们？

‘I wanted to believe what he believed, though he didn’t wish me to; and I managed to coax him to tell me a few of his thoughts. I can’t say I quite understand that one; but I know it is right.’
“我想相信他所相信的，尽管他不希望我这么做；”我设法哄他告诉我一些他的想法。我不能说我完全理解这一点；但我知道这是对的。”

‘H’m. Fancy your being able to teach me what you don’t know yourself!’
‘嗯。希望你能够教我你自己都不知道的东西！

He fell into thought.
他陷入了沉思。

‘And so I threw in my spiritual lot with his,’ she resumed. ‘I didn’t wish it to be different. What’s good enough for him is good enough for me.’
“所以我把我的精神命运和他的命运放在了一起，”她继续说道。 “我不希望事情有所不同。对他来说足够好的对我来说也足够好。

‘Does he know that you are as big an infidel as he?’
